												10/10This game is amazing. It is different from most games out there, which may bother some people.You run your own super sentai studio. which involves the management stuff: hire actors, buy/craft equipment, upgrade studio, take care of your fan base, hire marketing agencies. And of course, there is the action: fighting monsters, mecha battles. The pros:- Amazing soundtrack. Really, really, really amazing. You'll feel like a child again watching power rangers, black kamen rider or your favorite super sentai show.- Beautiful graphics. The very best 2D Pixel Art style.- Humor everywhere. A lot of hidden references. Pretty cool!- Great squad customization. You cannot create your own character. You assign actors to squad's roles and you can choose their color, name, skill, equips, weapon. You can also choose the name of the squad, the name of the mecha, the catching phrase.- Solid combat. Very fun, specially if you follow the director's instructions. - Lots of content. This game is huge. You can have 15 hours+ of gameplay. The cons:- Can't stop playing it!

												Enjoying turn based roleplaying? Enjoying squad based character control? Enjoying Sentai?Get this Game, Now! You don't even need to read further.A long, long time ago, when I first heard about Chroma Squad, I instantly backed these lovely people at Behold Studios and read every single update they came up with. Seeing this game progress over time was just amazing. Especially to see, how the developers sometimes struggled, but what they have now delivered is really big fun.You play as a 5 people stunt crew that worked for a very mad producer but decide to quit and create your own show.The game basically exists from 3 parts:- Studio management (Buying Props, handling Marketing, dealing with spam mails)- Episode recording (fights of your squad agains a bunch of enemies, kicking butts)- Mecha fights (mini game type 1-on-1 fights)The mechanics of the game seem to be very simple, and I guess they really are. But the gags that have been hidden everywere are just great (I guess, a lot of people might miss a lot, as they are too young).There is only bad thing I can tell about the game:@DEVS: Please add that the virtual keyboard pops up, when I play on a Tablet on my train journeys :)

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
Chroma SquadDeveloper: Behold StudiosPublisher: Behold StudiosNote: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.Introduction==========Back in the old days there were a flood of Sentai TV series: Power Rangers, Sailor Moon, Beetle Borgs, Tattooed Teenage Alien Fighters from Beverly Hills, Samurai Cyber Squad, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, etc etc. The list goes on for quite a while. Sentai translates to "Task Force" or "Squadron" and is usually a team of heroes wearing color coded outfits or uniforms. Basically superheroes...Japanese style! Generally they come with a range of personalities/roles that usually follows some variation of the Five-Man Band. Known for their synchronized posing; also, a standard powerup pose is often used in many Sentai works during the transformation sequence. A key concept is that the collective team are more important than the individual, and that more can be achieved by working together. Chroma Squad is directly inspired by Saban's Power Rangers, and capitalizes on most of these concepts from the Sentai genre but takes it a bit further in that you are actually managing the studio shooting the TV series!Gameplay==========Starting up the game you are introduced to your team of actors/heroes, as they are in the middle of a shoot for a TV show, taking a lot of crap from their director in the process. By the end of the shoot, the actors decide to ditch their jerk of a director and start their own TV studio and sentai hero show! One of the actor's has an uncle that lends you an old warehouse where you setup your new studio. At the start of your new career, you get to customize your team of actors, choosing what color their suit will be, the actors themselves, and change their names. You are then able to choose your studio's name, and some various phrases that will you used throughout the game, such as when your actors "morph" into their hero suits ("Chromatize!"). As a studio manager, it's your job to choose which episodes get aired and in what order. At the main screen, you can choose to buy equipment/props for your actors that boost their stats in battle scenes. You can also check yoru fan mail, which you will recieve regularly and are able to choose differents responses to. Sometimes depending on your responses you will lose or gain money and/or items. Items can also be crafted using materials you find in combat, such as duct tape and cardboard. The main draw of Chroma Squad is in the action scenes - combat. Chroma Squad utilizes a very simple tactical RPG system in which you can move your team across a grid on the battlefield. During your "Phase" you can direct any of your actors in any order you choose until they've all had an action, then it's the Enemy's "Phase". Each character has access to a limited set of skills, and the number of skills you can use increases as you shoot more episodes and as you wrap up more seasons of the show. Your team is able to use special "Teamwork" actions, which can be very, very useful in dealing damage or traversing the battlefield. For example, one actor can toss another one, enabling them to cover more distance. Another example is having 2 or more adjacent actors attack the same enemy in a team attack. Lastly, if all 5 of your actors are adjacent to an enemy, you can use a Finishing Move, dealing massive damage to your target! FEAR THE POWER OF TEAMWORK! Each scene also has special challenges in the form of Director's Instructions. These can range from reaching an objective within a specfied number of turns, or defeating a certain number of minions before attacking a boss. Completing these orders rewards you with extra points that are converted into fans and money at the end of every episode. Most sentai shows had giant mech suits...such as Power Rangers' MegaZord. Chroma Squad has a similar feature! Perhaps one of the best things about Chroma Squad is the enemy designs. Early on you meet a fellow named Transitmancer -- a mage wield a staff with a traffic signal attached to the top of it. You will also meet enemies like "The Boxing Box"...which is literally a cardboard box with arms, wearing boxing gloves. There's way more creative ones and even some cameos, but I don't want to spoil too much of the fun!Graphics==========If you have played Behold Studio's previous game, Knights of Pen and Paper, you will be familiar with the art style used here. It's slightly more advanced than KoPaP, with even more details on each sprite. Combat animations, movement, and even the special attacks are very well animated and look really nice. Props look great, and like I said before character designs and enemies look amazing.Sound and Music==========This game has one of the most amazing soundtracks I have heard in quite a long time. The best tracks are the battle tunes by FAR. Just let a battle start and leave it there for a few to take it in. They really get you pumped up for any challenges you are faced with! I have added most of it to my YouTube playlist reserved specially for great game music! The soundtrack is available for purchase on the Store Page for $4.99. Well worth it! Seriously, just give this a listen:


YouTube™ Video: Chroma Squad OST: 10. On to Plan B 

			Views: 6,112		

			TODA O ÁLBUM ESTÁ DISPONÍVEL NA STEAM: http://store.steampowered.com/app/363800/ Compre e ajuda uma empresa brasileira!...		

The sound effects are pretty minimal, but they do their job. I can't fault the sound direction here, as it's pretty well done despite being fairly minimal. The soundtrack more than makes up for any shortcomings!Performance==========Chroma Squad runs like a dream. No crashes, stuttering, framerate drops, or any weird glitches were encountered during my playtime so far, and I really don't expect to see any. Behold Studios is usually really good about the quality of their games, as we've seen so far. I didn't think to test the game with my controller, as mouse and keyboard worked extremely well. Probably best for this type of game anyway.Final Thoughts==========If you are looking for a fun tactical RPG that's a bit different and has a ton of humor, Chroma Squad fits the bill perfectly. Such a great little title, and a complete joy to play. You should not hesitate at all in buying this, it's quite the gem! The soundtrack alone is enough to justify the purchase. Gameplay Demo==========

Nerd House Verdict:==========Highly Recommended

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Behold Studios, the developer behind the fantastic Knights of Pen and Paper, have moved from an RPG about basement Dungeons & Dragons nights to an SRPG featuring a homemade super sentai TV show. It's not a massive leap in premise or design but that's not necessarily such a bad thing; KoPaP was a fantastic comedic RPG with enough depth to enjoy as a straight-forward game if humour isn't what you're seeking. While the visual design and menus are immediately familiar for players of the previous titles, I found Chroma Squad to be far and away the more enjoyable game; something I don't say lightly.The main meat of Chroma Squad's gameplay comes in the form of grid-based tactical combat where you lead your five person (and the occasional beaver) troop against generally overwhelming odds. It plays out like any game from the genre only fairly simplified. Streamlined is probably the more apt description though as you can easily find yourself tested, especially if you aim to complete the director's requests that come in twos for every single scene. Each character has their own class with subsequent perks to choose from so there's still plenty of strategy involved and the teamwork mechanics add a unique flavour with finishing moves and movement-extending throws.Like Knights of Pen and Paper, the simulation elements are quite light and serve as an outlet for cash to earn minor bonuses to certain stats. This isn't a business management sim like Game Dev Tycoon and while there are some moments of behind-the-scenes finance fiddling, it's more of a small taster between battles to break up the action than a full-blown hybridisation. However, there's no shortage of options for customisation and you can quickly build up a studio almost as unique to you as one you'd built yourself. You can enter personal phrases to be called out during gameplay, choose your actors, their suit colours and names, not to mention all the visual elements that come with stats like studio upgrades and equipment.Missions are varied affairs, with hostage situations, survival challenges and races against time thrown in to vary the typical back-and-forth fisticuffs. Early on, you unlock mecha missions which simulate Kaiju battles, these are mostly luck-based fights in the sense that you can keep up a combo as long as you want with the accuracy odds dropping with each successful hit. They can be frustrating but it offers a huge change from the basic battles and looks fantastic in action. It's likely the fights will be divisive with players but they're a great opportunity to see the huge robot you've been constructing from custom parts. At worst, they're a blip in an otherwise fantastic product but I enjoyed them at every occasion.I'm aware I've talked of the simplicity of the gameplay a fair bit and that it might put a lot of people off but it's been done to remove the chaff and alleviate the grind. There's still a wealth of stats to monitor, equipment to maintain and entire mechanics to indulge in should you so choose. The crafting adds an alternative to buying from shops with rarer and more effective items requiring that you deconstruct spare costume parts. Marketing options grant a huge range of bonuses upon finishing each episode and completed seasons create branches on the skill trees. It's not a slow-paced tactical XCOM clone and it's better off that way, instead it's a unique amalgamation of the best parts of so many different games and genres.The most obvious trait of Chroma Squad though, is it's humour. If you don't appreciate games that take a tongue-in-cheek poke at their subject matter then you might be disappointed; but really, what else would you expect from a game starring a homebrew TV setup where the costumes are made from cardboard and sticky-back plastic? A lot of the storyline doesn't really make that much sense, but again, neither did that of most live-action kid's TV shows. The script is mostly fluff and it's unlikely you'll be playing through each episode out of plot intrigue, but that's exactly what the stellar gameplay is there for. You'll still get laughs aplenty playing through the campaign and a constant silly grin from all the pop culture references generously heaped on top.I'll admit my review comes from the perspective of someone that has never watched a single episode of Power Rangers or anything of its ilk. I know the references and tropes well enough to have understand every in-joke but I went into Chroma Squad excited due to the developer and genre more than the setting of the game itself. I mention it only as I believe that lovers of all things Mighty Morphin will go on to enjoy this even more than I did. With that considered, there should probably be a health warning on this for the most rabid fans.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Edit: This review was done with a key obtained from the developer. Somehow, I missed the disclaimer on this originally.Not since Darkest Dungeon has an experience hit on as many levels as Chroma Squad has. There is a lot of wonderful design decisions made here, and the attention to detail is what shines here: Every detail seems to be thought out from the wonderful Tactical RPG that involves acrobatics and teamwork, to the detail of the story that plays to the strength of the nostalgia of the old Power Rangers. I had this goofy grin on my face the entire time I was playing the game, and this game is an early contender for Indie game of the year. It's that good.+:-Team based combat, especially on hard difficulties, rewards thinking and strategy in its teamwork based combat. Acrobatics (the ability to launch people further then they could run by themselves.-Strong detail payed attention to the details of each episode within the story, to make it feel like a old Power Rangers episode/series. -Customization of game takes things to new levels with catchphrases and squad names. Adds a whole level of immersion. -Little Details make the experience that much more immersive, such as punishing for using a finishing move that doesn't kill a monster. Audience gauge and Director guidelines help add challenge to make the episode more flashy. -Overall, the nostalgia that the game repeatedly hits works on almost every level, from the 8 bit graphics to the references to the series past. In addition, it's able to mix up the modern day media/internet culture into it as well. -Studio upgrades leave a lot of different options to play around with. Upgrades, Mech Upgrades, Studio Upgrades, etc.-:-Mech battles could be a little bit more challenging.-Some more information can be provided at times regarding teamwork skills (like the supports healing factor, for example)-Comes very close to copyright infrigenment in several cases. Worrisome in some cases. For Gameplay and First Impressions:

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I wanted Final Fantasy Tactics in Sentai suits and was not disappointed!No seriously, I'm calling Chroma Squad a must-buy in terms of tactical RPGs. At worst, the scenarios get kinda samey, the mecha battles are more luck-based than anything, Scout class needs work in terms of role within the team and the meme-based humour might get under some delicate skins. Never mind the details; as a tactical RPG, Chroma Squad gets everything right and even dares some neat ideas concerning character statistics, combat and the money/audience system.What I'm saying is there's a deepness to the game despite the apparent simplicity of the setting, with clear character roles and a certain leeway in how you want them optimized. The love for the genre is genuine and goes a long way in enhancing your experience; it's more than just shooting aliens as in X-Com. Building an audience to gain money and better toys is a welcome change from XP grinding. The grid movement can be unforgiving what with the inability to take back a move but I feel as this just adds to the challenge factor.In short: the core of the gameplay is great and the further you get from the tactical RPG, the worse it gets. I can't fault a game for false notes when it's just being overly ambitious. An original backdrop for an RPG, multiple story paths, clever insertion of Kickstarter backers into the story and the fact I've encountered no game-breaking bugs despite a Report button makes me want to heavily endorse this product. An example for other Kickstarter-funded game developers.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												An amazing game with noticeable flaws that tarnish the gameplay depending on the player.Pros:Nostalgic soundtrack and gameplay, balanced difficulty, loads of content/replayability, and creativity. Many games this generation are essentially creatively bankrupt, but Chroma Squad realizes this and challenges the standard of games today. A tycoon game with rpg gameplay and tons of customization has been completely unheard of. Fun humor and fun character designs, the game doesn't take itself seriously at all and knows its limits. It is literally self-aware of the tropes and cliches it uses. For example, in one point of the game, a girl needs to be rescued. One of the squad members questions if it should be a guy just to avoid using sexist tropes. The game knows the stupidity of generic hero-saving-the-day tv shows and utilizes it to bring out the fun that is in them easily. Also, if you are a fan of super sentai, you will laugh your♥♥♥♥♥off at these references. I promise you.Subjective:It's obvious just from the start of the game how much customization there is. You can customize everything- from your squad name, the names of your members, the attributes of the members, the weapons of the members, the abilities of the members, your mecha, your mecha's name, your transformation name, and way more. In theory, it sounds great, but when you get right down to it, it get's annoying. Have you ever felt the feeling of, "Ugh, I can't choose between these great abilities/weapons! I wish the game didn't even give me an option!" Well, half of the game is like that. It's so customizable to the point where it may ruin the enjoyment factor. Should I craft this? Should I buy this? Should I equip this? There's way too many choices. Me personally, I had only a few problems with this, considering how much I love customization in games. This is a pro or a con depending on the player.Cons:Repetitive. Incredibly repetitive, to the point where you say to yourself, "Really? This again?" The game is oozing with creativity but unfortunately the gameplay is designed so that almost all of the fights are entirely the same. Some enemies are different, the map layout is sometimes different (and other times copy pasted), but the game throws at you the same fights over and over again just to reach the conclusion. This is easily noticeable after getting through the start of the game. No effect on overall plot. Nothing you really do changes where the game is going. Sure, occasionally you get fans praising you for doing x or shunning you for doing y, but it doesn't really do much in the long run from what I've seen.Little strategy. Unless playing on the hardest difficulty, you only need a bit of strategy to complete the levels. Dialogue. The dialogue is sometimes humorous and creative, but really? It can be written by 5 year olds and probably be the same. The writing is pretty awful and the characters have little depth. This I get it; that's the whole point of the game. It doesn't take itself seriously and is SUPPOSED to be immature. It isn't that big of a deal, but the game could easily be better with more engaging dialogues and more clever jokes.Mecha fights. Fun the first time you launch it and the first time you use a new ability you got, but otherwise? Not engaging at all, and anti-climactic a lot of the time. Incredibly repetitive. Overall though? Do I have to go through a bit of repetitiveness and subpar dialogue to enjoy a game with tons of replayability, nostalgic design/soundtrack and a unique experience? Definitely. This game is fun as hell.

												If you are a fan of Power Rangers or Super Sentai. You should give it a try!Lots of subtile references/nods to Super Sentai seasons. (Won't say what they are but if you've seen sentai seasons of the last 2-3 years, you'll see some and will put a smile on your face!) Gameplay is really simplistic (Don't go into it expecting complicated mechanics like from the Disgaea Series) but honestly it doesn't need to be overwhelming. The overall episode "goals" challenge you to certain things before the end of the section. Have yet to run into one that wasn't impossible. As the seasons (5 in total) go on, you'll come across items to craft and buy to upgrade your Squad members, so there is atleast some customization for you to play with as you're going along the story.After each episode you get revenue based on how many fans you get. Fans are usually earned if you use an ability or complete one of the episode goals. Most goals tend to give you well enough fans to hit the cap. If a squad member falls, it'll subtract fans. Later on you'll start to get contracts from agencies that can change the end revenue based on what you want. +Money? +Fans? Things like that. The more fans you have, the more bonuses you could have!Again if you like Power Rangers/Super Sentai or Tokusatsu, try this out! If you aren't, you may not understand the fourth wall breaking studio-type story the game has. But the gameplay is still enjoyable!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Chroma Squad is a Tactical RPG made by Behold Studios, the developers behind Knights of Pen & Paper. Chroma Squad is a love letter and a tribute to decades of Japanese superhero shows such as: Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and the Metal Hero series. =STORY=You start off as a five-people  team of stuntactors who decide to make their own Sentai-themed TV show in which they become a Sentai team themselves and fight against all sorts of monsters while managing their resources and fan-community behind the scenes. The first two seasons start very tame since you’re still an indie Sentai studio with a low budget, but from season 3 onwards the plot becomes more serious and fascinating.Depending on your choice during the finale of season 4, you might either end up doing the Rider route, the Metal Hero route or the Sixth Ranger route. I won’t spoil much, but each route has their own scenarios going on with interesting mini stories that contribute to the game’s lore. The finale of the game itself is amazing, and is something to behold and be amazed at – I’ll try not to spoil it, but it’s definitely “empowering”.Mind you, the game developers have suggested to implement more alternate endings or routes  within future DLC or updates, so this review might end up dated and not give a complete overview to what the story system of Chroma Squad offers.= CUSTOMIZATION =This is arguably my favourite part of the game, ‘cuz who doesn’t want to make their very own Sentai dream team? You can customize your team by choosing out of approx. 20 actors, each with their own appearances and bonuses. You can also name them and decide which suit colour they wear, i.e. if you always wanted to make an all-Red ranger team, well here’s your chance! Throughout the seasons, the game offers various types of helmets and suits that not only give certain statboosts but also visually alter the appearance of your hero. Unfortunately, the amount of actors and visual-altering equipment you can choose from is quite limited, so you’ll have to either wait for future DLC or step up your modding skills.You can also name your studio, your team, your giant robot, your transformation and lines of dialogue that call forth said mech, transformation and team attack. While it doesn’t give you the ultimate customization possibilities like customizing your own hero costume or actor from scratch, the game offers a decent amount of customization which will hopefully be expanded in the future.= GAMEPLAY =While the game is a turn-based tactical system, it’s not as complex or multi-faceted as Super Robot Wars, but neither is it overtly simplistic. You generally control five characters, each with their own stats depending on equipment, actor, role and bonuses you’ve activated through studio upgrades or siding with the more favourable marketing agencies. Each role offers a variety of skill, the Techie and Support role are for example more oriented on long-range and healing skills, respectively. Your characters can generally do two actions per turn – in most cases you’ll (1) move to the enemy and (2) perform an attack or (1)(2) move to the other end of the screen. Your heroes can wield weapons which not only increase attack damage but also provide with an extra skill. Last but not least, there’s the Teamwork mechanic in which you can make two or more of your heroes pull off an combined attack at an enemy they’re both facing.The giant robot vs giant monster battles have a more mini-game feel to it, but it can still be one heck of an intense battle. It’s a sideview turn-based battle in which you can hit the enemy multiple times until your turn is ended through missing the opponent, ending your combo with the defend options or ending the turn with a super attack. During the enemy’s turn you must step up your reaction game to minimize the amount of damage your mech will receive.Outside of missions, there’s also a light Studio Simulation system going on – i.e. you’ll get to read and answer fan letters, upgrade your studio for additional bonuses, upgrade your giant robot, buy equipment, craft equipment or materials and side with the marketing agencies that give you the best bonuses or help you earn and gain more money and fans.= OVERALL =If you’ve longed for a game in which you can make your own Sentai team and fight against hordes of enemies with the help of unlikely allies and your trusty giant robot , then look no further because Chroma Squad is arguably the best Sentai game if not one of the best Henshin Hero games up to this point. The story, several dialogues and fan letters will make you laugh and smile – and perhaps, even give you the feeling that you’re being a true hero of justice. Gameplay-wise, Chroma Squad is a very accessible game but not without a challenge for those who want to step up their game. While the visuals and soundtrack aren’t AAA-tier, they’re still pleasing and amazing to see and listen to nonetheless. This game is definitely made with love, and it shows. I can’t wait for the future updates and potential-DLC this game has to offer. Behold Studios, you’re the best and thank you for this amazing loveletter to decades of tokusatsu heroism.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Chromatize!!!Oh, this game is going to stay in my mind when I am thinking about round based strategie right after UFO: Enemy Unkown (sorry - its hard to beat that one)You play as 5 stunt(wo)men who decide to disobey their director and leave to make a hero-show on their own. Each has a specific role ingame that makes one more awesome than the other. The plot divides and intertwines between "real-life" and show which leads to funny dialouges between the characters and enemies.The game itself is NOT a serious simulation and even makes fun of itself. Its mixed with a little bit of income managment and skill editing of the different classes by crafting and/or buying items.The crafting menu is not complex and not too simple - you get new equipment to buy/craft every "season"(which can be compared to chapters) which require rare materials you can find during an episode(level) or craft/recycle out of lower grade materials.The gameplay itself can be compared to other RBS - you move your characters a given number of tiles per turn and attack - or use a weapon - or use a skill - or prepare for 'Teamwork' to unleash the super epic ultra finishing move penta deluxe!!!While gameplay is kept simple the game gives you a number of goals you have to achieve (like: Kill [...] in 2 turns.) in order to gather more audience and get more money and fans for that episode(level) which get harder just like the enemies.While the enemies are sort of clone troopers its not getting boring since you will encounter a new enemytype or boss almost every level.The graphics themselves are outstanding (my bar for this one is not set too high) - the looks of the actors are changing with the equipment they are wearing and animations are smooth and flawless. You can see every minute that went into the creation of every art asset in this game.I'm not quite through with the game but as far as I played I would say that since I saw it on gamescom 2014 it lived up to all my hopes I put in it and didn't waste any of its possible potential. I absolutely fell in love with this game. (Thanks for being with MEGA-BOOTH at gamescom to the devs at this point)Buy this game if you want a fun ride with awesome ideas/design and changing gameplay.-RaptorTwitch

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
Product received for free
Basic InformationTitle:  Chroma SquadDevelopers:  Behold StudiosPublisher:  Behold StudiosGenre:  SRPG/Economic hybridGeneral ImpressionPerhaps I’m just nostalgic about those simple and happy times I used to watch the Power Rangers on TV as kid. For me, Chroma Squad really shed a new light on what a modern pixelated video game can achieve. The title I’m reviewing today is a far cry from your run-of-the-mill 2D Simulation Role Playing Game (SRPG, for short) since it incorporates a well planned economic component to it. You have to supervise  a team of stunt actors looking to promote their own studio and projects. And that is no easy task, given how cutthroat the show business is in general terms. You control everything from the production of the shows and even the advertising and human resources department of your firm. It’s not just a faux Power Ranger simulator in which combat takes center stage. You need to carefully manage your total funds and some compromises shall be made when hiring actors or sacking older ones which contrary to their skill sets, lack any appeal towards the audience. And you will certainly have to entertain your public. That is where the core tactical side of the game, comes alive. You have a surprisingly complex turn-based battle system that relies on literal teamwork between the squadmates you control, since boss fights are never easy. This really is a rare case of a title that can be used to demonstrate independent creativeness and show the gaming industry that you don’t require an overinflated budget in order to create a fun and captivating game.Strong Points+ Beautiful pixel graphics and equally pleasant soundtrack.+ Clever use of pop culture references and humor.+ Unique type of gameplay.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.Weak Points- Some elements get repetitive over time.Rating 9/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I backed this game on Kickstarter, and it's better than I ever could have hoped for. This game, at its core, is a tokusatsu simulator. What is tokusatsu? It's a style of Japanese live action television featuring transforming super heroes, martial arts, and special effects and stunts.Let me first say this: don't let the "Inspired by Saban's Power Rangers" throw you or discourage you from buying it. The designers were forced to put that under threat of legal action from Saban, and there are a few subtle digs at Saban throughout the game. Tokusatsu heroes are much bigger than just what came to the West as Power Rangers. In actuality, many countries including Brazil and France got Japanese tokusatsu super heroes in the eighties and nineties before Power Rangers was a "thing", and that is inspired by the full range of Japanese superhero shows. Fans of tokusatsu heroes will spot references not only to classic Super Sentai, but also to Kamen Rider and Metal Hero shows such as Space Sheriff Gavan and Juspion.There are two main portions to the game: tactical combat and studio management. In the tactical combat portion, you battle "mook" enemies and a "monster of the week" in a format almost identical to Final Fantasy Tactics or Disgaea in an isometric perspective. There are always "objectives" for each episode given by your show director such as performing a certain number of stunts or defeating the enemy in a certain way. Doing so will boost your ratings and improve the show's income.In the studio management portion, you purchase and set up upgrades for your humble studio, investing in better cameras, hiring big name actors and skilled crew, and upgrading your special effects and costumes. While your costumed heroes may start out with a mop bucket on their head and bicycle pads for armor, with enough positive fan reaction (which you'll see after each episode is filmed via a sampling of tweets about the episode) you might eventually be wearing costumes on the level of a professional production! Additionally, interactions with other companies and fans might affect your production. What will you do when other studios start coming to you with their hands out? Take them to court or give them a cut? What will you do when overseas fansubbers start subbing your show? Let them on the chance it'll increase your merchandising, or drop the hammer on them?In addition to this, you have a great deal of customization of your show itself. You can name your studio, name your super hero team, and even customize what they say when they transform or do their super attack. Want them to shout out, "Henshin!" when they transform instead of the default? You can do it! Want to pick your own colors instead of the default? You can do it! Want to have an Orange Ranger instead of a Yellow Ranger? Want them ALL to be red heroes? Yes, you can even do that!This game follows the standard Sentai story elements: heroes battle foot soldier "mooks" on foot in their civilian clothes until they build up enough power (audience approval!) to transform -- and when they do, it boosts your audience approval even more. Once you defeat the monster of the week, of course, as any fan of the shows know, the monster has to grow huge. And what would Sentai be without giant robot battles? Purchase gear and equipment, assemble your giant robot and have a battle on a massive scale. In addition, there is a motorcycle prop you'll receive later, and an option to shift the show into a "solo mode" featuring a lone motorcycle Rider hero with a flowing scarf that favors jump kicks as his preferred method of defeating monsters. So in case you are curious -- yes, you CAN be a Kamen Rider!The graphics are 8-bit, but don't let that discourage you. The animations are great, the characters are big and bright with big cutscenes when important events happen. The music is catchy and reminiscent of classic Commodore chiptunes or Nintendo 8-bit sounds with a catchier sound.Overall, I highly recommend this game. If you're a tokusatsu fan, you definitely will want to play this, but even if you just have a passing interest in superheroes, tactical battle games, or managing a TV studio, the charm and uniqueness of this game will certainly entertain you.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Back when the Power Rangers were a big deal in 1995, my parents wouldn't let me watch it. They deemed it too violent. Mind you, they're telling this to a guy who is chronically addicted to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and tuned in every Saturday to watch the Spiderman and Batman cartoons. Power Rangers were much too violent though. When my folks finally gave up on controlling my viewing habits Power Rangers quickly became a guilty pleasure and I watched it until Wild Force. Enter Chroma Squad, a retro style turn based tactics game that puts you in control of a squad of power rangers. It is every bit as fun as going round your parents' back to just watch cardboard robots beating up rubber monsters.Chroma Squad's premise is very catchy hook to begin with. A group of disgruntled stunt actors are fed up with their boss and quit their current Ranger season to start their own series. With buckets, old shirts and cardboard boxes your crew assembles a set of costumes and backdrops and the battle against evil can begin. Along the way you'll find that there is a little more to playing Power Rangers than just making cool poses.The game's real kicker is the ability to create and assemble your own team. You can possibly recreate every Ranger team down to the letter with the game, or engineer a squad entirely your own. Did you like Mighty Morphing Power Rangers? Just pick the five colours, three boys, two girls and be on your way. Fed up with the patriarchy? Pick five girls, colour them all in shades of purple and kick some♥♥♥♥♥ Feeling grimdark and edgy? Pick five depressed kids, paint them black and act like Batman. Everything is up to you. Each Ranger has its own role. Lead is in charge and gets additional hitpoints, while the tech rangers does bonus damage with weapons. The colours are up to you, so you can make the Pink ranger be the boss this time round and let the snooty Red ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ be the butt of the Megazord this time. After you tune your squad you record your episodes. This is a turn based tactics game where you fight minions and monsters on a grid. The real selling point here is positioning and teamwork. One ranger can kick a mook for sure, but positioning your squad in such a way will allow you to vault your rangers straight into the bosses face on the first turn to deliver a juicy team attack. It is key that master the acrobatics and abilities to chase down the shifty bosses, or that you weaken and wear out the brawlers without losing a Ranger, because no one likes it when the good guys lose.You performance isn't measured in money, or experience; it is measured in audience. Since you're recording a TV show your audience is your life; and you cannot survive without loyal viewers and fans. Every episode gives you a hand full of objectives to clear to make your episode a bit better. More audience, means more fans, means more money, means better suits, means better TV, means more audience, etc. It is a simple, yet fun system, because it invites you to think of other ways to approach a problem, rather than to look for the one tactic. The entire game is booming with references to the Power Rangers and its Japanese original: Super Sentai. Finishing moves, focus on Red, giant robots, believing in your friends, mystery helpers, talking jars, it's all part of the experience. During your downtime you have time to craft new weapons from arts and crafts materials as well as answer fanmail and hire marketing groups to propel your show to the next level of hype. You'll quickly fall in love with the familiar and sometimes cliché traits of the series that round out the experience.All in all, the game presses so many right buttons, it's hard not to like. Though the sometimes lazy writing rips you out of the game, the desire to know what kind of crazy thing the devs have cooked up for the next episode will have you coming back soon. The branching storyline also helps to draw you back in after beating it once. Chroma Squad is a precious gem that should be play by anyone who ever watched even a single episode of Power Rangers.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
Developer: Behold StudiosPublisher: Behold StudiosFormat: PCRelease Date: April 30th, 2015Oh boy here it is Chroma Squad. A game like no other out there.Let me start of by saying that this is a game for children.Nothing for adults like me and you. We are big now. We can buy alcohol, drive and get on all roller coasters.I mean I pretty much watched Power Rangers and the likes whenever I could, because well I have had smaller siblings so I had an excuse ... err I mean I was forced to watch it.Anyway you don't have to be a fan of Tokusatsu and Sentai to fully enjoy this game. I mean it doesn't hurt if you are it probably makes everything just so much better but all you need to fully enjoy it is a sense of humor.Now on to the review. Retsu go!Chroma Squad is a Tactical-Management-Business-RPP about running your very own sentai show.You slip into the role of five stuntmen which basically got fed up that they do pretty much all the work while the actors are just sitting in their chairs most of the time. One comes up with the idea to create their own studio and so they quit their jobs to set up their own sentai studio.This game is filled with jokes and references to the tv shows or to memes and it's overall a very good laugh.Now we get to the management/business part.You now have to setup your studio and buy props like mics, lamps or a better green screen. Those items will give you all special bonuses but also come for a price. You don't only have to pay once for those items well for some you do and others cost something like 25 bucks each episode. So you have to choose wisely on what to upgrade. Also you have to hire actors, choose an agency to help you reach a greater audience and make sure you're fans are happy since hey this is tv show!Onto the RPG part! Retsu go!In case it wasn't obvious but you take the role of five actors and the director of your sentai tv show. You have to read and reply to fan mail which can grant you bonuses depending on your actions and then there's crafting.Duct tape, play dough, card boxes and many more stuff you'll need to craft your new items like swords, guns, helmets and so on. You can buy several materials and you can also recycle your old and unused gear for materials. You only have a % chance to get certain materials but hey atleast you have the chance to get some materials back.Your goal is to record five episodes for a season. Meaning you have to record and fight five different scenarios before you reach the season finale aka end boss battle. While recording the shows you see the directors instructions on screen which you should follow in order to get the max amount of audience.What else can I say?If you enjoy tactical and/or rpg games you should definitely give Chroma Squad a try.If you like the good ol' Mighty Morphin' Power Ranger you will probably drool all over this game.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Excellent tactical RPG with a surprising amount of depth.It's a bit of a business management sim on top of the RPG side, but they mesh very well together.The game play works well, with plenty of options in combat to choose how you want to approach things, and a wealth of customization in the pre episode/fight setup.A silly and offbeat story line with enough genuine comedy to make you laugh occasionally helps to spruce up the quality game play as well.It starts off simple, so it's not difficult to learn but gets progressively deeper, and I can tell there is more to come. I'm genuinely looking forward to each new "episode" of the TV show you play in.Difficulty wise, I'm playing on hard and it's just right for me. Hard enough I have to pay attention to what I'm doing and think out my actions, and most episodes I'm barely scraping through. Can't comment on how that would fit for others of course, but as someone pretty accustomed to this style of game hard difficulty has works nicely for me.I'm not finished the game so I can't comment on length, but I'm a long ways from finishing and have put in about 11hrs on this save so far. So I'm confident there is a surprisingly large amount of content to play through.I've heard tons of love given to the sound track for the game but... honestly I don't see it. It's not bad by any means but it's more decent and fits the game well, then anything truly memorable.The visuals I really appreciate however, it's simple retro pixel graphics but the combat animations, movement, and even the special attacks are all very well animated and look quite nice. Lots of extra frills like a fast forward effect reminiscent of an old VCR on a CRT TV fit perfectly with the atmosphere.I can happily recommend this to anyone who wants a lighthearted RPG, or just looking for something unique and different. Not much else out there like this.9/10 and a genuinely excellent game. Easy recommendation.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Summary:Chroma Squad is a turn-based action RPG game that revolves around a group of Power Rangers stunt actors, who are acting Power Rangers. They are unhappy with their director and with the studio where they are taking the show, so they make their own, Chroma Squad! The story might have few surprises for you but the main thing are the references and jokes, you'll find many of those.Gameplay is classic for turn-based action games, with exception of acrobatics - a character can hold a position so another character can ricochet himself farther (closer to your target enemy). You can expect about 30 levels (split into 5 "seasons"), with repeating basic enemies but original bosses, which will make you laugh and, some later ones, might make you a little angry. You have to try hard.But I don't want to scare you, I've played on "Interesting" difficulty (take it as normal) and I think it was perfectly balanced experience. I had times where I've almost didn't beat the level (last man Power Ranger standing!) and I've never felt the game was too easy, so I always felt motivated to do my best.Anyway, Chroma Squad would totally suck if they weren't able to form into a huge mech. And guess what, you will have a mech action too! But don't get too excited for that, mech fights have completely different fight rules, there is no positioning strategy and your attacks are based on your luck.Visuals are presented in neat pixelart style, combined with nice sound effect and soundtrack, which contains even a Japanese theme song! Everything gets you to the right mood pretty fast, so you can enjoy everything developers made - and there's a lot of content to see.Chroma Squad is definitely worth recommending, I've enjoyed it for more than 10 hours and might even try to play it later again on higher difficulty for another endings. If you are looking for  turn-based RPG, pixelart and want many pop culture references, you'll love it!Pros:- Extensive system of skills, upgrades, items and crafting. You'll spend minutes in management windows between fights and you won't mind it at all! - Well-made turn RPG and strategy gameplay. - Funny dialogues that perfectly fits into the silly story of stuntmen running a TV show, that changes their lives.- Specific unique tasks for every single battle. So if you think it's too easy, try to do something more and complete them - you'll be more popular, if you can do it.- Fair pixelart graphics.- Doesn't get repetitive. There are many mobs that are getting reused pretty often but you can (on most levels) expect a new and original boss with his unique skills. Also, every season, each of your characters get a new skill!- More difficulties, more endings.- Good sound effects and soundtrack.- Steam achievements.Cons:- Kaiju fights. They are too much based on luck, you just see your % chance to hit your enemy... and hope you'll hit it.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Go go Chroma Squad!Now that the game is finally done with its Final Wave of beta-testing, the Super Marvelous Super Sentai inspired RPG is in everyone's hands, and it was well worth the wait.Only vaguely similar in structure to the also wonderful Knights of Pen & Paper (also developered by Behold Studios), the pixelated adventure takes your through the many misadventured of your own custom made team of  Sentai / Power Rangers inspired actors who have abandoned their previous, terrible acting gig to create their own series.The director? You, of course!The game is rife with fan service, and if you have any love for the original Sentai series or the Americanised Power Rangers interpretation of the show, you will feel right at home with this game. A great amount of customistation and developement is under your control, from the genders and colours of your team to the overall look of your costumes.The main game is a RPG treat, bringing you through numerous seasons and many episodes of your own hilariously awkward show. No trope is left untouched as you battle and "chromatze" your way through hoards of enemy lackies and boss monsters in the well designed turned based RPG gameplay. Though the pixel art may not be to everyone's taste, the humour behind the game's inspiration shines through beautifully.This is a highly recommended game, and one I encourage every Sentai / Power Rangers to check out. If nothing else, its a better Power Rangers game than any official branded has ever been.P.S. I make absolutely no apologies for the puns used in this review.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												TLDR: This is an amazing game, but it hinges on one (or two) factors. This is an amazing game IF: You like Power Rangers or Super Sentai. This is the main reason I'm "Not Recommending".  I will still play for another 50 hours or so, but I'm a Rangers and Sentai fan. 9/10 - Power Rangers/Sentai fans6/10 - Normal RPG, tactical fansChroma Squad has some mis-leading aspects, mainly that this is a simple tactical game, and not so much of a Manager/Studio Simulation, and it lacks any deep RPG elements. PROS:-Best Power Rangers game yet! No joke, easily the best. If you like Power Rangers at all- BUY THIS NOW! You will not be very disapointed.-Blend of tactical, rpg, and simulation aspects-Can customize team's colors, equipment, weapons-Crafting is available-Can upgrade the studio-Great retro music and art (some people hate that, I like it)-You do not gain levels. This is under pros and cons because to some this takes away from how much of an RPG it is. To others, this means no 'grinding'-Great GUI/UI. It looks very nice, and it's easy to use.-Contracts with different agencies. This is a really nice touch. I like this a lot. CONS:-The simulation/managing aspect is sort-of fake. You don't really become a fliming studio in the sense you get to create your own episodes. Nor does changing the 'actor' for your Rangers change their personality (a black guy with a mohawk has the same personality as an alien, who also has the same personality as a living beaver-man).  You DO get to choose the order of episodes, but this will only change the ending of the game (as of right now, when I write this). -Virtually NOTHING you do has an effect on how the story/studio/managing/episodes etc. Some things effect how many fans you get, and it will change these end-of-episode fake tweets (Twitter) "Wow!  You ended with a finishing move! That was awesome" or "Lame, you need to change your gear! #OldGearIsLame". This is a nice touch at first, but it becomes annoying. Especially when 'fans' want you to change your gear every episode, when there isn't any new gear avaiable.-Tactical elements are light: I did not feel I had to ever strategize to complete a level. -RPG elements are light: Very few RPG-like choices. When you beat a season, you get new 'Season Abilities', ultimately only allowing for 5 different abilities/powers/moves per 'Hero'/Ranger -Studio Management aspect is very light: Right now it only improves your heroes, and or Mecha. It can also give you more fans/money.-Mecha Battle: This is nothing more than a simple time-reaction game. It does not feel engaging, and also Mecha battles do not happen after every fight. So when it /does/ happen, it feels anti-climatic because of how shallow the fights are. -Crafting can be fun, but it also feels shallow. Instead of choosing the gear you like (like a damage suit vs a HP suit vs a magic suit etc) you just get scaling gear. So you end up re-crafting your old gear just so you can get the newest set. -Due to crafting the items in the 'Shop' are either much worse or much better in comparison. (Level 3 shirt from shop: 120 HP, Level 3 shirt crafted: 87 HP and +1 random property (likely of equal strength)-The story... If you buy this game for the story PREPARE to be disapointed. It's fully of tongue-in-cheek (aka humorous, funny, comical etc) elements. I am not a huge fan of this. The writing isn't very solid (Sorry Gui) and I never find myself wanting to know what happens next-There isn't a lot of gear/items/equipment etc. Half way through the game: 14 'equipment' pieces to craft, 17 to buy. Weapons: 14 to buy, 12 to craft. Remember, these only affect some visual looks and your stats. Weapons give you a new attack (which is nifty) but ultimately it's going to be a variation on the same thing (axe doing more damage than sword)-(Currently) no NewGame+-There are even fewer studio improvements to buy, making the studio/managing aspect even weaker. (I'm half way through the game and I have 10 available to buy) -Buying the "bigger studio' doesn't actually change anything for the episodes. Nothing at all. (It provides stats, but does not change the episodes themselves) At least in Game Dev Tycoon the visuals changed to a larger studio and gave more options to do things. That is not the case here.-You do not gain levels. This is under pros and cons because to some this takes away from how much of an RPG it is. To others, this means no 'grinding'Knowing all of this: I will still end up playing quite a bit. And I don't mind posting this, knowing a lot of fan-bois will dislike my review. I still find the game to be fun, but very misleading. You don't really manage very much. (Unless equiping & crafting gear in any other RPG counts as simulation/managing aspect :P ) The studio improvements don't change much. The gear changes your looks and stats (like most games) but there isn't much choice, so everyone at a certain point will be wearing either A) Gear that was Crafted or B) Gear that was bought. You aren't going to use an old gear-set that has worse stats, and there isn't a choice between visuals (you get what you get, right now)

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												Chroma Squad is a tactical role-playing game, released for personal computers in early goings of 2015. It was heavily influenced by various Tokusatsu series, two of the chief inspirations being Saban's Power Rangers and Shotaro Ishinomori's Kamen Rider.Go Go Power Rangers!Five professional stuntmen who've grown tired of the poor production values and tyranical director of their current television series decide to uproot and take their talent elsewhere. Soon after impulsively deciding to leave, the group begins developing an original Sentai series, and must work through a myriad of problems to ensure that the series is successful.Out of the frying pan, in to the casting department.Before the game rears into action, the player is given several options to tailor their experience: A choice between three difficulty settings, helping to accommodate players of all skill levels; selecting your squad and studio names, colors and transformation shout; and finally, designating the actors to the roles that you see fit.Each of those actors have unique bonuses, which help to determine how they'll influence the team for the better. Several of these bonuses are especially beneficial with a particular role, e.g.; Skill Regen for an Assist character to improve the rate at which they can heal the rest of the group. Some actors go so as far as to impose combat penalties on themselves, so that they can provide a heavy boost in another area.Branching paths are another feature that help to provide some elements of customization. The studio will occasionally receive an email with several options for replies. While most of these only lead to an audience bonus, others can provide weaponry that otherwise wouldn't be available. The largest branch in the game is accessed during one particular battle: depending on how one chooses to complete an objective, the game determines how the second half of the journey will play out. All of these add a great degree of value to subsequent plays.It's Morphin' Time!​The foundation that the game is built upon is squad based combat, which plays out on a turn-by-turn basis in which the rangers move around on an isometric grid. The team use their varied skill sets to turn the tide of battle, in whatever way they can. Be they used for healing, or rapidly bursting down the health of nearby enemies, each member is prepared to put up a fight, whether they're alone, or working together. Should they choose the latter, teamwork is used as a mechanic that allow them to launch one another to distant locations, as well as attacking enemies as a group for higher damage. Still, sometimes even a team of powerful heroes need a little more help to defeat a daunting foe.Megazord, Eat Your Heart Out​!At times like these, our heroes call upon their Mecha to participate in Kaiju battles; essentially, giant robots fighting giant monsters. These also play out turn-by-turn, but here the objective is to create combos with your abilities, all the while paying close attention to a percentage representing you're likelihood of hitting the target. The significance of this is that combo-chains determine your damage multiplier, and missing an enemy breaks this chain, resets it to 0, and proceeds to the the next turn. While these sections aren't especially interesting on their own, they do add enough variety to keep the core gameplay relatively fresh.A Heartfelt Tribute​Personally, I've never been particularly compatible with isometric tactics, as they tend to be very slow paced, without providing something that makes it feel necessary. That said, I found Chroma Squad to be a game that meaningfully improves the pace of the genre. Perhaps the kindest thing I can say about it in that regard is, while the gameplay is familiar, the time you spend in battle doesn't feel like it massively exceeds the amount of time allocated to plot and cutscenes, as it does in many tactical titles.As a longtime enthusiast of the source material, Chroma Squad had an easy time getting through to me, as it shows an incredible amount of reverence for the style, and does a wonderful job of presenting it in a unique way. Going beyond that incredibly initial premise, there's an incredible amount of charm to be found here. From the moment you launch the game, the main theme mimics the vocal styling of many classic Tokusatsu themes, and perfectly sets the tone for the adventure. Something as simple as skipping through cutscenes is done as though someone was fast forwarding through a VHS tape, showing an immense amount of character for something that otherwise wouldn't be noteworthy in the slightest. Here we have an incredibly quirky game that makes for a very engaging experience and is absolutely worth the price of admission.Time Spent: 132 Hours (Average game length: 15 hours.)Further Playing: Fire Emblem: Awakening (3DS), XCOM: Enemy Within (Windows, OS X, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
What I liked: The combat, yet simple has some depth The music and the charming yet cheesy story The whole TV management gameplay aspectWhat You Need to Know: Yes it's similar to Power Rangers, but this game is good on its own not for being nostalgic (I’m didn’t watch the shows as a kid) The combat is turned based, luckily the animations are fast and you’re not bogged down waiting for the enemies turn even when a dozen are present. Each ranger is a class with special abilities that grow in number with each season.The game is based on a TV of these fake rangers, but the story gets weirder as what’s real and fake blur the line. Each episode you play has optional objectives that when completed give you lots of fans(this is your way of making more money and getting better marketing perks). The first 3 seasons these were important to get as many as possible. But still missing some of them is ok and still not be crippled later on, plus a lot of them are easy. But some bosses spawn mines or spores by the dozens each turn which I did not like. But that was only 2 out of the 30+ bosses you fight. The game has a funny/corny story; I never skipped over it because it was entertaining enough to me. If you don’t like it you can skip it all very easily. There is no voice acting, so you will read the dialogue. It even has choices you make by email which will give you either in game rewards, like money, fans, materials or weapons or just the satisfaction of responding to a fan or person in need. Some even choose what bosses you fight so you won’t fight all the game’s bosses in one play through.The game even has 3 different endings where the last season of the game changes depending on your choice; you have different rangers you can pick at the start of the game (which you can name) along with the email choices above give a good replay value.Now the TV show management side is very easy and isn’t hard to understand. You have marketing team which you can pick from a lot with new ones each season offering different benefits, like more money, fans damage, item drop and more depending on who you pick. You have crafting which is cool, offering more variety of armor and weapons that the shop doesn’t have. The shop and items you craft are both viable with neither being the obvious op choice. Next are the mech battles, you customize your mech by the 5 parts of the body (head, torso, 2 arms and legs). These you craft and once start leveling up your parts to high tier it’s going to be hard to get the materials to swap if you want to. Now the battles themselves are simple, your main attack with every hit you gain a combo but lose in accuracy, so there is some luck involved there. You get abilities depending on the parts you picked for your mech. Overall these battles are short, flashy and fun to mix up the fightsI played the game on the middle difficulty and failed about 3 episodes (there is a penalty for doing this). So it’s not that hard. Playing on the easy mode would be a cake walk if you’re worried about how difficult the game is. The game even though it’s simple does require planning and synergizing your team’s abilities and timing when played on the higher difficultiesMy Score:A+Paid:Included in $1 Humble BundleCompleted in:14 hoursGames similar:  XCOM FTL Battle Brothers

number of helpful: 19 of 24 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
Go, go, Chroma Squad!Chroma Squad is Power Rangers plus Disgaea. If you like one or both of those, I am 99% sure you will like this. If you do not know of either, then that is what the rest of this review is for!I confess, I never watched Power Rangers or any sentai shows as a kid. But I do know the tropes quite well and have heard more than enough about them to get the gist. Chroma Squad is a love letter to those shows, and you should expect them to follow those standard formulas. I found it to be an absolute blast, especially as an SRPG lover. Take a look below to see all the reasons why.Pros:While I like SRPGs in general, this one hooked me and wouldn't let go. The gameplay is addicting. Every episode has different objectives and maps, and it is a lot of fun to figure out how to best impress your audience while winning the fight. It keeps the core gameplay strong while adding enough variables to make the on-foot fights fresh.There is a crafting system that  works well. You can make some nifty equipment with materials that randomly drop. Sometimes the shop equipment will be better, and you always receive gold after each level. So even if you bomb during a crafting session, you have good resources to fall back on.Grinding does not exist. There is no experience present, and the only thing you can earn from each level is randomly dropped items, which cap off at eight per level. I approve of the levels all being scaled by equipment per season, rather than by level. You can even mix up the order you play groups of episodes in!You have a lot of freedom with your characters. You can select different designs for the squad of five, name them, choose their skills, equip them accordingly, and make some great set-ups while utilizing a "role" structure. As a bonus, you get to name your studio, catch phrase, and robot, among other things.The story starts off a bit standard, but it evolves into a fun plot. The build-up is excellently done, and the development your characters get helps a lot. I grew very fond of my squad and was sad to finish their story, though happy with how it ended.There are three endings, and while I have only gotten one of them, I get the feeling they are each very different. Along with this, some choices come up throughout the plot that have an impact on the battles and story overall. It is great to have a reason to replay it beyond simply wanting to play it.Very good graphics all around! The characters look distinctive and have well-done designs, the giant robot and enemies look hardcore, and the TV screen openings/endings/loading screens are nice touches. It is a colorful game that is pleasing to the eye.The music is fan-ta-stic! The opening theme alone made me go, "Oh heck yes," and the rest of the game kept that quality. You can buy the soundtrack for $3.99, which is more than worth it. I know I'll pick it up when I have some more funds to spare.Of course you get a giant robot to fight in. Why wouldn't you? I like the way it works overall. Defending requires precise timing with your clicks, which is of a fair difficutly. But trying to hit the kaijus multiple times is problematic. I missed far more 70% opportunities than I hit with. Bad luck? Most likely, but it can be frustrating. I still call the robot fights a plus due to their epic feel and most of their mechanics, yet unlike the on-foot fights, there is not a whole lot of variation. The developers mentioned they want to strengthen this part of the game, which would be great.Speaking of the developers, they are very friendly people who take fan comments and suggestions into account. They are constantly striving to improve Chroma Squad. Having people like them as the creators of this game makes me think it will become even better. That is incredible to consider, given that they already have produced an amazing piece right here. Their tribute to sentai shows is masterfully executed, and I love their dedication to that.There are 43 achievements that you can get, and most of them are not too difficult. As a bonus, if you beat the game on a higher difficulty level, you get achievements for that level and all of the ones below it. I wish more games would do this instead of insisting you play on easy mode after beating hard mode, all for the sake of an achievement.Okay, look. You control a group of people in colorful suits fighting evil cupcakes, lawyers, irons, badgers, and television sets with martial arts, wacky weapons, and a giant robot made out of cardboard boxes. What else do I need to say to get you to buy this?Neutral:The analog stick movement with the PS3 controller seems a bit floaty. I am not sure how it is for other types of controllers. Using the mouse keeps the movements sharp. Thankfully, this is not a game that requires quick analog movements, so it is not a big deal.Speaking of controllers, you can't use the controller for the kaiju fights. Again, not a big deal, especially since there are not many commands used in them. It is somewhat bothersome to have to set the controller aside, but the store page does say it is only partial controller support. My PS3 controller actually worked in every other situation (besides typing out the names for my heroes/studio,) so that was a pleasant surprise given that I wasn't sure how well it would respond.There is no New Game+. Some games are not suited for New Game+, but this one begs for it. The good news is that the developers have acknowledged the lack of a New Game+ and are trying to implement it. I would be very happy with that addition!What this game does have are multiple save files. I like this feature. The problem is that there is nowhere in the game that makes it obvious this is possible. I thought I would be erasing an old file when I started a new one, and only then learned it keeps multiple files.This game does have trading cards. They look nice and are a good addition for collectors.Cons:If you have more than a certain amount of weapons or armor in your inventory, you can only see a handful to equip. You can't scroll through them to get an older item if you want it. Since I like to have one copy of each item in most of my games, this drove me bonkers. You can still recycle the old items, you just can't get to them on the equip screen. Ugh!When using the keyboard controls, the mouse pointer shows over the game pointer. I don't know if there is a way to disable that. If there is, I couldn't find it. That is the main reason I used a controller, as when you are using the analog sticks instead, the mouse pointer vanishes.There are some spelling and grammar errors scattered throughout the game. Most of them are not that noticeable, and they do not interfere with the story, but they are worth mentioning. The oddest one I saw was weapons that you craft saying "any role" can use them, when in truth some are limited to certain roles.Overall experience:I was excited to play this game, and it surpassed even those expectations. It satisfied me not only as an SRPG, but as a stand-out tribute to a great genre. It is charming, fun, and has fantastic spirit. I've beaten it once, but I plan to play it at least two more times. It's too good not to!Rating:9/10. I was leaning toward 9.5/10, but there's a few issues that drag it down a little too much for me to give that precious half of a point. That being said? This game is awesome and playing it will make you feel more awesome as well. Join in on the sentai love and pick up Chroma Squad now!Looking for more great indie games? Check out my other reviews on Indie Games Treasure Trove!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												It's a bit meta, lots of weird, and a huge amount of fun.Even as a concept, Chroma Squad is unique: You are stunt actors who decide to leave their job on power rangers to start their own better written power rangers. That means winning the battles are only half the fight: You have to win them with style, lest the audience decide your fights are too boring. While some of the directors goals are tricky, they do add to the challenge, and it force you to learn the tricks of the game quickly. You'll soon enjoy tossing actors across the map and pummeling minions as a team for fun and profit.Outside of combat, it's all about the show. You and your mech will need upgrades that not only give you the usual benefits of gear, but also make you look better. Get a bigger studio! SD Cameras! Flood lights! The better it looks, the move people will watch, and the better your options and cash flow will be.And this works together, resulting in a good casual strategy game that I can't wait to play more of.

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Talk about a hidden gem!I wasn't sure of what exactly I was expecting when I purchased Chroma Squad, but I liked the combination of tactical RPG and Power Rangers references enough that I had to give it a shot.  I was impressed right out of the gate as the game incorporates several different genres very well and even adds several new elements that I have not seen before.The tactical combat of the game is very enjoyable and there is much more to it than I had initially assumed.  Each episode begins with your heroes arriving on the scene and battling their enemies in their plain clothes.  While in this form you don't have access to your equipment and abilities, though you are formidable enough to go toe-to-toe with the villains all the same.  Once you transform, however, you get your costume and the previously stated abilities unlocked and you can really do some impressive things.  The aspect of combat that really caught my attention and made this game stand out, though, is that your goal is to make every fight as cinematic as possible.  For example, every battle has two Director's Objectives that give a massive boost to the points you earn for putting on an exciting fight, your Audience.  You also gain audience for performing special skills, defeating enemies, using teamwork to give a teammate a boost (the boosted character performs an acrobatic maneuver to move additional spaces that turn), and most of all for performing unified 'team attacks' where you set your squad up in such a manner that they all focus on and attack the targeted enemy at once,The music is enjoyable, the battles challenging and fun.  Did I mention that you get to customize the look of your gear, colors of your outfits, specializations of your stats and skills, and actors who you use for your squad?  Oh right, and you get to customize and do battle with your own mech!I can not put into words how highly I recommend this game.  Truly a hidden gem and one of the best games I've come across in awhile.
