content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												I friend gifted me this game so I just wanted to shout out a big thanks to him!This game... is awesome. I love the concept. Created by Behold Studios, Chroma Squad is essentially a Power Rangers management sim. You get to make your own squad and customize your team to fit your desires of having one of the best or lamest Sentai teams ever!The story is that a bunch of stuntmen quit their old job because they believe their director lacks creativity and want more creative freedom. The plot really goes off the rails later on but it's fun to watch. The dialogue of your team is super corny but I loved it however if that's not your thing then it might be something to consider if you're planning on getting Chroma Squad. The dialogue is filled with puns, references and enough fourth wall jokes to make Deadpool blush.Visually it looks nice, it's some nice pixel graphics. I don't think they use it as a lazy excuse since it's nice good to look at and there is detail in the game. Not the heaviest but enough to distinguish everything easily. The music is personally one of the best parts of the game. This is some really good chiptune music, it has some great soundtracks that get you pumped up for a boss battle and my personal favourite "This is Cerebro" is so campy and so catchy. The gameplay itself, when fighting is a tactical RPG. A pretty fun one, the game has an emphasis on team attacks which is pretty cool and works with the theme. You got abilities and cool weapons for the different classes to play around with and a cool chunk of bosses. You also get finishing moves for them which is pretty sweet as well. One thing that does bother me a bit is that a lot of the time the game can be too easy but then there is a huge difficulty spike in the last level. What is that all about?When not in normal combat you're doing one of two things. The first is managing your studio, it's fun as you have to upgrade the studio, buy or craft new gear, hire agencies to promote your show, check emails and all that managment sim stuff. The other is the mech combat. It wouldn't be Power Rangers without a giant mech battle in almost every episode. It can be fun but really it just comes down to chance whether attack or block attacks. It looks cool but it's pretty shallow.To conclude my mad ramblings I of course like this game a lot! It's one of those games I wished I played earlier when it came out last year. If you understand the basic core material you'll have a lot of fun with it.  If you've never heard of Power Rangers AT ALL or know exactly ziltch about it then I wouldn't reccommend this to you. Otherwise you should definitely get it! It's a game that's about having fun rather than being amazingly unique or difficult (for the most part). I give this an 8.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Chroma Squad... what a unusual concept.I grew up watching oldschool japanese films (Godzilla, Ultraman, Rodan, etc), watching shows like Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, oldschool martial arts films that were dubbed by... less than stellar actors, etc.So lets just say I love the source material and whatnot.Final Fantasy Tactics style games (Tactical RPGs) are always sorta hit or miss.  Some focus too much on choice leaving you with a mountain of options and a hard time deciding what actually works for you.  Others are far too focused on the story and ignore a good tactical format for combat.Chroma Squad hits alot of good notes:-5 classes, all with tie-ins with character archtypes in shows like MMPR-"Actors" that give different stat boosts to the class you slot them into, or to your progress as a whole, depending on choice.-Solid combat that feels good, without a mountain of stats and rules to learn-Various mini-goals for each 'mission' (part of an eppisode) that are typically not too hard to complete and net you more money to spend on upgrades-MMO style gear levels (White/Green/Blue/Purple) that help you determine which gear is better (not to mention easy to understand stats)-Alot of comedy moments before/during/and after each fight.  There are more references to pop culture, source material, and strange happenings than I can even begin to list.-Great badguys, even when they are repetative it's still funny to see the dialog that tries to explain why they are there.Now some negatives-Crafting system can turn out garbage gear.  You can break said gear down and try again, but it's a losing system.-Some of the 'mini-missions' don't work with everyones playstyle, there have been a few so far that I found irritating to try to complete.-Sometimes the 'jump' feature doesn't seem to want to fire for no reason.  This makes positioning annoying at times.-Music gets repetative, but not really a big issue, mute works wonders.I love me a good tactical game, and one filled with humor and references to some of the best (and cheesiest if I'm honest) shows/movies is awesome in my book.  Too bad there isn't multiplayer co-op or pvp, that would send this game to the realm of 'zomg best timewaster ever... for a week or three'

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Chroma Squad is, as it says, a tactical RPG that was inspired by the many Sentai series such as Power Rangers, Kamen Rider and many, many more. What is the story, you ask? Well, essentially, the story of the game goes like this: You have a bunch of stunt people who recently quit their jobs because of a director who was, shall we say, demanding and is overall being a complete♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and they all decide to start a studio of their own! From the beginning, they don't have much to work with, using cardboard, duct tape, and third-rate costumes to get by, eventually, they start having an audience to work with.The gameplay is quite fun, you kit out your actors in the best gear that cardboard and duct tape can buy and record new 'episodes', essentially maps, for the season, each with their own bonus objectives that don't punish you much for failing them but the extra fans and cashflow you can get from maxing out your audience each episode is a nice incentive to do them. Every actor has their own special abilities that are accessible as soon as they suit up which can be sometimes impossible to do at the start of the episode as you need to build audience power first before chromatizing. The phrases said throughout the game such as "Chromatize" and "Mecha Power, Activate!" can be modified in the studio to your liking. Yes, this means you can be as silly or as creative as you like... or creatively silly.The difficulty of the game is strange at times, some episodes are easy, others are pretty difficult, even with the best gear for the season's tier equipped, and others still are fairly difficult. You'll end up curbstomping half the time if you're playing on the normal difficulty if you know how to play tactical RPGs, well, tactically, and I'm fairly certain hard mode is pretty challenging but I can't quite say that for myself. I'm not going to say that this game is too easy but it feels too easy at times, especially when you have an assault one-shotting everything they touch that isn't a boss monster or a shielded enemy.However, despite the odd difficulty curve, I absolutely adore the presence of the game and I absolutely love the feel and the gameplay of Chroma Squad, it kind of reminds me of XCOM, in a way, with all the aliens but minus the permadeath. Oh, and the music's damn good too, I will admit that the title theme may have dug deep into my brain and has implanted its melody into my brain and it won't get out. Although, there's not really much replayability in this game apart from the acheievements and, well, I can't say all that much without spoilers.In short? Fun game, even if you're not very familiar with the subject of the game, although most references may fly over you since this is an homage game, after all. Worth a buy? Sure. It's a good game for its price although it tends to be lacking a bit in the replayability department, it's fun for what it's worth and that is what matters.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Chroma Squad is a tactical strategy game with some management aspect. It kinda resembles new XCOM games. Its main meat, the tactical strategy, part is quite fun with couple of interesting mechanics. Things like doing combined attacks with your team members and or making acrobatic throws. Management part offer quite different choices. Such as transforming your viewers into either fans or cash. It has satisfying amounts of options in character customization and in RPG elements. There five roles and you hire different actors with different bonuses for each role and each role has small skill tree in itself. You can equip your characters with crafted gear with random properties. Even the mecha fights which are not the major component of the game has some fun mechanics. It uses combo mechanic where successive hit increase your damage but reduce your hit chance so you have decide when to use your finishing move. Have not finished it yet but according to the achievements pages it even has multiple endings so some replayability.Story and design wise i feels like a true old Power Rangers TV show. It has a kinda cheesy humor and characters it was to be expected from it's Power Rangers source and i personally found them funny. This cheesyness also includes popular culture references and memes. A small detail i really liked was that you can customize the color and look of your characters costumes and you can see these changes effect the looks of the effects and mecha and small things like that. You can also customize your warcries like when you finish a boss or transform or summon your mecha.One last thing, if you do not like pixely art style that might be turn off for you.10/10, GOTY, would recommend etc.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												More or less an in depth review-Pros~This game brings you back to your childhood (or lets you experience a childhood), bringing me back to the days where I proudly watched series like Power Rangers. Not many games that want me to feel nostalgic can do it like this game, the next best thing for nostalgia would be Shovel Knight, but this takes the cake~Simple , yet extremely fun RPG mechanics. Ok lets get this down, 5 base classes, the lead, support, techie, assault, medic. Each class is equipped with each special ability of course, but then there becomes another layer, with the inclusion of different characters with each their own respective stats and weaknesses, this can dramatically effect the way you can fight a boss. An example would be, my lead, who i chose to be the Panda Guy (Forgot his name!) has reduced movement speed, because of this one of the episodes required me to kill the boss with my lead (This is also known as Director Instructions, although not required, it gives you a boost in "audience" which helps you use a few Studio options which will be explained later) My lead was way too far from the boss and there was no way to get to him before the boss dying from my techie's amazing counter-chance. Thus causing me to feel the want to restart the level and do it again to 100% it, and I did, I had to dramatically change the way I play by having the Lead always stay close to the boss while the others protect him. Now I would explain the skills to you, but they are fairly simple and standard RPG mechanics (Use them and then you have a cooldown, the usual)~What it wants to introduce to you though is it's "teamwork" mechanic. This mechanic allows you to have one of your well....heroes...can sacrifice their turn to say instead of using a skill to kill an enemy they switch to teamwork mode so that another one of your team can go to them and be launched farther than they can usually move, you could also do a teamwork attack. Which consists one or maybe even all of your team to attack a single opponent, which does become very useful against harder minions.~Music- ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the music is so nostalgic, it literally brings the heart of 8-Bit RPGS and Super-Sentai series and puts them together to make just an amazing soundtrack~Story - To me, the story is the important part of a game (If it offers a story, it better be damn good *cough cough Call of Duty Ghosts cough cough*. Now at first the story may seem pointless, but after maybe the 2nd season if i recall, it gets just a huge jump in drama and everything just starts to mold into place. Each character is given their own little "arc" or little segment focusing on them and their personal problems, and by the end of them season you feel satisfied and you just want more. Although I won't spoil much of the story, I can tell you that the dialouge includes many pokes and jabs toward internet memes and commonly uses smiley faces (Which too me is very refreshing) Now in terms of story itself, you start off as very ticked off actors that leave the studio they are hired at and buy/create their own. As you progress you are given "choices" through "fan mail" which people send you, although it may not seem significant, these fan mail choose the path you will be taken on and how your fans will react, also be warned there is no voice acting so get ready to read.~Bosses- Each boss is super memorable and actually are pretty damn funny when intended, each skill set makes sense for each boss and are actually pretty fun to figure out how to fight against. Now after certain fights, you are allowed to what some people may call MECHA FIGHTSSSSS!.....now these are simple but are actually pretty fun and poke fun at the *ahem* Power Rangers mecha fights.~Stuio/Crafting Etc. - In the studio you can buy stuff from the shop or look and change the skill sets of your characters. Inside the shops you are given the ability to buy Armor and Weapons. Now most of these items are basic and the best usually come from crafting (DUH) but are still useful. Now crafting, simple, yet not the best or even my favorite, so ill explain my dislikes of it later. You can also go to the "Studio" options which allow you to spend money generated from episodes to upgrade certain attributes (Health Care gives your actors +Health and HD Cameras give you better Audience Conversion Rate). Next up is the Mecha Screen, basiclly upgrading the parts of the mecha to make it better as the story progresses. Not too overly complicated, but could be a lot better.-Cons~Crafting- Because you cant replay episodes, you better hope you get those crafting items by luck OR you can spend considerable ( A LOT ) of money from episodes you did to buy Material Packs and because of this you may be out of luck for the first few seasons or you force yourself not to buy better Armor/Weapons/Studio Upgrades. ~Agency Buying- I held off talking about this because I'm more or less biased toward this, but as you progress thorugh the story you can hire agencies to promote your show, this gives you special boosts to a certain amount of episodes (1 or 3) and of course it tells you the boosts but it doesnt tell you how much fan power it costs (You earn fan power during episodes) which left me bummed out because although there were 4 boosts I liked on the agency, I could only get 1 of them for 3 episodes because I didnt know the fan power was so high. Leaving me a lot of money down the drain.~All in all this is a great game, it achieves what it wants and does even better than certain rpg's. I would give this game the Indie Game of the Year if i could9.4/10

												I'm really enjoying the game so far.  Combat has an XCOM vibe in that you have two actions per ranger, though you can use things like "teamwork" to pull off some powerful attacks/stunts. content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
My Humble ReviewPros Themed after all of the team battle live action tv shows in Japan pre/post Power Rangers Great fun story,comedy,fan service galore Some team/studio management servicing as upgrades for battle and earning spending money Good crafting system and shop giving you a option to either buy all your gear,craft,or both Great number of characters to choose from to make your team, some better than others dependingon your play style Multiple brancing side stories won't spoil Fantastic music, you will want to play with the music turned on, great time Mecha battles, simplistic but fun. Also upgrades for your Mecha Graphics made this game more of a treat for me than probably mostCons Some of the battleground areas sorta repeat often but there is enough variety but might be a con for some. Season 5 difficulty curve, this can be a make or break moment for some trust me (depending on ur choice at a certain point). I got the hardest option so had to battle like a one man army to victory.With planning, patience , and strategy I over came it. I can't decide if I would call it a con or not, but for some they might fight the battles too simplistic which might make the game feel repetitive. Since I enjoyed my time in the game and I played in spurts of 1-3 hrs at a time I did not feel the repetitive nature much.Overall Thoughts & Final VerdictA fantastic lover letter to the genre it is inspired from.Great soundtrack,variety of bosses, mobs,special attacks and team attacks. Truely a gem for anyone who was a fan of the power rangers ,and of 8bit gaming. Do yourself a favor, get this game full price or on sale and hope we get a Chroma Squad 2 bigger,better and badder in action.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Combining pros and cons, because you should know what you like in a game and what you would rather not want to see.Go: It has 8-bit graphics.I myself have gotten quite weary over retro-pixely graphics. But I also know that graphics shouldn't be a reason to determine whether to buy/play a game at all. The worst that can happen with a good game of which you don't like the graphics is that you might think "well, it could look better". And as we all know, if you have to say that it's just the worst, right? It has an 8-bit soundtack.Well, technically it's not 8-bit at all. Ultra fakebit, I'm telling you. Everyone who's ever listened to chiptune should notice immediatly. Noobs.For me it was the same as with the graphics at first - I just can't hear it anymore. And still, the soundtrack is super catchy + fits the game perfectly, although I feel like it could contain a few more tracks. Then again, the theme song is not just catchy, but also funny. Speaking of which, the game itself is pretty punny.Yes, it's definitely one of the funnier games you'll see. Not necessarily the funniest, because it's not Portal. However, although I've always been looking forward to seeing new boss monsters, because of their funny names or puns they came up with, I felt like the humor was innocuous. Of course humor doesn't always have to be ironic/sarcastic/critical - I just feel it wouldn't have hurt sometimes.Oh, hold on, there was this one situation where they were directly referring to Anita Sarkeesian's Tropes vs. Women in Videogames series, which I found absolutely hilarious, very well placed and well executed. Good job Behold Studios! Although it's not a very long game in and of itself, it felt unnecessarily prolonged after around season 3 in the game. It was basically the same thing over and over again, until the game ended. Most episodes you make go like this:Fight minions, fight minions and boss, fight mecha battle against same giant boss.That's probably the weakest part about the game and the one thing I would personally hold against it. Still, I managed to beat the game just yesterday and right now I'm actually in the mood to play it again, with different actors. The fighting system is tactical and has it's own profundity, while remaining simple. It's really a good balance.Although, of course, I personally would put the fighting system and the game itself into the more casual corner with the other more casual fighting systems and the other more casual games.tl;drWhen trying to summarize my experience, I would absolutely recommend anyone (meaning all of my friends and you) to buy this game and at least play the first two to three seasons (the game progresses in seasons) of it, to see if you'd like to continue or stop. I'd also say that it's worth it's regular price. But hey, you can always wait until it's on sale. And if it is on sale, you should definitely get it.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Chroma Squad, a game that gave me a quad heart attacak.Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG, which has quite the fast download baud. But there is more, because the thing about it that earned my immediate apllause, is that it is parodying sentai with several references throughout, which made me glad, but I have sadly found a lot of accidental hentai.Super sentai, or to the duper americans power rangers, are shows about various dangerous threatening the world with a shower of monsters. So it is up to three to six teammates, to bring an end to the evils killing spree. The difference between sentai, and the ignorance of power rangers are huge, mostly in terms of violence because lord knows how hard mothers bother, they somehow still seek something that will make them take the offense and write angry letters.The basic of the plot that quickly forms a blood clot, is five stunt actors are getting the brunt end of the stick from the director, mostly because the real actors are mostly spectators now. They get sick of this repetitive shtick, so they decide that instead they shouldn't bide their time, they quit on the spot leaving the old studio to rot, to start their own, though they bring their former director down by stealing the suits. Earth is under threat, but like a stoners baguette the heroes take a long time to learn, and until then they are quite stern about this all being special effects, or defects. They use the footage of them fighting aliens, to get their show more lighting. I won't go further, because this does go deeper but is actually simple to follow, which is a nice dimple of quirks that I love.The tactical gameplay, is actually quite practical. Like a cannibal feret, you can use teamwork to attack, step back, or get teammates closer or in positions you would rather see in your vision. You have a variety of not only weapons, you have a small soceity of actors to pick from, obviously some fit better into each role of the five, it is up to you to put down that tea cup and to decide which loon becomes a front line goon or a back line maroon. But you also have directors instruction to follow, which you should unless your skull is hollow. Or you'll be low on money, and despite the amount you will quickly blow through it. Items are dropped, as long as you aren't stopped from murdering aliens. Which can be used to upgrade your zord, or create weapons and armor out of cardboard. Though you must not forget, because you can't bet all your cash on weapons and shiny gear, to try and make the enemies fear you. You have to handle a studio, since you are the borough. You can pay for better green screens, shop association, contracts for promotions that last up to three episodes before abdication. Upgrading health care, so that your squad will fair better when taking hits, or upgrade the workshop to get more tiny bits to craft with. One thing I do enjoy, which was quite a clever ploy. Are the letters you receive, after each episode you achieve, you have fan mail to answer, and if you do it without fail you gain fans, money, or more funny as it is I rather support telling your director off when he threatens to take you to court.This game is great, though unfortunately fate can't make everything perfect. The zord battles are the main issue, I did rip a few tissues at them...At first, but aside from that I did not have a thirst for anymore, because they were slow where you just click a button to deal a combo of blows. No strategy or thought, but despite the upgrades you bought, even if you take a hard hit an yelp, and run out of health, you call your fans for help. They give you health, which was quite a bother to me to know there was no stealth to the threat. It meant I could mess up, without having to fess up any real significant consequences.That aside this game is grand, and all of the humor and references make it far from bland. Out of all the sentai references, the one that more so instantly hit my preferences, was a statue greater than sweet bubblegum, that was dedicated to big 1, from Jack-Q the second super sentai.Otherwise can recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Hah! This game is too much fun. For anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy RPGs, with plenty of customization, cheesy chiptune music and intricacies that are easy to learn but difficult to master... Pick this up, even at full price.Here we have a game where you manage a crew of actors/actresses of your choosing, filming a television show with a brand new studio. The two big elements to this game are when you're in the studio (business management mode), and when you're recording (combat mode). Both are fleshed out quite well--when you're in the studio, you *will* spend a while making tactical decisions as to what agency to sign with, what to craft/buy and for whom, and how to gear up your mech for the upcoming fight.Combat is a whole 'nother beast. It isn't *terribly* complicated on the surface, but the addition of being able to enter a "Teamwork" state where you can either combo with others or, more importantly, catapult off them to gain some extra movement and set yourself up, that's where it gets interesting. It's a little reminiscent of throwing people around in Disgaea (similarly, the whole game has a Disgaea-ish feel to it). In fact, if I didn't know any better, I'd think this was a direct offshoot of the Super Sentai-esque characters from Disgaea, but that's just because this is also a tactical RPG and it's a common trope.In addition, adding a layer to combat, in each scenario you have a pair of "Director's Instructions," which net you bonus points (referred to as "audience"). These are tallied at the end to give you money and "fans" (which are effectively points that allow you to benefit from more of your chosen agency's bonuses). PROS:* Though it's not for everyone, and can get a little repetitive, the cheesy, chiptune, over-the-top music is great. * Also subjective, but I find the combat to be just plain fun, and hard difficulty will provide no small amount of challenge for the perfectionist. Mech combat is no exception.* Very deep game overall. Seems like something I'd give another playthrough.* It's funny and cheesy without pushing either of those too far.* Nicely animated for 2D sprites.CONS:* Some of the stats are a little unclear, and there seems to be no in-game explanation for most of them. Some of them are self-explanatory, some aren't. This might not really count as a con, but the UI could have used some cleaning up.* Can't undo accidental misclicks in combat. In fairness though, that can be chalked up to human error, it's not like it's easy to misclick.* No toggle to see the tactical grid, which has led to some poor choices in gauging how far away I've been from an opponent (another reason I wish there was an undo function).* This may just be me, but my computer stutters at least one or two times during those crucial timing-based defense moves in the mech battles. Probably just me since I run so much in my background, but the game continues and I'm left only to guess when to click. I've run much higher graphics games with zero issues like this still running everything in my background, but I will say the game is otherwise technically sound.* My last minor gripe, I wish I could fire an actor and replace them. So fair warning, you can't change your characters mid-game.Pick this one up if any of that appeals to you, it definitely put a smile on my face.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG where you use power ranger esque characters to fight monsters. so right off the bat it sounds awesome right? Well it is, it's really awesome but is it perfect? No. When the game is on the ground using its awesome sentai inspired battle system it sparkles like the sea. However each stage ends with a mecha fight, that is cool in theory but in practice it becomes a nightmare. Stages in this game usually take about an hour so after an hour of immensly satisfying tactical comabt where victory is decided by skill alone you are thrust into a situation where you could randomly lose all your progress and need to entirely restart the mission. This can leave you entirely dishearted as an hour of very intense gameplay can be thrown out the window. Aside from this however, the game is outstanding. looks great, sounds great and can lead to some very satisfying gameplay. You really should play this awesome game, but be ready from some seriously salty rage quits at the meccha battles.

content:
Posted: February 27
												The "humble" pixel art of this game can catch you off-guard. It's a very funny game, much deeper than I expected (30h + on it), and overall it's very well done. You start with 5 stunt men, from a Power Rangers alike TV show, that get tired of doing all the hard work of the show and getting none of the credits, so they decide to create their own show where they can be the leading actors too. I won't talk about the rest of the story because that would be a spoiler. The combat is turn based, like XCOM or The Banner Saga. When you are not fighting, you are running the show and you have to deal with TV ratings, marketing, season budgets, etc. At the beginning it will be a very crappy and low-budget show, and it will be up to you to improve it.The 95% of positive reviews are a good indicator of the quality of this Brazilian game funded through a kickstarter campaign. It's an homage to the Power Rangers / Super Sentai kind of shows from the 90's, so you'll probably find it more interesting if you were a kid during that time. The key feature of this game it's his humor. They managed to pay an homage but yet at the same time they mock every single cliché from those shows. The acrobatic jumps, the different colors of each fighter, the giant robots (Mechas) at the end of each episode, and much more, it's all there. It's a cliché mocking homage game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG where you use power ranger esque characters to fight monsters. so right off the bat it sounds awesome right? Well it is, it's really awesome but is it perfect? No. When the game is on the ground using its awesome sentai inspired battle system it sparkles like the sea. However each stage ends with a mecha fight, that is cool in theory but in practice it becomes a nightmare. Stages in this game usually take about an hour so after an hour of immensly satisfying tactical comabt where victory is decided by skill alone you are thrust into a situation where you could randomly lose all your progress and need to entirely restart the mission. This can leave you entirely dishearted as an hour of very intense gameplay can be thrown out the window. Aside from this however, the game is outstanding. looks great, sounds great and can lead to some very satisfying gameplay. You really should play this awesome game, but be ready from some seriously salty rage quits at the meccha battles.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Hah! This game is too much fun. For anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy RPGs, with plenty of customization, cheesy chiptune music and intricacies that are easy to learn but difficult to master... Pick this up, even at full price.Here we have a game where you manage a crew of actors/actresses of your choosing, filming a television show with a brand new studio. The two big elements to this game are when you're in the studio (business management mode), and when you're recording (combat mode). Both are fleshed out quite well--when you're in the studio, you *will* spend a while making tactical decisions as to what agency to sign with, what to craft/buy and for whom, and how to gear up your mech for the upcoming fight.Combat is a whole 'nother beast. It isn't *terribly* complicated on the surface, but the addition of being able to enter a "Teamwork" state where you can either combo with others or, more importantly, catapult off them to gain some extra movement and set yourself up, that's where it gets interesting. It's a little reminiscent of throwing people around in Disgaea (similarly, the whole game has a Disgaea-ish feel to it). In fact, if I didn't know any better, I'd think this was a direct offshoot of the Super Sentai-esque characters from Disgaea, but that's just because this is also a tactical RPG and it's a common trope.In addition, adding a layer to combat, in each scenario you have a pair of "Director's Instructions," which net you bonus points (referred to as "audience"). These are tallied at the end to give you money and "fans" (which are effectively points that allow you to benefit from more of your chosen agency's bonuses). PROS:* Though it's not for everyone, and can get a little repetitive, the cheesy, chiptune, over-the-top music is great. * Also subjective, but I find the combat to be just plain fun, and hard difficulty will provide no small amount of challenge for the perfectionist. Mech combat is no exception.* Very deep game overall. Seems like something I'd give another playthrough.* It's funny and cheesy without pushing either of those too far.* Nicely animated for 2D sprites.CONS:* Some of the stats are a little unclear, and there seems to be no in-game explanation for most of them. Some of them are self-explanatory, some aren't. This might not really count as a con, but the UI could have used some cleaning up.* Can't undo accidental misclicks in combat. In fairness though, that can be chalked up to human error, it's not like it's easy to misclick.* No toggle to see the tactical grid, which has led to some poor choices in gauging how far away I've been from an opponent (another reason I wish there was an undo function).* This may just be me, but my computer stutters at least one or two times during those crucial timing-based defense moves in the mech battles. Probably just me since I run so much in my background, but the game continues and I'm left only to guess when to click. I've run much higher graphics games with zero issues like this still running everything in my background, but I will say the game is otherwise technically sound.* My last minor gripe, I wish I could fire an actor and replace them. So fair warning, you can't change your characters mid-game.Pick this one up if any of that appeals to you, it definitely put a smile on my face.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016



YouTube™ Video: Backlog Beatdown: Phil the Conquistadork Reviews CHROMA SQUAD! 

			Views: 64		

			Phil's review of Chroma Squad! Phil's New Year's Resolution is to kick the crap out of his considerable gaming backlog, and he's starting with the tactical RPG Chroma Squad!		

It’s a tactical RPG with base-building strategy elements that follows the story of five stuntmen who leave their second banana positions to make their own martial arts TV show. Like Knights of Pen and Paper, Chroma Squad has retro-inspired graphics and music, and spends a lot of time breaking the fourth wall and poking fun at pop culture tropes.I personally felt that Knights of Pen and Paper, while it had some charm, went on for far too long without shaking anything up, ultimately weakening what might have been a charming experience by overstaying its welcome. And while Chroma Squad sometimes suffers from a similar affliction, I feel that Behold Studios learned a hell of a lot, tightening and producing an RPG that is just plain fun to play.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Wonderful little tactical RPG game where you control a team of actors with their own show where they fight monsters, which starts coming true as time goes on.The meat of the game is the tactical turn based combat, and as someone who really enjoys this type of gameplay this is right up my alley. There are also some RPG elements outside of combat, such as allocating skill points, crafting and buying upgrades.After completing most maps you join together and go into a giant mecha to fight the boss of the map again, with a different combat style which is focused on timing the hits and using a limited number of different abilities. This is a nice addition for the first few times, however it is not nearly as fleshed out and feels like an after thought. And seeing as how you have to do a bunch of these fights I'm quite sure everyone will get tired of them before the end of the game.The story is reasonably entertaining, although it can become tiresome to follow since it is delivered solely through text boxes of the main characaters, and you have to wait for each one to finish scrolling in order to move on to the next one. So if you read much faster than the game scrolls then you're going to have to do a lot of waiting. There is an option to fast forward through everything, however it is not really useful if you still want to follow the story since the fast forward skips everything.And the game does go a little overboard with the pixel artstyle, I certainly would have liked more definition and fluid animations. Also the overall design starts to become stale with time, especially since this is quite a long game.I would easily recommend Chroma Squad to any fan of the tactical turn based combat style.7 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Chroma Squad is a Tactical RPG game made by Behold Studios, creators of the mobile game, Knights of Pen and Paper, an RPG that is more pressing buttons that movement. Now you'd think that this would make it hard for them, seeing as they're pretty much doing nothing the same. If you do, get out. This game is packed with humor, references, and breaking of the fourth wall. And while most people hate breaking the fourth wall, it's done in a way where if you literally are paying no attention, you will not see it. And if you're going into this game using the internet for the first time, the references to pop culture and video games will definitely fly over your head, but if you know the internet like the back of your hand, every reference will make you laugh, and there are a lot. The game play is simple, you have two actions you can do with every character every turn, and you can switch between who you're using by clicking their box, or using both of the above player's actions. Each "class" has their own unique set of skills, with customization diverse enough so that there is very little repetition. A lot of this game's achievements can be accomplished on the first run, but to get them all you will have to play the game at least three times. And if you get stuck, the community has already figured them out. After you beat the game, I reccomend sticking around after the credits for each run, and you will be pleased by what comes after, but stick around until you get forced out of them to get information that will complete the story more and more. Now buy the game and get to playing. #FrendshipIsForever

content:
Posted: January 29
												Five stunt doubles quit their job and start their own sentai show in Chroma Squad, a turn based tactical RPG. If you’re not familiar with the sentai genre, it’s basically costumed people doing goofy acrobatics and occasionally piloting giant robots to fight space monsters and other wacky stuff, and this game features all of that. You even get to name your team (I picked Colorblind Crusaders to be ironic) and can customize all of their catch phrases.Each of your team members has a role that defines how you will use them in combat. The scout typically runs ahead to stun groups of enemies or pick off individual monsters. Support heals and technician has a variety of useful skills and long distance attacks. Lead and Assault are for tanking and damage dealing respectively. All characters have their own skill tree that expands with new selectable skills every season.This game features an assist system where a character ends their turn and becomes available for throwing other characters across the battlefield. If you put characters in assist mode while surrounding a monster and attack with a non-assist character, you will perform a team attack for additional damage. Finally, placing all five members of your squad in assist mode surrounding a monster initiates a special finishing move that does a lot of damage. A major underlying system in Chroma Squad is the audience meter. You gain audience by successfully completing levels. To keep things interesting, each level has director’s instructions that are essentially mini-quests ranging from “defeat the monster with a finishing move” or “attack the monster with lead 5 times”. Audience is turned into cash at the end of each episode and can be used with various marketing agencies to give your squad various different bonuses as well as additional cash. Cash is then used to buy armor or weapons or crafting materials to make specialized gear.If I had to sum up Chroma Squad with one word it would probably be “cozy”, if only because of the soundtrack and overall graphic theme. Try listening to the OST on youtube and you’ll see (or hear rather) what I mean. I really liked the simplified retro-look as well, it has sort of a late-era SNES feel to it which fits perfectly with the game’s style. There are all sorts of little campy details like the characters doing different silly poses when they’re the focus of conversation or the omnipresent recording crew following you to every single battle and staying just out of harm’s way. All of this comes with a nasty catch though; there are some significant performance issues in this game. My rig is capable of doing VR games no problem but I still had loads of framerate drops at random parts of the game. The good news about this is that it typically won’t effect your playthrough due to the tactical nature of the game, but it will be a bit of a pain for giant robot fights where you have a QTE during the monster’s turn that requires you to click at a precise time to defend.If you are in to sentai-style stuff at all, you will probably love Chroma Squad. Even if you aren’t though, this game is still fun for anyone who would enjoy a tactical rpg like Disgaea or Final Fantasy Tactics.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												       Chroma Squad is simply a love letter to what Power Rangers use to be. It has action, comedy, interesting writing, and anything you would want from a PR game. You start out as 5 stuntmen who have recently quit their jobs doing sentai stunts to form their own studio. When you get into the studio thats when the real magic begins. Once there, you're able to design your own suits and mechas, something I'm sure any PR fan has dreamed of.     You're also able to respond to fan letters and control your fan market to some extent by choosing from a wide selection of advertaisment firms. When you go into battle this game is a mix of an RTS and Turn Based RPG ala Pokemon. The RTS side is used for your simple ranger battles where each class has a variety of skills at their disposal, which grow as the story progresses. You're also able to do showy finishing moves on the bosses in true sentai fashion. My only problem with the RTS board is that sometimes you can't see parts of the grid because they're blocked by objects on the field.       The game then becomes much closer to a TurnBased RPG when in mecha form where you're allowed to hit your opposing monster a certain number of times before a hit misses and they hit back. But, all is not lost when they hit back theres a system that if you time it correctly and click in the white area of the bar you can block some of the damage. Think Gears of War's reload system. Everyonce in awhile though this bar lags causing you to get hit by the full blunt of the attack without a chance to stop it.TL;DR:The Story and writing are amazing and are VERY PR like. The RTS combat while fun has some issues with grid square blocking, nothing gamebreaking though. The mecha combat is far slower than the RTS combat but still quite funScore: 8.6/10

Posted: August 20, 2015
												 This a really cool, funny game. It's based on Power Rangers, so it's obviously already awesome just because of that, but the gameplay is what really makes me love it so much. This is a strategy game where your characters become more powerful by either (The long way...) crafting equipment you gain from various enemies, or (The easy capitalist way) paying for equipment at a shop. This game also has a few different possible endings, so that gives it some replay value, and since this game lets you choose different characters at the beginning as well as have your own play style, you shouldn't really be bored out of your mind replaying the game like I usually am with some other games. The price isn't really too much compared to what you get out of it, because there are a lot of ways you could customize your team to work with your play style (At least 3!.... Probably more, though...). Chroma Squad really gave me a lot of nostalgia, especially since I grew up watching Power Rangers, but I think I could really recommend this game to anyone who really likes any sort of strategy game or any sort of game where you can make important choices to decide what happens. Soooo.... This is a pretty good game, and, as a plus, the soundtrack is awesome!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												If this game were a woman, it would be that kind plain looking one sitting at the bar that you think "well why not" and then when you both get back to her place you have the most mind-blowing one-night stand of your life.  You leave the next day thinking you should ask for her number, but you don't want to ruin the mood.  For the next week you can't stop thinking about her, every waking moment at work, you're dream of that smooth sound track, or the cute way teamwork throws you over the enemy head or that classic finishing move with a twist...you realize she was the one, she was the game you could spend the rest of your life playing if they'd just put out more!  But...but, it's too late, because you didn't want to be ask...damn damn damn!  (seriously though, I'd be happy if you guys made some DLC for the game)Actual review:This game is a paragon of polished indie developing.  Gameplay is nicely balanced between managing a budding hollywood studio, planning show episodes, gearing out your team, and actual filming (combat events) of the show.  The storyline is well written and kept me wanting to find out what happened next, combat is varied with all the different things you can do (teamwork, using items/weapons, skills, morphing ("chromizing") vs fighting as nomral people, and of course all the wonderful abilities that come up through gameplay.   Let's not forget the mini-goals you can choose to complete during each scenario and managing your fan base (answering emails...etc).I appreciate that you have a casual mode for people who want to build a studio based on purely asthetic decisions vs. the harder modes where you need to manage stats that items give production.My favorite part is when building a team I can name them anything I want (I can name the squad anything I want too) and you get to choose the people on your team INCLUDING a loveable but useless animal mascot....well he wasn't so useless once I armed him with guns!  mwhahahaha!

Posted: May 3, 2015
												The first time I played this game I was hooked until my laptop's battery died.As someone who's been aching for a good game about tokusatsu for years, I can't think of a game that has ever given me so much childish glee.The combat is fun, the presentation is excellent, and the management aspect is solid. Chroma Squad feels like it went down a checklist of damn-near everything I personally could ever want in a game. Power Rangers, giant robots, tactical combat, extensive customization, crafting... Even if some of these systems aren't individually excellent in their execution, together they create something truly special.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												This game is fantastic. Lots of nostalgia for anyone growing up watching power rangers. There isnt much strategy to the game but just enough to make it enjoyable though you wont be smacking your head against the wall because it is difficult. Sometimes completing all the director's instructions can be a chore but if you dont care about that and just want to 'win' than it will be a piece of cake...unless you play on the hardest difficulty, where you will need all the fans you can get to generate money and keep your studio floating. There is definitely replayability because you can get a couple of different endings but it feels like most of the choices you make are small scale, it is a pretty linear story with some variations in my opinion.Also, dont pay any attention to the gamergate types that complain about feminist tropes. There is one episode that has a guy kidnapped instead of a girl in the very beginning and it doesnt have any bearing on the rest of the plot, just the game creators making commentary on overplayed tropes.Overall I would highly recommend this game to someone who loves strategy, RPGs, power rangers, and a few corny jokes.10/10

Posted: May 1, 2015
												Have you ever wanted to be a Power Ranger?  Have you ever wanted to direct the action of the Power Rangers?  Have you ever wanted to see it all play out in old school pixelated graphics?  Have you ever wanted to manage a film studio and also have an anthropomorphic beaver on your team?  Chroma Squad might be for you then...  If you haven't wanted these things, you should still check it out.  It is a pretty fun turn based combat game with some management simulation and strategy built in.  The graphics are fun, the story is funny and witty, and the game is light and good natured.  If you are looking for more information you can check out my YouTube series on the game at

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Chroma Squad is a Tactical-RPG (i.e.: Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem), coated with some Management Sim mechanics.In Chroma Squad you control an independent Super Sentai Studio trying to create its first series. As such, you'll have to manage your money, buy upgrades to the studio, new clothes for your actors and hire people to take care of your marketing strategy. The meat of the game, however, lies between these management sessions. Whenever you record an episode, the game becomes a tactical RPG: you start giving orders to your actors on where to move, who to attack, stuff like that.It's an amazingly stylish game. The pixel-art is awesome, the soundtrack is pure chiptune bliss (plus a main theme with japanese lyrics!) and the game is packed with references to pop culture and super sentais in general.You don't really need to be a super sentai fan to enjoy the solid tactics mechanics in this game, but it surely adds to the overall experience. I recommend this game to anyone who ever enjoyed a Power Rangers episode or is just itching for a new TRPG game.TL;DR: Awesome Tactical-RPG with stylish graphics, soundtrack and references. If you like Super Sentais you'll fall in love with it!

Posted: August 20, 2015
												 This a really cool, funny game. It's based on Power Rangers, so it's obviously already awesome just because of that, but the gameplay is what really makes me love it so much. This is a strategy game where your characters become more powerful by either (The long way...) crafting equipment you gain from various enemies, or (The easy capitalist way) paying for equipment at a shop. This game also has a few different possible endings, so that gives it some replay value, and since this game lets you choose different characters at the beginning as well as have your own play style, you shouldn't really be bored out of your mind replaying the game like I usually am with some other games. The price isn't really too much compared to what you get out of it, because there are a lot of ways you could customize your team to work with your play style (At least 3!.... Probably more, though...). Chroma Squad really gave me a lot of nostalgia, especially since I grew up watching Power Rangers, but I think I could really recommend this game to anyone who really likes any sort of strategy game or any sort of game where you can make important choices to decide what happens. Soooo.... This is a pretty good game, and, as a plus, the soundtrack is awesome!

I could say this game could finished in less than a day if you did all of it in every difficulty, but that's clearly up to you.  To Behold Studios, THANK YOU! Please consider doing a sequel!

Posted: February 29, 2016
												If you are a fan of Power Rangers or Sentai, you will absolutely love this game from start to finish. It is a well built strategy rpg with all the features necessary to build your own team of crimefighters with a super meta/ awesome narrative to boot. The gameplay is smooth, and the game visuals add to the tone and character of the story Behold Studios was trying to tell. It is not a perfect game. I wish the mecha or megazord fights were more diverese (or more like the common combat) maybe with like 5 zords against the giant monster in a strategy style. I would like to have a custom character creator as dlc if possible. In short, besides my nitpicks. I do recommend this game. It feels like you the manager of a season of power rangers or super sential and thats all I could ask for. Plus, the MUSIC IS FREAKING AMAZING.

Posted: November 12, 2016
												So in Sentai and Power Rangers, when the team gets defeated, they come back later in the episode and beat the enemy.You're not allowed to be defeated and I feel like it really takes away from what Sentai and PR is all about, standing defiant despite defeat.  Still, I get it, one of the 5 characters is a healer, and you have to use that.  It prevents me from making a fantasy, dream-team though.  Anyway, I'm a 1993-present PR and Sentai buff, and this game is the closest thing to an RPG for that genre.  I'm a bit of a fanboy though so take it as you will.As far as the gameplay, it's quite basic really, and the combat system makes you want to always use counterattack skills.  The music is really good!

Posted: November 3, 2016
Product received for free
												Great squad based RPG/microsim game. The simulation doesn't matter that much it basically functions as an upgrade menu so don't expect much from that end of it but the fighting felt good,although a bit tedious at times due to crazy ammounts of knockback. From the sound of most of the negative reviews they were playing on harder settings, but I was playing on casual because I never have enough time to beat long rpgs on harder difficulties, but anyway it seemed a little too easy until the end game. I barely won so I can only imagine how difficult it must be on harder settings, as It was a good game but I am not likely to replay it as it did get a bit tedious towards the end, especially the giant robot fights which were cool in concept but always boiled down to the exact same thing. Anyway I got this on humble bundle and wasn't disapointed, check it out if you want, or don't its your time and money, this is just my opinion that I felt necasary to write as I just played this for about 8 hours over the last couple of days and was mostly hooked.

Posted: October 30, 2016
												As a tokusatsu fan, Chroma Squad is amazing. I was worried that, much like many other Power Rangers inspired media, this game would be ashamed of it's roots. Making fun of the source with a "look how stupid this is" attitude.That is certainly not the case. Chroma Squad is very self aware, but is a celebration of the genre! It's light hearted, tongue-in-cheek humour, and most importantly: fun.The gameplay may be basic when compared to other tactics based RPGs however the dressing (for lack of a better word) more than makes it up. Perhaps I am biased, but the idea of running my own Sentai production company, with control over the costumes and props, and studio, and marketing etc. coupled with the absolutely charm of the writing... I can't describe how happy it made me.I feel exteremely bad for waiting this long to pick up this game, and through a humble bundle no less. The developers of this game deserve full compensation for doing such a magnificent job.I don't think you NEED to be a tokusatsu fan to enjoy this game. The writing makes it very accessible. But if you are a fan, or have knowledge of the subject, there are a ton of little nods and easter eggs to be found.

												As a both Tokusatsu fan and Power Rangers fan this game is pure gold They even find a way to put a Pseudo Kamen Rider in there, love it gameplay is solid, soundtrack is good Play it

Posted: March 3, 2016
												TL; DR: If you like X-COM style tactical RPGs, this is a pretty fun and light spin on it.  The game has some rough edges, but is a solid all around tactical RPG.Long Version:If you're into tactical RPGs like X-COM, then this is a fun 10-15 'light' experience.  The angle (you're stuntmen from a Power Rangers-esque TV show that get in a fued with the director and decided to start a new show) is original and can be pretty amusing.  For better or worse, you can fast forward through most the story.  I wish there was an in between, where you could read the cupious amount of story text quickly without reverting to warp speed, but it's either painfully slow or hyper speed.  The other thing holding the game back is a bit of UI/tutorial polish.  The game, especially in the beginning, rapidly unlocks new features, but never really even tells you they're there, let alone what everything means.  It's not a deal breaker, but I could imagine going through significant chunks of the game without realizing some suped up ability or item was available.The other drawback of the game is the QTE Mecha mini-game that ends many of the episodes.  You basically are given a % chance to hit on a punch, to continure your combo, and have the option to switch to defense or lay a power move on.  Needless to say, you will feel the burn of the RNG when you miss 3 or 4 consecutive ~75% swings, each time taking massive damage because you can't properly defend when you miss.  You thene have a little bar that you have to click when it's in the right zone to deflect as much damage as possible.  I only 'lost' 3 or 4 times playing through the game, and every time it was in the mecha game.  Kudos for trying to mix it up with a different paced bit, but it's too rough around the edges, especially compared to the relatively tight tactical RPG play.Speaking of the 'RPG' aspect, they are definitely on the lite side.  No XP, you just unlock the next level of the skill tree when you complete each season.  No mana points either, everything is done on a x-com style cool down system (also, there is no ammo, everything can be used as many times as it cools down).  There is crafting, though it's not very well explained.  The advantage of crafting is that the gear has a few set attributes, plus a few random attributes to it that MAY make it better than the items you just buy outright.  But you never know until you craft it, and you can't compare a craft item to your current gear until you actually make it.  You also have to combine lower craftable items into better items, and then better items again, to be able to craft the good stuff.  This, again, is never really explained and buried on a submenu - I didn't know I could do it until Season 5 (of 6), and until then, I was confused on what the point of a crafting system was when you never got the materials you needed to craft.  Turns out, I had plenty, but I had to combine my 75 rolls of regular tape into 15 rolls of silver tape, and then those 15 rolls into 5 rolls of gold tape...which I could then use to buy the pimp stuff.If tactical RPGs are your thing, this is a nice light experience.  I imagine it has pretty low system specs, so it would probably be good on a laptop, though the Unity engine chugs occassionally, especially during the mecha scenes.  Definitely worth picking up for a few bucks or in a Humble Bundle.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												So in Sentai and Power Rangers, when the team gets defeated, they come back later in the episode and beat the enemy.You're not allowed to be defeated and I feel like it really takes away from what Sentai and PR is all about, standing defiant despite defeat.  Still, I get it, one of the 5 characters is a healer, and you have to use that.  It prevents me from making a fantasy, dream-team though.  Anyway, I'm a 1993-present PR and Sentai buff, and this game is the closest thing to an RPG for that genre.  I'm a bit of a fanboy though so take it as you will.As far as the gameplay, it's quite basic really, and the combat system makes you want to always use counterattack skills.  The music is really good!

Posted: November 3, 2016
Product received for free
												Great squad based RPG/microsim game. The simulation doesn't matter that much it basically functions as an upgrade menu so don't expect much from that end of it but the fighting felt good,although a bit tedious at times due to crazy ammounts of knockback. From the sound of most of the negative reviews they were playing on harder settings, but I was playing on casual because I never have enough time to beat long rpgs on harder difficulties, but anyway it seemed a little too easy until the end game. I barely won so I can only imagine how difficult it must be on harder settings, as It was a good game but I am not likely to replay it as it did get a bit tedious towards the end, especially the giant robot fights which were cool in concept but always boiled down to the exact same thing. Anyway I got this on humble bundle and wasn't disapointed, check it out if you want, or don't its your time and money, this is just my opinion that I felt necasary to write as I just played this for about 8 hours over the last couple of days and was mostly hooked.

Posted: October 30, 2016
												As a tokusatsu fan, Chroma Squad is amazing. I was worried that, much like many other Power Rangers inspired media, this game would be ashamed of it's roots. Making fun of the source with a "look how stupid this is" attitude.That is certainly not the case. Chroma Squad is very self aware, but is a celebration of the genre! It's light hearted, tongue-in-cheek humour, and most importantly: fun.The gameplay may be basic when compared to other tactics based RPGs however the dressing (for lack of a better word) more than makes it up. Perhaps I am biased, but the idea of running my own Sentai production company, with control over the costumes and props, and studio, and marketing etc. coupled with the absolutely charm of the writing... I can't describe how happy it made me.I feel exteremely bad for waiting this long to pick up this game, and through a humble bundle no less. The developers of this game deserve full compensation for doing such a magnificent job.I don't think you NEED to be a tokusatsu fan to enjoy this game. The writing makes it very accessible. But if you are a fan, or have knowledge of the subject, there are a ton of little nods and easter eggs to be found.

Posted: February 3, 2016
												A Game that puts you in charge of making your own Awesome Super Hero Saturday Morning Cartoon Show, because your last boss rejected your ideas to improve the show, so now its pay back and its all good. Why? Because you, the player, take control of these 5 actors starting up their own TV Show and you get to decide what needs to be done. Like which episode plot/mission you will be doing, earn cash, managing your Awesome Studio Backlot, earning a ton of cash, getting support and likes from fans, $making it rain$, crafting items for your stars to use in the episode (which improves stats), earning tons of cash, having references from actual shows to be in your episodes, and did I mention earning butt-loads of Cash. So if you ever wished of making your very own Saturday Morning TV Show then this is the game for you.

Posted: February 10, 2016
												The full review can be found on Start 2 Continue[start2continue.com].Excerpt:After enough grief from their director, five talented stunt actors decide to take matters into their own hands, starting their own studio and action-packed TV show. Where Millennials like myself had the Power Rangers back in the ’90s, Behold Studios gives us Chroma Squad, a tactical RPG where you control this quintet of do-gooders in their rise to glory–or at least television fame.Packed with a ton of tongue-in-cheek, fourth-wall-breaking humor and its obvious impersonation of Power Rangers, Chroma Squad is all about nostalgia in its style and delivery. With its pixelated sprites and loading screens that “warm up” and adjust like an old tube television when you’re starting a new episode, this is the kind of game that would go great with pajamas and a bowl of cereal on a Saturday morning.

												Woooo... Just finifhsed the game on its "medium difficulty" and all i can say is wow. Such a satisfying experience all around. If you really enjoy rpg strategy games such as fire emblem then this is certainly going to make you one happy camper.PROS:Very easy to get intoHilariously bad punsGame doesn't take itself too seriouslyCustomizable catch phrasesGreat upbeat musicPretty colors O>Oa LOT of humour----------------------CONS:Mech battles get repetitive after the first 4~Crafting can just sometimes seem outclassed by some of the easily aquired shop itemsHilariously terrible punsCan sometimes feel a bit aggravating if you need to get a certain directors challenge done, then the AI screws it up for youAll and all, i loved this game, but its not for everyone. So play it if you watched power ranges as a kid and always wanted to be one. ^-^

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the small playing time that Steam shows. When I started playing this game for the first time, I was offline, and I played for 7 hours non-stop.This game is a dream that come true!When I was a kid, on the 90's I loved to watch tokusatsus (heroes in costumes, like Power Rangers, Super Sentai, Kamen Rider, etc..) and loved to play with my cousins like we were in the show.If you're like me who always wanted to be the creator of your own tokusatsu show, here's your chance!Chroma Squad is a beautiful game of tactical RPG  (a bit similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, or Tactics Ogre) where you control your own tokusatsu squad and studio in your way to become very successful and famous.You can customize the colors, names, and choose the actors that will play them, and even what they say when they call their giant robot, or when they transform!You equip items (that even change their appearance!) buying from the store, or creating from your workshop to become stronger, and choose wich skills each one will have. Each squad member have it's own role and skills. (There's the Lead, Assault, Scout, Techie and Support.)If you watched tokusatsus you will notice many references, and the game have very funny conversations and events.Even if you're not a fan, nor didn't watched any tokusatsu, I recomend this game if you like Tactical RPGs. You will love it!Don't waste any more time, buy it and have tons of fun!Now if you excuse me, the world need my help. Random Rangers, let's Randomize!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Really fun game with a lot of replay value.  Tactical RPG combat flows well and the team-up system leads to some fun things to do even while abilities are on cooldown.  Branching story paths make for some good incentive to play through multiple times.Mecha battles are a little one-note, but still fun.  Crafting system seems to have bad drops, but with proper marketing choices and investing in some of the material packs you can make it work out.My only complaints: YOU CANNOT UNDO ACTIONS, which is so frustrating sometimes, oh boy.  That's the number one problem for me.  Also there is not enough cool stuff to spend money on in the in-game store, as each tier boils down to "defense armor" vs "offense armor".  Crafting has one or two interesting items (the Speed boots and the Team-Toss gloves) but there isn't a lot of variety outside of the gimmick items, when there could be a lot more going on.  More actor choices (and the ability to recast them mid-series) would be nice too, it feels like a very small pool of options.The game also ends right when you start feeling very powerful so I'd like to see a 'New Series' mode (where you do a new team with a new storyline but keep your studio) or some sort of extra seasons.  Some way to keep going.  The game feels a little short.  A 'mission creator' and some sort of endless mode with escalating difficulty as seasons keep going on could fix this, and I believe the developers are looking into these sorts of ideas.It's off to a great start, it's an awesome game for anyone into tactical RPGs or sentai/power rangers stuff, and I hope it keeps improving over time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

Posted: November 11, 2016
												The normal gameplay gets a bit repetitive and ability-on-cooldown heavy later on, and there's few options for divergent strategies within your team, but I still would've recommended this game if not for the absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG relient mech fights.  There's no strategy, it's all luck.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												I'm going to recommend it, with a few caveats.  Keep in mind that the game mostly gets by on charm and style.  As a tactics game, it doesn't do any of the things I'd like it to.  My favorite Tactics games, like Final Fantasy Tactics and Tactics Ogre, let you recruit a handful of named characters with personalities.  Other games, like XCOM, let you fully recruit and customize your own squad.  Chroma Squad does neither, you can choose 5 from about 15 different characters at the very beginning of the game, and they're all interchangeable with no discernable personality.So without interesting characters the gameplay has to be compelling (like XCOM) but it's pretty simplistic and does a poor job of explaining itself.  That being said, you get to make your own Sentai team.  So, you know.  That goes a long way.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Ten years ago, every friday after school, my mom and I would drop by the nearby Blockbuster and get a handful of DVD's. Most of the ones I got were blocks of episodes of TV series from the 90's/2000's. Some of these were, you guessed it, Power Rangers episodes. Ever since then, the TV show, and vitrually any other kind of Sentai, held a special place in my heart, and you can imagine how I felt when I saw this game on Steam. This game mixes strategy with the over-the-top action, spandex, robots, and explosions of any episode of Power Rangers, and does a phenominal job of invoking the inner child who was too young to  see sucky special effects. If you like fast-paced, turn-based games and Sentai fight scenes, then I definitely reccomend Chroma Squad.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												The pros:The game is quite fun and very addictive. It's a strategy RPG with a unique concept that is pulled off extremely well. It's the perfect application of crafting mechanics, too. The graphics are beautiful, and the music is impressively good. The concept of going from small-time to big time is a brilliant idea for a game of this manner.There is a lot of attention to detail in the game, with secret things to find both graphically and plot wise. It's easily worth the MSRP, and is one of those things you don't know you want until you have played it for yourself.Protip: Don't try hard mode on your first playthrough. It's really unbalanced hard.The cons:The programming is so glitchy the game feels like a beta version. The textboxes overflow when people are talking and transitions are often jarringly abrupt, just cutting out and flickering when a level ends instead of having a proper "you win" screen. The controller controls need major work as they just operate the mouse cursor instead of having true controller support.The writing is mediocre, with very poor grammar that could have used major proofreading. Some of the scenarios are sort of nonsensical due to the writing. The appearances of numerous Kickstarter backers break the immersion of the game, it would have been better if they didn't have to awkwardly say their full names every time someone appeared. The backer characters all look like the same nerdy white guys, and dont make sense in the setting.With the lack of characterization you'd think there'd be some kind of character creation for your team, but instead there is very little in the way of choice if you want a decent team, I wish you could choose from more diverse appearances and just assign certain personalities to them, instead there are kind of obvious "best characters", so if you didn't want a cartoon beaver on your team youre flat out of luck.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												A long overdue gift to those who grew up dreaming of making a Sentai series all their own. What Chroma Squad lacks in simulation elements it compensates with a neverending celebration of the best parts of Sentai new and old. If there is anything to pity its that Chroma Squad wasn't 3 different games and fans of Metal Heroes and Kamen Rider only get to revel in the last season of the storyline, but their inclusion shows just how much love Behold Studios has to offer, it can't be contained and oozes out of every scene! At the same time, if you step outside what the game celebrates you're left with an honest and simple Strategy RPG with map and encounter designs that genre veterans will find uninspired. The Episodes of the game are filled with colorful characters based on classic Sentai villains and antiheroes or pop culture and it is their presence and strength of personality that bring flavor to each individual Episode. So if you're prepared to be charmed, prepared to fall in love with the idea of being a team of costumed heroes, or prepared to be entertained by a campy throwback to how Sentai captures the hearts of children, Chroma Squad is absolutely the game you're after, look no further.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												After 20 hours of play I would most deffinetly that if you want to get this game...wait for a steam sale or humble bundle sale, etc. It's not worth the full asking price. The awesome atmosphere of 90s Power Rangers, Voltron and Silver Rider and the Star Sherifs is more or less lost among the repetitive grind of the game. The missions devolve into mindless running around and doing the same 4 skills on each of your squad mates over and over again, on bland, unispired, baren fields. No variaty, no interesting locations, no obsticles. The mecha fights are a joke. You like to grind press a quick-time eventbutton 20 times, while waiting or a randomly generated percentage attack to hit or miss ? Well this is the game for you. To add insult to injury in the middle of the game there is an episode which is just mecha battles one after the other, like the developers just gave up and said ♥♥♥♥ it...The final stage/episode is even worse. Oh do you want to fight all the bosses up until now all at once ? How about after that try to escape from a room filled with gas, while you get pummeled by a repetitive bad guys? And then get to the final boss that just spams those god damn unskippable attacks so you can watch them ...hmm 50+ times? Best day ever.All in all - good story, cool idea, fun concept with the companies, the studio upgrades, etc.Horrble repetitive main game - fight 5 different enemies the whole game.... - a squirel guy, a bird guy, a toad guy, a rhino guy, a possum guy....that's it - and of course the pallet swaps...A quirky concept a good game does not make! There should be some fun gameplay somewhere in the whole mess.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Chroma SquadThere is alot going on with Chroma Squad but I'll keep it short...some areas of the game are very very very good...and some awful.Let's start off with the good, Chroma Squad is a hybrid between simulation and turn based strategy. It sounds complicated, but they kept those two elements at the simplist form. So,  the developers pulled it off nicely.  I played on the easiest difficulty because I am atrocious at both genres, but this title kept me interested.  There are a few branching storyline choices to choose from, so that's a plus as well.The storyline is hit or miss...so I'll try to keep the spoilers to a bare minimum. Note the word try:If you read the description, if Chroma Squad, the player runs its own Super Sentai studio/show.  The actors who decide to start their own show are all best friends who got tired of their former show's director. So the player runs the studio, and the action(Turn based strategy) is the episode being filmed. I wish it was that simple.  It begins to get confusing, because everyone begins breaking the 4th wall(from the show to their audience), sometimes the actors don't know if what's happening while on set is scripted or really happening, and then soon they begin to 'Morph'/Transform for real and fight real battles while its still being filmed.(In other words, the actors became real super heroes and saved the world). I sometimes got mixed up with what is real or what isn't real.  At one point, a developer comes on screen and tells the actors its all just a game and he made a glitch by mistake, is that the 5th wall being broken????The gameplay was fantastic, and the retro style graphics were beautiful too.  I liked the idea of naming my studio and all the catch phrases, so the only thing I didn't like was the story, I pretty much hated it.  I wish it was either one or the other, either a Super Sentai game(Where I name the characters, catchphrases, customize colors/armor), or the same studio simulation/turn based strategy where it was kept JUST A TV SHOW without a confusing storyline.6.5/10I know alot of people love the story, and that's okay.  It just wasn't for me.
