Posted: December 30, 2015
												I wanted to like this game. The concept of former stuntmen making their own TV studio that you control mixed in with strategy RPG combat was a fresh idea in a landscape full of zombie survival games and minecraft clones. But having just finished the game, it failed to deliver on so many levels.PROS:- Great overall concept.  Run a TV studio while having your stuntment meet certain criteria in strategy RPG battles.- The art style is interesting and has character.  The costumes pay homage to the various costumes seen in shows like Power Rangers.- The music works well enough for what it is.CONS:- The studio management aspect of the game is very under developed.  Most of the choices, from the type of camera you use to the marketing agency that you hire, are shallow and don't offer more than slight bonuses here and there.  For example, you can have your marketing agency put up your actors for an award, but all that will do is increase your fan power, which is used to activate marketing agency policies.- Objectives in battle could have been more varied.  As it is, there are 3 primary objectives that you'll see:  1. Kill X amount of enemies, maybe with Y time; 2. Kill the boss with a team member/team attack/finishing move; 3.  Keep everyone alive/above 50% health.   This is disappointing because, being a TV show that you make, you could have gone with more interesting objectives, especially if you the player could set them.- The writing is not very good.  The story seems to be unsure on whether it wants to play a particular scene straight or comically, and so flip flops between the two extremes awkwardly.  In addition, the story progression is very clunky and poorly executed.- The game is unfunny.  Most of the "humor" comes from blatant references to pop culture outside of the genre (such as a Robocop/Tiger hybrid.  That's it, that's the joke), with a smattering of poorly constructed puns to tie it all together.- The localization is not very good.  The game was clearly translated by somebody that does not have very good command of the English language, as much of the text and dialogue just reads wrong to a native English speaker.  Getting a decent writer would fix this and some of the previous issue.

Posted: March 15, 2016
												Normally I'm fairly good at knowing which games I'll enjoy, and this is one of those rare exceptions that I was completely wrong with how I'd react. Halfway through the third act, I found myself floored, how could I not know that a tiny top down team tactics game would be drastically improved with the guise of recklessly cheap 90s nostalgia? For me, this game is like a restaurant, that I ate at for years- to the point where I got physically ill anytime you thought of it. It is this eatery, but years later, when I found out the chef has been indicted for serving criminally poor quality meals, and in some robust campaign I found myself back there, with a free meal coupon, and the new chef personally going out of their way to try and regain my patronage. It takes content from my childhood and under the guise of pointed satire, allowed me to appreciate the beauty of chintzy theatrics.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												While it's not the Power Rangers game of my dreams, I found a lot to like about Chroma Squad. I was originally turned off when I found out it was about running a TV show and not actually being Power Rangers, but it actually works. It's full of all the cheesy lines and scenarios fans of the old Power Rangers seasons will like, and people who have stuck with the show can appreciate the love and knowledge of the franchise and it's tropes went into this game. I'm not particularly a fan of strategy games and I'm not really good at them, so I found this game pretty difficult on normal, but fans of the genre might find it too easy. Still, I really enjoyed all of the customization, the multiple storylines, and found the game overall to very enjoyable.

Posted: August 15, 2015
												I feel rather disappointed in that I was unaware of this game until long after the Kickstater was met. I'm a fan of sentai series, both american and japanese versions, and I see a lot of genuine love and effort put forth in the game to show off the themes, corny messages & jokes, and tropes that those shows fall into. With that, however, a love of those fanchises is felt through the effort and minor details scattered in the stages, dialogue, and backgrounds. For instance, the statue of JAKQ's 'Big One' in the convention stage or the reference to Doggie Kruger in one of the post-stage tweets. What about the game play? Well, it plays like the tactical RPGs I love (FF Tactics, Disgaea) while still have it's own take and original elements to it. I do wish there was a big more clarity in know what can and can't be done. For example, I didn't know until Episode 3 that I could customize more then the chest of my mech by clicking on the seperate parts. There are some small nuances in the game like that that take me out of the game for a moment as I may have spent my materials differently. Better explanation on fan or income conversion may be nice as well. Overall, I'm very happy with this game and pray the studio learn from this and make their next game bigger and better.

Posted: July 19, 2015
												Buy it. You don't need a review from me. Wait, you do? Well... alright then.Pros:+The dialouge: It's just amazing how many jokes they can state considering the setting is litterally being an indie studio group filming power rangers.+Stradegy: There's a good amount of it. I'm basing it off of just finishing Season 1, but basically you are given director tasks to appease audience, such as defeating X amount of Y monsters in Z amount of turns, or pulling off finishers on bosses which are very satisfying (when you Chromatize)+ THE MUSIC: My lord is this the best soundtrack I've heard in a long time. Kudos to the music makers for making such an amazing soundtrack (looking at you A little break from saving the world)+ Graphics: The graphics is a very vast and colorful pixelated style, and it's very appeasing to the eyes+ Fan System: Considering it's about an indie group trying to run a show, fans play a major role. They determine how much money you get, and that money goes to upgrading equipment which is the only way (as far as I can tell) to increase your stats.Cons:-Crafting Equipment: I'm not knocking off the crafting system, I like it. The only thing that pesters me is that you don't get to see the stat increase or decrease until after you craft it, and once you craft it, you have to hope it does increases with hopefully small decrease in other stats, otherwise you have to recycle it and so far my rng of recycling has been pretty poop.-Options Menu: Totalbiscuit would probably sue me for doing this since that's his thing.. but the option system is kind of lacking. Sure the requirements would allow even my pc which is viewed as being powered by a potatoe could play it, but the resolutions are kind of hard to navigate and change.. for some reason, you have to let the game go full screen, change the resolution (for me I had to click alot to figure out how to make the slider work), then uncheck full screen, and then it'll save the resolution you want (though for those that play full screen all the time it might not be a problem). But hey at least it has a seperate audio slider for both volume and sfx. ^^That's about it. The cool thing is that the company is now doing the long task of fixing many bugs... so it's good that they'll keep updating this game. Heck there's even a button to report bugs. So because of that, so will this reveiw if more changes for the better (or worst) occurs.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												This game was really fun, and it taught me the about the power of friendship and teamwork. It is a great tribute to the Power Rangers and all Sentai, but also stands on its own as a turn based strategy.The game is very satirical and at times a bit meta, but it's just to keep things light hearted. I had so much fun crafting new armor and weapons to go along with each team members powers (which get cooler every season you beat). There are plenty of spelling errors, bad grammar and bad puns. You will also find yourself in stereotypical locations and plot devices from the series such as "The Park" or "ranger feels bad for hurting the groups feelings somehow".I only wish the game was harder. On Interesting difficulty I never lost a ground battle, and I only repeated a few Mecha battles (yes of course there is a giant robot) because I hadn't figured out the crafting system yet.Overall great game, 9/10

Posted: June 8, 2015
												8/10"Great gameplay along with nostalgic references, couple of tweeks to mecha combat needed and more diverse storylines wouldnt hurt"I picked this game up based on the theme and overall design and i am so glad i did! Brilliant references to 90's culture and an interesting tactical RPG combat system make this game very enjoyable. The scenario is you are stunt performers of a super sentai show who decide to make it on your own by kickstarting your own, the plot then twists from what is a tv show with stunt actors to then turn into something alot more real. The game gives you full control over your cast, studio and many other things which makes this game very interesting and different from the norm. With your team of 5 unique classes you can take down foes with a variety of unique moves or work together and form devastating combo attacks. The fact each character is a certain class is a great idea keeping you thinking about what form of attack you will make that will benefit the battle in the long run. Your characters strengths can also be upgraded with an interesting upgrade system, with a shop you can spend program revenue with to buy stronger equipment or a crafting system in which you can create equipment with drops or purchased materials to help make your characters or mecha stronger. As far as the mecha is concerned it is perhaps the weakest part of this brilliant title, although it feels incredible the first couple of times it happens the tactical tile RPG suddenly turns into a 2D fighting mechanic that feels as though it relies on luck far too often. Your accuracy ratio reduces the number of successful hits you make in the same turn, there were times however where i would hit once have an 85% hit chance and miss finishing my combo. i understand it can happen sometimes but it happened alot more than it probably should have. It made it more frustrating given the fact the enemy monster had the same attack pattern which never missed and then could also do a super attack every few turns made some of these duels long, repetitive and rather frustrating. I feel if the mecha combat was still a tile combat system where you fight in the city it could be made a lot more interesting, whats to say your viewer rating could go down based on the number of detroyed buildings via combat, or using the environment to your advantage. It would certainly make the currently bland mecha combat into something a bit more interesting. The story structure is set in a number of series in which the goal is to increase your fanbase and revenue by putting on an awesome show. You are also in charge of advertising and the studio which can be upgraded to help with the show. The idea of seperate series is great and makes the game into more bitesize chuncks that open up possibilities of extra content later on. With multiple endings the game does have replay value and the episodes in each season can be played in any order desired. The enemy designs are fantastic and some of the stories are great but perhaps more of a mixup with different scenarios would only benefit the game more, party members could be missing or sub objectives could be more diverse with perhaps saving civilians or dealing with environmental scenarios. This does happen sometimes but maybe not enough.The soundtrack is a pleasure to listen to and keeps the tempo going. it plays very well along with the artistic style of the game.Overall the game is a great experience, especially if you are a power rangers/super sentai fan with some great story and combat design and an interesting yet simple upgrade system and tle based RPG combat. More diverse storylines and some work on the mecha battles would only do this game good! If they bring out more content as well this game could be played long into the future.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												Time to save the world with mild Gymnastics. Chroma Squad is about a small team of stunt men that get sick of thier old boss and deside to start their own Power Rangers like show. The gameplay has you using five different squad members in a grid based arena fighting some waves on enemies and a boss. The game's main difficulty is based on if you choose to the the mission objectives, from hit the boss every turn, win in 5 turns, or finish the boss with a finisher. The game is filled with references that just comes and goes from video games, to pop culture the games has cheesy diologue. The crafting system is somewhat of a mess so I just stick to the shop. Posted: May 3, 2015
												Chroma Squad is an outstanding tactical RPG that I highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and a ton of other live action hero shows. The game clocks in about 15 hours (give or take) to complete one play through and is loaded with a ton of fan service and pop culture references that keep you constantly hyped and laughing throughout your journey. The blend of simulation and RPG is where the game truly shines and feels unique. You aren't only creating your dream Sentai team, you are a part of the show!On the tactical side, the game does not get very complex, and I found the game to be quite a breeze on Normal, but honestly, that's okay. A game does not need to be hard as hell in order to be fun. However, I will note that as hype as the Mecha battles are they are pretty one sided and easy to complete most of the time. From the perspective of a fan of Sentai it makes total sense and you feel awesome beating up Kaiju for the sake of justice, but the above mentioned simplicity is why I couldn't recommend the game to someone just looking for a Tactical RPG fix. Though I would say at the very least look up some footage and if you are open minded enough you might really enjoy it anyways! Might even get you interested into Sentai etc.Chroma Squad as it is may have relatively simple combat, crafting and business simulation but I strongly feel like that's the entire point of the game. The game doesn't just want you to create a Sentai show, it wants you to be the hero! So what are you waiting for? Get out there and deliver some justice! And don't forget to shout a cheesy line like "Justice is best served in a rainbow of colors!" It doesn't have to make sense, as long as you do a cool pose while saying it you'll be FINE.Pros•	High replayability•	Fan service...fan service everywhere!•	Incredible soundtrack•	Amazing retro graphicsCons•	Individual aspects of the game are simple•	Left me begging for more customization. (perhaps we might see more in updates)•	A few annoying bugs, but patches should be coming in quite soon9/10

												This game was really fun, and it taught me the about the power of friendship and teamwork. It is a great tribute to the Power Rangers and all Sentai, but also stands on its own as a turn based strategy.The game is very satirical and at times a bit meta, but it's just to keep things light hearted. I had so much fun crafting new armor and weapons to go along with each team members powers (which get cooler every season you beat). There are plenty of spelling errors, bad grammar and bad puns. You will also find yourself in stereotypical locations and plot devices from the series such as "The Park" or "ranger feels bad for hurting the groups feelings somehow".I only wish the game was harder. On Interesting difficulty I never lost a ground battle, and I only repeated a few Mecha battles (yes of course there is a giant robot) because I hadn't figured out the crafting system yet.Overall great game, 9/10

												Well I don't know HOW nor WHY i love this game....but i do... You may be wondering: Why would you hate this game? Well it's not the power ranger theme cause i loved the show when i was a kid; no it's the fact i hate, and i mean "hate with a burning passion that wishes the genre to die out and never return" hate, tile based stratagy games...but when i played this...when i started playing Chroma Squad...something was VERY different. The fights never over stay their welcome in the easy mode, the challenge of the higher difficulties are fairly noticable (though they need to stop fixing what was already a good game), and it's just fun to make up your own power rangers team name and special lines. the upgrading system is all based on the items you buy or craft so you be really tanky or deal ALL the damage. my only issue is the craftable armours and weapons aren't as good as the shop items thanks to RNG-ness deciding if the weapon has an attack buff at all and lator shop items tend to be weaker in weapon but not in attack base making more about using your basic attack then anything else but it's sad saying even THAT is better then hoping to get a good weapon via craft... It's a great game despite that and for someone who hates "Move guy to enemy to attack them" styled fights that's saying something!

Posted: June 8, 2015
												8/10"Great gameplay along with nostalgic references, couple of tweeks to mecha combat needed and more diverse storylines wouldnt hurt"I picked this game up based on the theme and overall design and i am so glad i did! Brilliant references to 90's culture and an interesting tactical RPG combat system make this game very enjoyable. The scenario is you are stunt performers of a super sentai show who decide to make it on your own by kickstarting your own, the plot then twists from what is a tv show with stunt actors to then turn into something alot more real. The game gives you full control over your cast, studio and many other things which makes this game very interesting and different from the norm. With your team of 5 unique classes you can take down foes with a variety of unique moves or work together and form devastating combo attacks. The fact each character is a certain class is a great idea keeping you thinking about what form of attack you will make that will benefit the battle in the long run. Your characters strengths can also be upgraded with an interesting upgrade system, with a shop you can spend program revenue with to buy stronger equipment or a crafting system in which you can create equipment with drops or purchased materials to help make your characters or mecha stronger. As far as the mecha is concerned it is perhaps the weakest part of this brilliant title, although it feels incredible the first couple of times it happens the tactical tile RPG suddenly turns into a 2D fighting mechanic that feels as though it relies on luck far too often. Your accuracy ratio reduces the number of successful hits you make in the same turn, there were times however where i would hit once have an 85% hit chance and miss finishing my combo. i understand it can happen sometimes but it happened alot more than it probably should have. It made it more frustrating given the fact the enemy monster had the same attack pattern which never missed and then could also do a super attack every few turns made some of these duels long, repetitive and rather frustrating. I feel if the mecha combat was still a tile combat system where you fight in the city it could be made a lot more interesting, whats to say your viewer rating could go down based on the number of detroyed buildings via combat, or using the environment to your advantage. It would certainly make the currently bland mecha combat into something a bit more interesting. The story structure is set in a number of series in which the goal is to increase your fanbase and revenue by putting on an awesome show. You are also in charge of advertising and the studio which can be upgraded to help with the show. The idea of seperate series is great and makes the game into more bitesize chuncks that open up possibilities of extra content later on. With multiple endings the game does have replay value and the episodes in each season can be played in any order desired. The enemy designs are fantastic and some of the stories are great but perhaps more of a mixup with different scenarios would only benefit the game more, party members could be missing or sub objectives could be more diverse with perhaps saving civilians or dealing with environmental scenarios. This does happen sometimes but maybe not enough.The soundtrack is a pleasure to listen to and keeps the tempo going. it plays very well along with the artistic style of the game.Overall the game is a great experience, especially if you are a power rangers/super sentai fan with some great story and combat design and an interesting yet simple upgrade system and tle based RPG combat. More diverse storylines and some work on the mecha battles would only do this game good! If they bring out more content as well this game could be played long into the future.

Posted: May 27, 2015
												Summary: The game is great only hindered by some difficulty issues and minor bugs. The games story and graphics are fantastic. Upgrading is satisfying and also takes a lot of thinking. Combat takes strategy and is near flawless, for the most part aside from the Mech battles difficulty spike.Lengthy-er Review: Combat is great, it takes a lot of strategy of what combinations of teamwork, and skills to boost your audience meter. The game lets you customize what your squads name is, transforming motto, and actor names. This makes the game feel way more your own and adds a lot of depth. The story is silly and over-the-top enough to feel very Sentai-like. The "hub" where you buy upgrades and items is another fantastic aspect of the game. Buying new items and mech parts, along with buying new marketers who can bring you special benefits depending on which person you sign a contract with. Replying to fan emails was also a joy to do. Now onto the cons. Mech fights are incredibly challenging even on normal mode, it took me NUMEROUS times to defeat most makes in the final 2 seasons. Mech fights also lack strategy and ends up mostly being dependent on luck. For example, for each punch you start off around 90% chance to hit, then goes down to around 80% for the next punch, and so on. Problem is healing skills require you to get around a 4x combo of punches to do any real healing, and so does the +Def move. It is nearly impossible to get consistent 4x combo, myself rarely even getting 3x combos. Even with that decent sized flaw it doesn't take away too much from the game, it is still fantastic and charming. All the pro's easily out weigh the cons.Rating: 9/10

Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game may have been released too soon. Once it's fully bug tested and no longer freezes during the interminably long last mission (which I finished after 7 attempts and two weeks), this game is a 4/5. As it stands, with these glitches, it's a 2/5. Positives:- The idea is well thought out and utilized. - The main RPG game is fun and entertaining, and fairly deep. - The fourth wall breaks and overall sense of humor are fun. - Customization- you can change your team's name and their various battle cries. These make the in game dialogue awesome at times. (No, Bill, of course you're as important as anyone else in Sakura and the Rest!) I'd like more costume choices, but what's there is fine. Negatives:- The mecha missions are incredibly dull, since it always comes down to the same exact fight (punch punch punch punch special. Click to lesson damage. Click to lessen damage. Click to lessen damage. Punch punch punch punch block.) A few of the enemies have very slow animation that makes the battles even MORE interminable, especially the Barney parody. I changed the mecha summoning catch phrase to "Let's Get This Over With!" I seriously dreaded them every time. - Glitches. These are the game's current biggest issue. They seem to be clearing up, but they kept me from finishing the last mission for two weeks, which destroyed the game's momentum and my interest in pursuing the other alternate endings. Buyer beware. - The last mission. There's a plot twist in that last mission that changes who the villain is that makes it less satisfying. I didn't get the final battle I REALLY wanted. Overall, this game is a lot of fun and incredibly imaginative. Once it's fully polished, I recommend it. Just check out the community board before buying and make sure that things have been cleared up.

Posted: May 3, 2015
												Ever want to make pretend and create your own 'Power Rangers' inspired TV show while actively fighting your way through the story? Well with Chroma Squad you get that chance! Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG inspired by the 'Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers' where you get to buy all your set equipment, outfit your heroes with new cardboard armor and weapons, and fight evil villains. All with the help and guidance of CEREBRO! (Cerebro is a floaty brain much like Zordon!) I played through the tutorial and the first "episode" of Chroma Squad and it was delightful and full of nostalgia. You are a group of stuntmen(and ladies) that leave a show much like the Power Rangers and decide to go off on your own to make your own show! So you are given access to a warehouse which you use as a studio to try and create a better show.With tactical rpg elements like upgrading your actors skills, costumes and weapons, you increase their stats like a regular rpg. However, you are creating a TV show. So you must also spend the money you earn to upgrade your studio, lighting, cameras and a number of other things.The goal here is to keep your fanbase happy and create the best show you can. Here's my first look! (Still uploading it's so fresh)


YouTube™ Video: First Look - Chroma Squad

			Chroma Squad is now available on Steam for $14.99 - http://store.steampowered.com/app/251130/ Podcast/Website - http://www.EarlyAccessPodcast.com Follow on Twitter -...		

If you are looking for a fun, saturday morning cartoon inspired tactical rpg, then Chroma Squad is on point.(I mean I know you weren't actively looking for a saturday morning cartoon inspired tactical rpg.)There is a lot to like here - great music, pixel art, and enjoyable gameplay. Posted: May 3, 2015
												Chroma Squad is an outstanding tactical RPG that I highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and a ton of other live action hero shows. The game clocks in about 15 hours (give or take) to complete one play through and is loaded with a ton of fan service and pop culture references that keep you constantly hyped and laughing throughout your journey. The blend of simulation and RPG is where the game truly shines and feels unique. You aren't only creating your dream Sentai team, you are a part of the show!On the tactical side, the game does not get very complex, and I found the game to be quite a breeze on Normal, but honestly, that's okay. A game does not need to be hard as hell in order to be fun. However, I will note that as hype as the Mecha battles are they are pretty one sided and easy to complete most of the time. From the perspective of a fan of Sentai it makes total sense and you feel awesome beating up Kaiju for the sake of justice, but the above mentioned simplicity is why I couldn't recommend the game to someone just looking for a Tactical RPG fix. Though I would say at the very least look up some footage and if you are open minded enough you might really enjoy it anyways! Might even get you interested into Sentai etc.Chroma Squad as it is may have relatively simple combat, crafting and business simulation but I strongly feel like that's the entire point of the game. The game doesn't just want you to create a Sentai show, it wants you to be the hero! So what are you waiting for? Get out there and deliver some justice! And don't forget to shout a cheesy line like "Justice is best served in a rainbow of colors!" It doesn't have to make sense, as long as you do a cool pose while saying it you'll be FINE.Pros•	High replayability•	Fan service...fan service everywhere!•	Incredible soundtrack•	Amazing retro graphicsCons•	Individual aspects of the game are simple•	Left me begging for more customization. (perhaps we might see more in updates)•	A few annoying bugs, but patches should be coming in quite soon9/10

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Third game in the series (after Knights of Pen and Paper and KoPaP2) is definitely an improvement. Nonetheless, the pacing feels slow, the character customization limited, and upon succeeding I rarely felt like I'd been particularly clever, but more that I had exploited poor AI and strange mechanics. The attempt at a humorous plot line is also incredibly painful -- as much as I wanted to like it, the writing is abysmal. That said, there are some well-done elements. Acquiring points by piling on certain mechanics (rather than by being brutally efficient in dispatching enemies) to unlock power-ups lead to some of the more interesting tactical decisions, and the crafting system occasionally presented a tough choice. In another couple games, this dev team could be the talk of indie gaming, but not yet.

Posted: November 4, 2016
												Chroma Squad is a turn-based, tactics RPG from Behold Studios. Let’s get rocking.The GoodThe Power Rangers were a huge part of my childhood. I’m not talking about the newer, crappier Power Ranger series’, I’m talking about the original that started in 93. The Red Ranger was on of my idols as a child. Chroma Squad has all the same Power Rangers vibes in all the right ways.The story is not what I expected it to be. While I was ready to dive headfirst into a tactical, turn-based Power Rnagers styled game, I was surprised to find that I was diving into a tactical, turn-based you’re playing as stuntmen filming a Power Rangers styled show game. Total curve ball. That’s what I get for not watching the trailer beforehand. I’m still trying to figure out how I missed it.Gameplay is simple, but not too simple. There’s the right amount of everything for you to take into consideration while you’re in the heat of battle.The music is great and the dialog is actually pretty funny.The BadI’ve got nothing here. Move along, please.The MehIt’s not actually the Power Rangers.Verdict: YeaIs this a game you should get? If you like turn-based tactical games, then yes. If you watched Power Rangers at any point in your life and enjoyed it, then very yes. If you can get it on sale, even better.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												A tactics game where you play as a Power Rangers TV studio. Game is split up into episodes (where you do battle) and in between episodes you spend your cash/craft upgrades. It has a silly story with silly enemies and plot. Story is mostly told through dialogue so doesn't get very deep. A lot of 'just because' reasoning so you have to go with the flow. Things that happen outside dialogue are often just quickly summed up by the narrator to set the scene. Graphics are good enough and sound fits well.Episodes are often split up into 1-3 tactics battle segments and sometimes finished off with a mecha battle. The tactics system is pretty standard and simple. There are only damage and status effects, no damage types (no physical vs magic attack, no elemental resistance/weakness). The mecha battle is a regular RPG slugfest where you take turns attacking each other. You can do multiple actions in your turn and each action builds up your combo meter (which increases the effect of your next action but decreases the accuracy). In normal mode, the enemy mecha usually just does 3 regular attacks one special attack. You reduce damage taken through a timing minigame (there's a bar that fills up, stop it at the right time and you block more damage).It feels like you want mecha battles to be over as soon as possible so it feels better to go for as many 50%+ accuracy attacks as you can rather than ever defending. It seems like enemies usually do 3 attacks of ~5k damage each and defending (maybe unless you go for max defense) only blocks a total of ~5k of that. It feels like a race against the clock so the less turns you take to defeat the mecha, the less turns the enemy has to deal 15k+ damage.However, it does get a little frustrating when you miss your 2nd attack (~85% accuracy) twice in a row, which is brutal because of your missed damage output (especially if you're holding onto your finisher for a high combo) and it means you take free rounds of damage. But I guess that's why there's the mecha audience meter (DBZ spirit bomb-esque gathering the energy of your fans). When you lose all hp in a mecha fight, your hp meter refills with audience points (though losing hp from then on doesn't seem to affect audience score later). Assumably, the more fans you have the more HP you get.In tactics battles, your performance is calculated by an audience meter which goes up through combat actions and by following the episode's director's instructions (which are bonus objectives like 'win in 5 turns' or 'keep all members above 50% health). In normal difficulty, clearing missions wasn't too hard but clearing them while following the director's instructions was sometimes pretty challenging. However, you don't need to do every instruction to max out your audience meter and it doesn't seem like failing them matters if you fill the meter anyway.Boss enemies sometimes have line attacks but they feel unpredictable. The attacks don't hit a standard grid-based area (not clean 45 degree directions) so it's more realistic but you can't tell what it'll hit. One boss has a burst aoe (starting from himself) that usually hits allies hidden behind other allies but there were rare times where it didn't (only the one in front got hit). Sometimes the cubes served as cover, sometimes his attack hit despite the cube being in the way. Maybe there is no such thing as cover and it just randomly misses without showing the 'miss' text. He burst twice in the same spot on one turn and hit 2 on the first and all 5 on the second.The only real indicator I could see of how much damage you'd do is the enemy health bar (which shows how much remaining hp would be left after the attack). It can be a little tough to see if an attack really finishes it off or if there's a pixel left. It would've been nice to see an obvious indicator (like the bar turning gray) to show the attack should finish off the opponent.Alternatively, you could check your attack stat for how much damage you'd do (only for single attacks; I'm not sure how teamwork attacks affect damage).Seems to let you retry missions relatively easily (via abandon mission) so if you like to retry there's no need to quit/restart the game. If you don't, then you can personally choose to make your own hardcore mode by accepting whatever result you get. It's pretty nice for me because you go into episodes without knowing what you're really up against so you can abandon and customize/upgrade as necessary so you can beat the mission. Also, some director's instructions (mission goals) can be ruined by unfortunate events outside your control.It allows you to fast forward through cutscenes which is very nice. However, it sometimes speeds through the first text bubble even when I didn't intentionally click or skip through. It may have captured a click several seconds before during a cutscene or something. It would be nice to also have animation speed options in settings to make quicken actions and be able to fast forward in-battle quips.[Side note: why is 'go' and 'fas' blocked by steam? Wanted to type 'go' and 'faster']Other thoughts: One tactic is to pull back and give a turn to let the enemies chase you, often clumping together for aoe skills. Audience bonuses from marketing may not count towards the audience meter cap (meaning if you max out the meter it still counts as a bonus towards the cash/fan conversion). Would be nice to have that cleared up in-game. Mostly polished but there are some quirks. Dialogue bubble gets cut off in one sewer scene, breath->breathe typo. Seems like some e-mails don't deduct the right amount of cash? I know some options say they'll cost a certain amount but are reduced but those mention it in the reply. At hotdog stand battle, it feels like there's a minion that comes in on the left side that doesn't get placed on the map? When you have a flat +fan modifier at end of battle, it still shows as per 100 in the tooltip (you have +175 fans per episode but it shows as 175 fan conversion per 100 audience) Seems like you're supposed to lose audience when a party member is downed but it either doesn't work properly (audience bar visually is reduced but actual number isn't) or there's a hidden buffer you get by overfilling the audience meter. Seems like Tammy is supposed to get into the mecha (and sometimes she teleports with the rest) but they didn't make a new cockpit image, still only 5 people. Although normally fine, sometimes I had a little visual lag/frame skips when blocking in a mecha fight, making it hard to time blocks properly.Worth a try if you like the theme (a studio making episodes of Power Rangers) and are fine with simple tactics games. I don't think I would like it as much if it were a generic tactics game (the combat system isn't very deep) but I think they play up to the theme very well. Reminds me of Punch Club (silly story, good-enough game) though I think I enjoyed this experience more.

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Wow, all I can say is "Wow!!"This game appeals to the part of me that remembers almost missing the bus often in 2nd grade trying to stay inside to watch as much Power Rangers as I could.It's a bright, more simple version of games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Ogre Tactics, etc.  You play as stun actors who after dealing with an insulting, arrogant director realize they have the passion and talent to make their own show instead of being doing the hard stunt work and letting actors soak up the screen the rest of the time.From there, you manage your own studio, making decisions about fan interaction, marketing, managing crafting materials (used for building your own costume parts as well as eventually creating your mecha suit, yeah, it's as awesome as it sounds)The game's story is clever anc cute and as of Season 3, seems to be building to more of an interesting story than I would have ever expected from what was seemingly a simple game (sure, it's got the basic tropes you've seen before, but they're done right and they provide a context that serves it's purpose and frames the fighting well)I get it. I get why the reviews are so good: great game, great exectution, interesting concept that appeals to something that was likely a part of many of our childhood's.Grab it.  I got it free from a good buddy who had an extra key from a bundle, but had I known what a true gem this is I'd have bought it up already.Seriously, get it, get it, get it, get it.  Manage your studio, prepare your mecha, and CHROMATIZE MOTHA♥♥♥♥AS!!!!

												Here is a review I wrote for the website Indie Game Source.http://indiegamesource.com/igs/reviews/chroma-squad-review-go-go-not-power-rangers-r218TL;DRPros:+Fun and flashy combat that does a nice job replicating battles from popular super sentai shows+Lighthearted and humorous writing that is appropriately cheesy and over-the-top+Bright, expressive pixel art+Overall oozes charm and nostalgia; better than the sum of it's parts and a must play for anyone who grew up watching shows like Power RangersCons:-Combat isn't particularly complex, especially the mecha segments-The same environments and director instructions are reused a bit too often; not enough variety in "episodes"-Still a number of bugs to work outUltimately, your enjoyment of the game really comes down to how much super sentai you've seen. Posted: May 13, 2015
												Chroma Squad is an amazing game where you delve into the makings of a Super Sentai studio. It's like a business tycoon, a tactical RPG, and a customization rainbow stuffed into an amazing masterpiece of a sandwich!I honestly can't remember how I stumbled across this gem, but when I saw it, I fell in love with it and I had to have it. I'm glad that I did stumble acorss this, 'cuz I've had the funnest time playing Chroma Squad, the most enjoyable game I've come across in a while. In the first week of owning it, this game was what I'd play every night if I wasn't busy. It's extremely addicting, and while the story seems to start out at a good pace, things escalate quickly later on, providing great plot twists that keep the story immensely interesting.With those opening comments out of the way, let's list the pros and cons.Pros:~A great level of customization with a plethora of actors, colors, and equipment to choose from, heck, even the mechs have a good level of customization.~A great soundtrack. I persoanlly am a big fan of the 8-bit/chiptune style of music, it reminds of the days of arcades and gameboys. Any chiptune lover would listen to the soundtrack over and over again. If you like the music, get the reasonably priced soundtrack. Not only does it help support the devs, but you get to listen to your favorite groovy tunes from the game anytime you want.~Cool graphics. if you like these kinds of pixely games or pixel art in general, this is a game for you.~The storyline. I've said it before: It's interesting with a great pace.~The play time. It took me about 22 hours to get through my first playthrough of the game, on the normal difficulty setting. And that's just for one of 3 endings that the game has to offer. Depending on the difficlty level you're playing and the time spent jamming out to the music, the time to get all the endings can range from 50 hours to 70 hours. Great amount of gameplay.~The achievements. There's not hundreds of them like their are in other games, and most of them are pretty easy to get, you just need to play the game accordingly. I got over half the achievements on my first playthrough. (Though I guess they could add some ones in the future that require DLC.) If you're not an achievement hunter, that's all right, it could just be a fun side quest. This game has enough play-achievement balance that you don't need to dedicate hundreds of hours to get all of them.~Difficalty settings. This is always a great feature to have in a game. The difficulties are casual, interesting, and challenging, ehich translates to easy, normal, hard respectively. If you're new to this type of game and/or want to focus on the story, play the game on casual. If you've played these games before and like a nice balance of story and challenge, interesting's your cuppa joe. If you like a challenge, like good planning, and you aren't afraid to lose a little to win a little, challenging is just the right fit.~Nice balance of battle and management. Not only do you fight with your heroes, you need to check and maintain their gear in order to beat the enemies that get more difficult as time progresses, as well as answer emails from fans, manage production companies, and upgrade your small warehouse studio as time goes on.~A great price. This game is relatively well priced, and will provide hours of fun and enjoyment that for most of you will be the best entertainment you've had in a while. At 15 American dollars for the game, with 5 additional for the soundtrack DLC, 20 dollars is a great price for this game. (Without DLC, the game is about 10 British pounds, 13 with DLC, for those of you in the UK)Cons:~Though the customization is great, it would be a little better if there was more actors to choose form to play your characters.~Though it has a great storyline, playing it for the second time, at first, can seem kind of repetitive, and I found it hard to emotionally invest myself into the second set of characters. If you feel the same way, I advise taking a break for a month or two, so the shine of this game doesn't get burnt out.~Dr. Mi ahOtherwise, this is a great game, and if you were a fan of the Power Rangers when you were a kid, you're going to love this, although prior association is not required for this to be a great game. I personally thought ths was an amazing game.I give Chroma Squad a 9.7/10Happy Chromatizing!

Posted: May 24, 2015
												For 15 or even 30 bones, you really can't do much better than Chroma Squad. Even if Power Rangers (or Super Sentai if you INSIST) isn't necessarily your jam, it hits all the right notes for making a good gaming experience through that Triple-A seems to have forgotten; It's fun. Fun. You remember that? You know, when you get giggles or smile? When you get drawn into the experience not because of the spectacle, but because the game directly involves you and lets you make it your own, that's how you make games fun.Throwing down on some details, here's some specifics of why it's already made my top ten for 2015 --Turn-Based strategy, not RPG. Think XCOM: EU, but with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Power Rangers.-Customisation and upgrades for pretty much EVERYTHING.-Resource management that's more give-take than just your standard subtraction. It reminds me a lot of how the economy worked in Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries, a type of economy system I feel got left by the wayside in favour of simpler/easier things that don't add any weight to your decisions.-Crafting, a system that is notorious for earning my ire by basically being utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t roughly a million per-cent of the time, actually makes some sort of sense in how components are named/what goes into what. It's also not needlessly complicated, which is a gigantic tick in my "yes" box.-It's got good moments of humour in it. It's not a comedy game, per se, but it knows not to take itself too seriously, and the humour it employs has a nice spectrum, from subtle pointing out of tropes, tongue-in-cheek, to bad puns, to breaking the fourth wall, and even some nice.... "meta" moments.-The art is nicely done, and consistent. While I can't say I have any particular love for the "retro" style that just about every indie game is doing, this one has really nicely animated sprites with a lot of good character to them as well as fun and well-done environments.In conclusion, if you're one of those indie-game wads that just can't get enough of retro-styled graphics, crafting and whatever, you should have already creamed your free-trade, locally sourced shorts just by looking at the game's trailer. But even if you're not, this is definitely a game worth playing if you just want to have some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun playing games for once.

Posted: May 31, 2015
												If you had even a passing interest in Power Rangers as a kid, you'll get a kick out of this, even more so with the fact that you can tweak your team from the start by changing their names, appearances (or even, in some cases, race) and suit color to add your own personal flavor. I spent a good ten minutes trying to come up with my own team name and catch-phrases. The tactical RPG aspects are simple and enjoyable, and I like a more streamlined approach to gearing the squad. What I really love about the game, though, is its consistent charm; from my characters yelling my ridiculous catch-phrases, to the Assist character constantly using emoji's in dialogue, to some of the ridiculous bosses you face (shout-out to Transitmancer), I often had a wide grin on my face while playing.As for gripes, well, the Kaiju battles got repetitive; spam Punch until you were at about 60% accuracy then pop Defense, Defend self against enemy's attacks, repeat. It'll probably be harder on higher difficulties, but I found myself getting somewhat bored during a battle between a GIANT ROBOT AND A GIANT MONSTER. Also, there were a couple bosses who kept doing knockback abilities that kept me from doing a Finishing Move, which happened to be a side-objective for that Episode, so I spent maybe twenty minutes trying to get into the correct position.That said, though, this is perfectly viable nostalgia fuel that manages to be fun, engaging and lets you have a beaver on your superhero team. Sheer brilliance.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Overall: 9/10Combat:  8/10:  Combat system consists of move and attack phase with the additional options to go into teamwork mode or use free actions.  You gain audience members as you defeat badguys, achieve mission objectives, and do special moves or use teamwork.  The common enemies are just that - common, you will see the same enemies throughout the game though they upgrade in power and stats (as do you).  The bosses are great, as with most of the game they are made with humor and they have unique skills and play styles.  There is another type of combat you go into, I dont want to spoil it but if you watched power rangers you probably know what it is.  Generally this mode of combat has you fighting and gaining combos which power up special moves.  During the enemy attack phase you play a mini game where you try to click at the right moment to minimize damage.  I give combat 8/10 because the difficulty scales weird.  I felt underpowered initially but by midway into the game I was stomping on most missions.K I'll finish this review later I gtg for now.  My Truly Honest Opinion: Get this game, you won't regret it.  It doesn't matter if you're a 90's kid or if you watched power rangers (though it makes it all the more better),  if you did not get any of its references or jokes I still feel this game is solid and worth the 15 dollars.

Posted: May 27, 2015
												I was really hesitant at first to purchase this game because of the lackluster look to combat but damn, the power rangers/super sentai theme just won me over. I've watched every episode of power rangers and most of super sentai. With that said, the thematic elements are spot on. The way the dialogue is corny and the team up moves are all taken from power rangers and i love every single second of it.As for the turn based strategy, the game is pretty fun. While other games like Fire Emblem or FF tactics have more interesting and robust systems, the combat elements in this game are still fun. Complexity doesnt always mean fun game play. The RPG elements are also very interesting. I was surprised to see that this game has a development strategy portion similar to that of the kariosoft games. Overall, highly recommend this game if your a power rangers/super sentai fan. For rpg/tactics fans, I would say it's less complicated and interesting the other games in the genere , but the combat is still fun.

Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game may have been released too soon. Once it's fully bug tested and no longer freezes during the interminably long last mission (which I finished after 7 attempts and two weeks), this game is a 4/5. As it stands, with these glitches, it's a 2/5. Positives:- The idea is well thought out and utilized. - The main RPG game is fun and entertaining, and fairly deep. - The fourth wall breaks and overall sense of humor are fun. - Customization- you can change your team's name and their various battle cries. These make the in game dialogue awesome at times. (No, Bill, of course you're as important as anyone else in Sakura and the Rest!) I'd like more costume choices, but what's there is fine. Negatives:- The mecha missions are incredibly dull, since it always comes down to the same exact fight (punch punch punch punch special. Click to lesson damage. Click to lessen damage. Click to lessen damage. Punch punch punch punch block.) A few of the enemies have very slow animation that makes the battles even MORE interminable, especially the Barney parody. I changed the mecha summoning catch phrase to "Let's Get This Over With!" I seriously dreaded them every time. - Glitches. These are the game's current biggest issue. They seem to be clearing up, but they kept me from finishing the last mission for two weeks, which destroyed the game's momentum and my interest in pursuing the other alternate endings. Buyer beware. - The last mission. There's a plot twist in that last mission that changes who the villain is that makes it less satisfying. I didn't get the final battle I REALLY wanted. Overall, this game is a lot of fun and incredibly imaginative. Once it's fully polished, I recommend it. Just check out the community board before buying and make sure that things have been cleared up.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Chroma Squad is an amazing game where you delve into the makings of a Super Sentai studio. It's like a business tycoon, a tactical RPG, and a customization rainbow stuffed into an amazing masterpiece of a sandwich!I honestly can't remember how I stumbled across this gem, but when I saw it, I fell in love with it and I had to have it. I'm glad that I did stumble acorss this, 'cuz I've had the funnest time playing Chroma Squad, the most enjoyable game I've come across in a while. In the first week of owning it, this game was what I'd play every night if I wasn't busy. It's extremely addicting, and while the story seems to start out at a good pace, things escalate quickly later on, providing great plot twists that keep the story immensely interesting.With those opening comments out of the way, let's list the pros and cons.Pros:~A great level of customization with a plethora of actors, colors, and equipment to choose from, heck, even the mechs have a good level of customization.~A great soundtrack. I persoanlly am a big fan of the 8-bit/chiptune style of music, it reminds of the days of arcades and gameboys. Any chiptune lover would listen to the soundtrack over and over again. If you like the music, get the reasonably priced soundtrack. Not only does it help support the devs, but you get to listen to your favorite groovy tunes from the game anytime you want.~Cool graphics. if you like these kinds of pixely games or pixel art in general, this is a game for you.~The storyline. I've said it before: It's interesting with a great pace.~The play time. It took me about 22 hours to get through my first playthrough of the game, on the normal difficulty setting. And that's just for one of 3 endings that the game has to offer. Depending on the difficlty level you're playing and the time spent jamming out to the music, the time to get all the endings can range from 50 hours to 70 hours. Great amount of gameplay.~The achievements. There's not hundreds of them like their are in other games, and most of them are pretty easy to get, you just need to play the game accordingly. I got over half the achievements on my first playthrough. (Though I guess they could add some ones in the future that require DLC.) If you're not an achievement hunter, that's all right, it could just be a fun side quest. This game has enough play-achievement balance that you don't need to dedicate hundreds of hours to get all of them.~Difficalty settings. This is always a great feature to have in a game. The difficulties are casual, interesting, and challenging, ehich translates to easy, normal, hard respectively. If you're new to this type of game and/or want to focus on the story, play the game on casual. If you've played these games before and like a nice balance of story and challenge, interesting's your cuppa joe. If you like a challenge, like good planning, and you aren't afraid to lose a little to win a little, challenging is just the right fit.~Nice balance of battle and management. Not only do you fight with your heroes, you need to check and maintain their gear in order to beat the enemies that get more difficult as time progresses, as well as answer emails from fans, manage production companies, and upgrade your small warehouse studio as time goes on.~A great price. This game is relatively well priced, and will provide hours of fun and enjoyment that for most of you will be the best entertainment you've had in a while. At 15 American dollars for the game, with 5 additional for the soundtrack DLC, 20 dollars is a great price for this game. (Without DLC, the game is about 10 British pounds, 13 with DLC, for those of you in the UK)Cons:~Though the customization is great, it would be a little better if there was more actors to choose form to play your characters.~Though it has a great storyline, playing it for the second time, at first, can seem kind of repetitive, and I found it hard to emotionally invest myself into the second set of characters. If you feel the same way, I advise taking a break for a month or two, so the shine of this game doesn't get burnt out.~Dr. Mi ahOtherwise, this is a great game, and if you were a fan of the Power Rangers when you were a kid, you're going to love this, although prior association is not required for this to be a great game. I personally thought ths was an amazing game.I give Chroma Squad a 9.7/10Happy Chromatizing!

Posted: May 12, 2015
												Here is a review I wrote for the website Indie Game Source.http://indiegamesource.com/igs/reviews/chroma-squad-review-go-go-not-power-rangers-r218TL;DRPros:+Fun and flashy combat that does a nice job replicating battles from popular super sentai shows+Lighthearted and humorous writing that is appropriately cheesy and over-the-top+Bright, expressive pixel art+Overall oozes charm and nostalgia; better than the sum of it's parts and a must play for anyone who grew up watching shows like Power RangersCons:-Combat isn't particularly complex, especially the mecha segments-The same environments and director instructions are reused a bit too often; not enough variety in "episodes"-Still a number of bugs to work outUltimately, your enjoyment of the game really comes down to how much super sentai you've seen. The game relies a lot on Power Rangers nostalgia and poking fun at the genre's various quirks and tropes.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Finally finished the game (after having to re-start because my previous save bugged out due to having start a day before official release). I cannot wait to start doing this game over again (likely with a different path and a new ending) for my Drunk Play channel.The sound, the game play, the nostalgia. All very good.Only negative thing I'd point out is how the crafting system is now 100% random. You can't go to the store and buy crafting materials to get the crafted items you want. Now you buy a box of random items and if you're not lucky, you could end up never being able to craft better items (or at least Season level items) to up your game for the next battle. Can get a little bit annoying. But you should end up doing just fine in the end.TenNaddaTen. Will save the world again.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												This is a nice little game that will keep you busy for about 15-20 hours. I really liked knights of pen and paper (my avatar is from that game) for its graphics and casual game style, and also enjoyed the overall foreign feel with bad grammar and jokes that don't always translate perfectly. This game is sort of the same, but is more linear and less compelling to replay.As someone growing up watching the power rangers I wanted to go back to some of those cheesy moments and the game really delivers, including the repetitive unispiring boss fights in the form of a minigame. The plot is overall nice and somewhat reminds me of their other work, and there's a nice fast forward effect to skip through the story. TBH I skipped through most of the ending just to finish playing.I will probably return to this game when a major update is declared and overall don't regret buying it on sale. Thanks Devs for the time put in to writing and styling this!

Posted: February 17, 2016
												Simple Turn-based tactics RPG that brings in a few unique mechanics to the genre.Gameplay straddles a fine line between making things intuitive but not too simple while giving you just enough but not too much stuff to play around with. The crafting system is multiple layers of RNG buggery and it leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth sometimes.  You can work around it but meh.The pacing is fairly on point and the game never really overstays its welcome.There are Super Robot Fights, though it's easily the weakest part of the game currently.  They're also gathering feedback and have announced an overhaul, so this point may become moot in a couple of months.Aesthetics are colorful with a strong indie feel (it's an indie, kickstarted game so yeah).  16 bit and the like.The writing assumes that you've watched at least 2-3 episodes of power rangers and have a passing knowledge of certain internet memes that came out within a specific timeframe (I had to google a couple things).  I enjoyed it.  It has the right kind of corn and ham that'll get me to sensibly chuckle most of the time.and again, the pacing is pretty strong despite the source material.I highly recommend configuring your super sentai team away from the defaults to fit your preferences as it can greatly improve your gameplay experience.  My team was called the Rude Rollers, they Rolled Out, and my robot was named Pablo Escobar (he shanked giant monsters).A single run may take like 6-8 hours and there are multiple endings.

Posted: February 13, 2016
												The game far exceded my expectations.I don't need to tell you about the graphics, either you like the chosen style or you don't. FWIW I think they did a great job of having consistent high-quality pixel art. The sound track is great too!Story is good, has multiple endings (and the game play is good enough to go through and get them all), good humor, and if you are there just for the tactics, there is a fast-forward though the dialogue.Game play is excellent.When I first recieved this game my expectations were that it would be good, but not great, but I figured I might as well give it a try, since I got it.  My intent was to play for just half an hour before bed, since I had to get up early the next day.  The next time i had bothered to look at a clock, nearly four hours had passed. I'll take the old addage about time flying as objective evidence that the game is fun as heck. Since building my new gaming rig, I have actually played it more than any other game.The game is not perfect.  I have encounted a few bugs (nothing that made it crash, and any complicated software will end up with at least one small bug.)The games i play over multiple times is limited, this one easily made the short list.You don't have to be a fan of any of the tv shows that inspired the game, or particularly fond of turnbased strategy games to find the game enjoyable. The hard difficuly offers a challenge and rewards a strategical approach, medium is more forgiving. It is a game that i think is accessible to a wide audience. For its target audience it offers nostolgia, but It is not inappropriate for younger audiencies and gameplay is approachable to anyone.

												That was 20 hours that I don't regret. Creating your own "power-rangers"-team, and playing them through meta-scenarios while making a studio and buying plastic swords was a great ride. Because I named all my characters after friends, the banter ended up being eerily similar to if I had written it myself, which was great. Tactical turn based fighting is fun, and the added focus on teamwork and stunts on partners made it even better. I would have loved even more characters to play through the game with, and even more weapons and gear to craft and buy. I guess it's not too negative that I want more of what's already in the game. The pacing of seasons is a great idea and works well, allowing the game to be played in episodes or seasons if you want. I rarely complete games, but this one was fab, and I'll probably play it through at least one more time.Had been 8/10, but because the price point is what it is, given the production values, I'll put this at a 10/10. No game is perfect, and everything can be improved, but if 10 is an obtainable number, and considering the price, then yeah. One of my favourite new games.

												TLDR:Gameplay - 10Music - 10Story/Writing - 10Nostalgia - 10Chance for Enemies to Dodge Attacks - OP_____________________________________________________________________Still in "Season 1" and this game is great. My only complaint is that their hardest difficulty is too hard. There are objectives to fulfill in each mission, for example: Kill all enemies in 4 turnsAnd it feels like the enemies dodge more often on round 4 than they do the previous 3.  I've had to restart more than a handful of times because of this.Another objective might be: Kill the boss with a finishing moveWhich requires all 5 party members to be alive, so if one of your members gets KO'd then tough♥♥♥♥♥♥ Which is especially hard when the Season 1 boss has 2000HP and you hit for 60-100 each person. You can team-attack for about 400-600 but that requires all party members to be right up next to the bad guy, which sounds easy enough, but as you get hit your players get knocked back depending on where they get hit from so your players will fall out of range of team attacks.Oh, and the healer can heal allies but can't heal itself? It feels like I just have to keep restarting the mission until I get lucky enough to finally pass, which to a certain degree I can understand because I don't want my wins to be handed to me, but my tactics (in a tactical-RPG) should not be undermined by something as whimsical as ♥♥♥♥ing RNG-dodging.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												This game is adorable and feels like a SNES classic that flew under the radar. The pixel graphics are clear, well-animated, and bold, the soundtrack is super catchy, and the gameplay is fun. Most of all, it oozes flavor from everywhere, from the item descriptions, to the post-level "tweets" as a scorecard.If it has any flaw, it's that it's a bit shallow for a tactical RPG; there's a lack of class customization and enemy variety, though they cover all the bases. The mecha battles could be better, too. The difficulty curve is a bit wobbly as well, though I enjoyed having some easy stages to "cooldown" with following the tough ones.Unless you're looking for a deep tactical game, none of these rough edges are enough to pull the game down. The game is a love letter to sentai shows and 90s childhood, without any cynicism or irony. It looks back on it with modern eyes, pokes fun at it's own expense, but completely embraces its nostalgia. I loved it!

Posted: January 12, 2016
												Decided to grab this game since I liked Tactics RPGs, and wanted something bright and colorful. Came into the game with pretty "meh" expectations and was blown out of the water.As someone who watched Power Rangers when I was little, this game is an absolute nostalgia trip, while at the same time parodying a lot of the tropes of the sentai genre. The game starts with the protagonists getting a tutorial from their overbearing boss before quitting to form their own sentai studio. You get to name all your rangers, choose their colors (Even if the palette is rather limited), their mecha, their catchphrases, etc. Though this has no impact on gameplay whatsoever, it adds nicely to the fantasy of running your own show. Gameplay is a relatively simple TRPG where you can only have one of each class, Assist, Tech, Assault, Scout, and Lead. This prevents a lot of the cheese strategies that are common in TRPGs like Fire Emblem and Final Fantasy Tactics. This game's difficulty in actual fights is usually pretty low. Instead the difficulty comes from getting your Audience meter filled up and then keeping it filled. The best way to fill it up is by doing flips, team moves, special attacks, and Director's Instructions, which are special submissions that can range from "Don't lose any of your team members" to "win in 5 turns" to "Defeat the boss before defeating any minions." The gameplay, despite being turnbased, really does a great job of showing how a sentai show usually plays out, and its very easy to see how cool everything would look to the eyes of a child watching the show at home. The only major gameplay flaw is that my scout always felt useless. Next to the rapid-fire skills of the Tech, the massive healing from the Assist, the raw damage and acrobatics bonus of the Assault, and the tankiness of the Lead, the Scout... moves an extra space every turn. This would be alright if his damage were anything special, but either my choice of actor or gear for my scout meant that he was consistently doing less damage than the healer. Though the scout does get several crowd control abilties, they all require him to be in the midst of battle, and the Scout's frailty means that these are very risky to use past Season 3.Graphics are psuedo 16-bit, bright colorful and cheery graphics with some great sprite art. Not quite on the same level as Undertale's sprite art, but its all still very appealing. Boss designers are all unique and, with a few exceptions, creative. Though you'll be fighting in th same 7 or so locals a lot, I'm willing to write that up as part of the parody. Besides, the locations are all great looking and have enough functional differences from one another to keep you on your toes.That's not to say the game is perfect. While the game is generally humorous, there are more than a few spots where I felt as though the game was expecting me to laugh and I didn't. Mecha fighting is pretty boring and one dimensional, and is usually the worst part of any mission its included in, which is a shame since a lot of its moves and parts are references to Mecha anime like Gurren Lagann and NGE, references I would appreciate a lot more if it wasn't part of the most boring part of the game. There's crafting, which is already a very played out mechanic that seems to pop up in every game nowadays, but at least here it fits the fantasy of everything on a sentai show being handmade and crappy looking. There's also multiple things that seem to ride the line between satire and unironic crapiness. When you reach Season 3, most of that season's plot revolves around your Lead growing an ego, which is a trite and boring plot line used in every sentai show ever. Are you trying to make fun of these trite and boring plots, Chrome Squad, or was your plot for Season 3 just trite and boring? Or did I just answer my own question?Despite those flaws, I'd be wrong if I said this game was bad. The game just has so much heart and dedication put into it, the gameplay is fun, the visuals were colorful and the plot is meta-tastic goofiness. While the game didn't make me burst out laughing or bawl my eyes out, it was just so delightful I can't help but recommend it. If you love Tactics RPGs or Sentai shows, consider it a double recommendation.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Pros:Customize your team with various actors, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.Further customize your characters with various stat-increasing gear choices and weapon types.Responding to emails seems to provide variation in the storyline, or just give you goodies or fans.Upgrade your base to provide various buffs to your team.Optional crafting system; just buy from the store if you can't be bothered.Winning the fight is only part of the game; try to maximize audience, fans, and income as well.Light-hearted, otherworldly story with plenty of comedy.Cons:Only five party members and predetermined classes limit team customization.Unable to cancel your movement action, even if you haven't taken any other actions; annoying if you misclick a location, or misjudge distance for a ranged attack.Characters don't level up, only gaining skills and stats from equipment and progressing through the story "seasons"Since characters don't level up, and you can't rerun past content for money or crafting components, you can't grind to level up and make the game easier on yourself even if you want to.You can only see tile markers on tiles you can move or attack to, sometimes making it difficult to judge positioning for ranged attacks.You cannot customize whether UP is Up-Left or Up-Right if using a gamepad; you just have to get used to it.A goofy, lovable Turn-based Strategy that reminds me of Disgaea. A type of game all too rare on PC. Definitely recommend to fans of Turn-based Strategy games such as Disgaea or Final Fantasy Tactics.

												Ok first off let me just say that I was never big into Power Rangers, but THIS game just blows me away! I love tactical RPGs, and this game is amazing. From the quirky/cheezy lines, to the amazing combat when you team up, this game brings 90's style live-action TV to you. Everything about this game screams Power Rangers, and that's a good thing! Posted: July 5, 2015
												This game is exactly what Kickstarter should be about: interesting idea, fantastic development team, and, most importantly, delivery of a finished product. The game itself blends a business management simulation on the macro level and a tactical RPG for an episode of the TV series, played for greatest theatrical effect. The animation is simplistic and minimized, but that's okay. This game oozes nostalgia, and coming off as "Mario Brothers-esque" is not an insult. Music and graphical interface are smooth, but some small issues have arisen with different computers. The biggest selling point is by far the writing; snark and self-referential humor make reading the dialogue part of the experience rather than a chore. As an added bonus, there is a fast forward option via pressing the enter key. It's one of the many little details that says this studio cares about the fan experience. The only real downside I can think of is the menu system: clunky and no real way to make transitions between the various sub menus easier, but perhaps that is just the nature of a game that puts you in charge of so many details. That being said, the positives outweigh the negatives by several orders of magnitude. Pick this little gem up; even at full price, it's a bargain.

Posted: March 23
												Chroma Squad is a nicely simple tactics RPG and a very cute parody/homage to Power Rangers and Super Sentai. Tactics RPGs can be hard to get into because they're often 100+ hour epics with large numbers of characters, classes, and items to sort through; Chroma Squad strips away a lot of that to create a tactics RPG that doesn't require the same level of commitment, while keeping enough elements to maintain a certain level of strategic depth. For the most part, beating the missions is relatively easy - the tricky part is usually trying to fulfill the optional objections to maximize your audience. This worked pretty well as a way of challenging the player without punishing them too much for the occasional failure. Unfortunately, the giant mecha fights are more difficult and rely fairly heavily on luck.The character statistics are pretty straightforward, but some of the global boosts aren't as clear as I'd like. For example, how much is +10 Drop Rate? I guess the base Drop Rate is 100, but it doesn't seem to say that anywhere. +2 Fan Conversion Rate and +25% Crafting Rate are similarly unclear.Fortunately, most of these concerns do little to take away from the game's solid core. Chroma Squad is a good fit for both newcomers to the genre and veterans who feel like taking a break from their attempt to 100% complete Disgaea.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												Chroma Squad is a turn-based rpg, where you essentailly run a Sentai show. I personally love this game, it has some great mechanics, and the dialogue is rather impressive and witty. You control most aspects of the "show" from the name of the squad, to the catchphrases that they yell in combat. The story, yes there is a story, is simple and funny. It essentially follow the typical story that you'd expect from any sentai show.It's not a terribly long game, as I'm on 8 hours of gameplay and in my 4th season out of 5 seasons. Each season gradually gains more episodes with various conditions that will gain you more audience/fans. These conditions vary from survive 10 turns to use teamwork acrobatics 5 times. Their simple conditions that give each episode a nice flavor, and occasionally make you play with a different strategy.Overall, it's a fun game. Simple and easy to pick up. Sure the graphics aren't the best, but it fits very nicely with the theme of the game.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Just beat it for my first time, it is a fun few hours of gameplay and since they're are multiple endings and diffrent routes I will be playing it once or twice soon to see them. If you love the Power Rangers then this will be extra funny to you I bet. I loved the villain, loved the growth of the characters, I really just loved most of this game. They're are a few issues I have with it though for example it is annoying that if you loose your Assist member you loose 95% of all healing and can never revive anyone unles you Chromatize/power up, and the fact most of the NPC allies aren't seen or mentioned again was a little disapointing though I understood why. All in all I really loved this game especially when I finished it and got to see the Villains 'dance' to the ending theme, kind of wished your squad was dancing during this as well to celebrate they're job well done but whatever.If they make a sequel or DLC I am likely to buy it and I am not the biggest fan of PC gaming, but I would love to see if they keep this story going, have the timeline of this game alter the next, or if we get to see the current squad follow something like the power rangers with the changing of powers and rosters because it's mentioned in game that happened before.Again really love this game and think it is at the least worth a try.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												It's a fun, light-hearted game! It's got good (not fantastic) music, a decent set of strategy mechanics, a fun and mostly light story, giant mechs, and an engaging, but lightweight TV show budget simulatorIt's a jack-of-all-games. It's a turn based strategy, 2-D mech fighting, TV show simulator. Though, by the end of the 4th season (out of 5), money management ceases to exist because your set is bankrolled enough to fund the wildest expenditures with ease. Combat is also too easy, with some straight up OP characters and pants-on-head AI. The enemy will spread out it's attacks amongst your team rather than congregating together to fight a single weak enemy, thus losing is almost laughably hard. That being said, team acrobatics, team attacks, and finding the sweet spot with AOE attacks are honestly delightful.It's not super strategic, but it's a genuinely fun and widely appealing indie game.

												Only in about 8~> hours. But I'm already having ideas for my next playthrough.
