Posted: July 2, 2015
												As a huge toku fanboy, I was excited to see a video game based on Super Sentai. One that kept in the spirit of sentai by parodying it, and at the same time, paying tribute to it. I've been following this game since Kickstarter, but only more recently got a chance to buy it with the Steam Sale.As far as the gameplay goes, it actually managed to exceed my expectations. Everything is controlled by mouse and things like the the teamwork mechanic and skills you can switch out are things I've seen in other games, but this is one of the better ones in recent memory. Teamwork is more than just an extra person to help you attack, you can also use teamwork to get to spaces much farther on the field and pull off specials using it. This really helped me when trying to accomplish the special requirements. The game never felt imbalanced, too, which is awesome because it's the easiest trap to fall in with strategy RPGs.When you start a new game, you're given the option of picking your team. While I wish there was more options for party members (DLC/Chroma Squad 2?), what characters they do have are very diverse and I think they have just a right amount of options for character selections. The plot itself is the exact same regardless of who you pick, so the main reason to do this is to decide your character's starting stats and which ones you would like to see for the rest of the game, which I really like a lot. The easy way out would have been to just always have them in the suit and choose their stats, or just have your five chosen for you. It even allows there to be a possible lesbian romance later on in the game depending on what gender you pick a certain ranger. Your main five are completely customizable.As for the story itself, it's not like a mind blowing story or anything like that, but it does it's job of feeling like the power ranger/super sentai shows the game is based on. The end goal is defeating a big bad guy, and on the way, you defeat a ton of different monsters ranging from ridiculous to...well, more ridiculous. There's also trophies, multiple endings, storyline branches, and three difficulties to add some replay value.There's one place this game falls flat for me, and I don't think it's major, because it only really started to bother me nearing the end. The humor in this game can be funny at times, and then at other times can get a little groan worthy with the memes. I don't mind a lot of the refernces. The non-comedic ones for sentai fans in the weapons/equipment/skills that referenced a bunch of different sentai series all made me smile when I realized the references, and certain jokes work really well. At one point, they reference the "What has science done" image with the Seagull with massive biceps, and jokes like that and the backstreet boys/lady gaga references work really well, but when it's just meme, after meme, after meme, it starts to get a little grating, not unlike being in the presence of an middle aged person who goes on Reddit.Still, I would recommend this to anybody looking for a fun and quirky little RPG. It's definitely worth the price. I still have two more ending paths and minor storyline branches to get, so I may update this in the future, but having just completed my first playthrough, I just wanted to share my thoughts on it.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Pros:Customize your team with various actors, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.Further customize your characters with various stat-increasing gear choices and weapon types.Responding to emails seems to provide variation in the storyline, or just give you goodies or fans.Upgrade your base to provide various buffs to your team.Optional crafting system; just buy from the store if you can't be bothered.Winning the fight is only part of the game; try to maximize audience, fans, and income as well.Light-hearted, otherworldly story with plenty of comedy.Cons:Only five party members and predetermined classes limit team customization.Unable to cancel your movement action, even if you haven't taken any other actions; annoying if you misclick a location, or misjudge distance for a ranged attack.Characters don't level up, only gaining skills and stats from equipment and progressing through the story "seasons"Since characters don't level up, and you can't rerun past content for money or crafting components, you can't grind to level up and make the game easier on yourself even if you want to.You can only see tile markers on tiles you can move or attack to, sometimes making it difficult to judge positioning for ranged attacks.You cannot customize whether UP is Up-Left or Up-Right if using a gamepad; you just have to get used to it.A goofy, lovable Turn-based Strategy that reminds me of Disgaea. A type of game all too rare on PC. Definitely recommend to fans of Turn-based Strategy games such as Disgaea or Final Fantasy Tactics.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												A light tactical RPG for people who appreciate making robots out of buckets. Not terribly difficult, but also not very deep.The game starts very slow, but picks up considerably about seven hours in. This game scratched an itch, but might be too little, too late for some people. I'd recommend waiting for a sale.More in depth, I'm a little disappointed with the tactical depth of combat. There aren't many ways to mitigate damage during combat. It feels like enemies can attack at arbitrary ranges and move across the map at will. All-out attack is usually the best option, tempered only by the games scoring system, which encourages drawing fights out longer. Even seven hours in, I only have access to one crowd control skill, and very limited area attacks.The crafting system seems expansive, but the game is very stingy with crafting materials, which is a problem for the mech combat minigame. I found myself buying items from the shop just to try breaking them down into spare parts. I really wish there was a way to buy the materials you need from the shop. Collecting drops from enemies seems contrary to the theme of the game--why am I making the lead's costumes out of scraps from the extra's costumes? Where are the extras getting their costumes, if I have to craft the main characters'?

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Overall: 9/10Combat:  8/10:  Combat system consists of move and attack phase with the additional options to go into teamwork mode or use free actions.  You gain audience members as you defeat badguys, achieve mission objectives, and do special moves or use teamwork.  The common enemies are just that - common, you will see the same enemies throughout the game though they upgrade in power and stats (as do you).  The bosses are great, as with most of the game they are made with humor and they have unique skills and play styles.  There is another type of combat you go into, I dont want to spoil it but if you watched power rangers you probably know what it is.  Generally this mode of combat has you fighting and gaining combos which power up special moves.  During the enemy attack phase you play a mini game where you try to click at the right moment to minimize damage.  I give combat 8/10 because the difficulty scales weird.  I felt underpowered initially but by midway into the game I was stomping on most missions.K I'll finish this review later I gtg for now.  My Truly Honest Opinion: Get this game, you won't regret it.  It doesn't matter if you're a 90's kid or if you watched power rangers (though it makes it all the more better),  if you did not get any of its references or jokes I still feel this game is solid and worth the 15 dollars.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Chroma Squad is full of style with its fun writing, simple yet engaging gameplay, and so close to copyright infringement for all its references it's not even funny. In the game you control a group of people that run a live-action power rangers rip off show where they fight evil baddies and have huge mecha fights. Before you start one of these levels though (referred to as episodes in game), you have to micromanage your money at your studio (It is a t.v. show after all), in this section you purchase upgrades for your studio and purchase equipment for characters and such and it is surprisingly engaging how much thought I personally put in to figure out where to put my resources, did I want to put more money towards purchasing materials to craft cardboard box equipment, or did I want to invest in marketing agencies to increase my fanbase and reap extra benefits for a few episodes? It gives you enough to manage without overwhelming you. The combat is your typical tactical rpg with skills and classes and such,however there is a nice little temawork mechanic where if you set a character to teamwork mode you can assist other teammates in team attacks and acrobatics for more movement adding a little extra depth to the combat. Mecha fights play differently as when you're fighting bigger monsters you play a sort of risk-reward turn based game, you basically have hit chance and damage multiplier, whenever you attack and hit the monster you get to keep combo-ing them with attacks and other abilities and as long as you land hits, for every successful hit your damage for the next attack goes up, however it has a lower chance of hitting and when you miss it becomes the monsters turn, this also employs a decent amount of strategy but can ultimately feel like luck sometimes, its still enjoyable and doesn't detract from the main gameWhen it comes to customization this game handles that aspect very well allowing customization of not only characters, but even the customization of the company, you can name the super hero squad whatever you like as well as the mechas and what they shout when they suit up, heck if you wanted to you could even theme the whole thing around butts! Butt Squad! Mecha Butt! Butter up! There is a great amount of customization in the game!Overall it comes down to this:Do you like Power ranger esque tactical rpgs with funny parody writing, lots of customization, and fun gameplay, while micromanaging your own butt studio?Then Chroma Squad is for you8/10

Posted: January 12, 2016
												Decided to grab this game since I liked Tactics RPGs, and wanted something bright and colorful. Came into the game with pretty "meh" expectations and was blown out of the water.As someone who watched Power Rangers when I was little, this game is an absolute nostalgia trip, while at the same time parodying a lot of the tropes of the sentai genre. The game starts with the protagonists getting a tutorial from their overbearing boss before quitting to form their own sentai studio. You get to name all your rangers, choose their colors (Even if the palette is rather limited), their mecha, their catchphrases, etc. Though this has no impact on gameplay whatsoever, it adds nicely to the fantasy of running your own show. Gameplay is a relatively simple TRPG where you can only have one of each class, Assist, Tech, Assault, Scout, and Lead. This prevents a lot of the cheese strategies that are common in TRPGs like Fire Emblem and Final Fantasy Tactics. This game's difficulty in actual fights is usually pretty low. Instead the difficulty comes from getting your Audience meter filled up and then keeping it filled. The best way to fill it up is by doing flips, team moves, special attacks, and Director's Instructions, which are special submissions that can range from "Don't lose any of your team members" to "win in 5 turns" to "Defeat the boss before defeating any minions." The gameplay, despite being turnbased, really does a great job of showing how a sentai show usually plays out, and its very easy to see how cool everything would look to the eyes of a child watching the show at home. The only major gameplay flaw is that my scout always felt useless. Next to the rapid-fire skills of the Tech, the massive healing from the Assist, the raw damage and acrobatics bonus of the Assault, and the tankiness of the Lead, the Scout... moves an extra space every turn. This would be alright if his damage were anything special, but either my choice of actor or gear for my scout meant that he was consistently doing less damage than the healer. Though the scout does get several crowd control abilties, they all require him to be in the midst of battle, and the Scout's frailty means that these are very risky to use past Season 3.Graphics are psuedo 16-bit, bright colorful and cheery graphics with some great sprite art. Not quite on the same level as Undertale's sprite art, but its all still very appealing. Boss designers are all unique and, with a few exceptions, creative. Though you'll be fighting in th same 7 or so locals a lot, I'm willing to write that up as part of the parody. Besides, the locations are all great looking and have enough functional differences from one another to keep you on your toes.That's not to say the game is perfect. While the game is generally humorous, there are more than a few spots where I felt as though the game was expecting me to laugh and I didn't. Mecha fighting is pretty boring and one dimensional, and is usually the worst part of any mission its included in, which is a shame since a lot of its moves and parts are references to Mecha anime like Gurren Lagann and NGE, references I would appreciate a lot more if it wasn't part of the most boring part of the game. There's crafting, which is already a very played out mechanic that seems to pop up in every game nowadays, but at least here it fits the fantasy of everything on a sentai show being handmade and crappy looking. There's also multiple things that seem to ride the line between satire and unironic crapiness. When you reach Season 3, most of that season's plot revolves around your Lead growing an ego, which is a trite and boring plot line used in every sentai show ever. Are you trying to make fun of these trite and boring plots, Chrome Squad, or was your plot for Season 3 just trite and boring? Or did I just answer my own question?Despite those flaws, I'd be wrong if I said this game was bad. The game just has so much heart and dedication put into it, the gameplay is fun, the visuals were colorful and the plot is meta-tastic goofiness. While the game didn't make me burst out laughing or bawl my eyes out, it was just so delightful I can't help but recommend it. If you love Tactics RPGs or Sentai shows, consider it a double recommendation.

												A creative tribute to the Tokusatsu genre that many have grown up to or still enjoy. Having team work and acrobatics effect audience levels was an interesting mechanic that allowed to the player to decide on how much of either to do to maximize the attendance to gain more fans/money per episode. The attendance machanic in general seemed a bit easy to abuse to an extent, should have a negative factor if either is overly used.Having different characters to choose from at the beginning for each role is a really nice touch. This allows the player to choose how they would like to play their games, and not have a stagnant gameplay with fixed characters for the storyline only.Storyline progressed at a decent pace and was well thought out in respect to what Tokusatsu's usually revolved around. But also adding in a bit of flare by blurring reality with fiction.One thing that was unimpressive after a few levels would be the minion's designs. Posted: July 18, 2015
												Good game - the isometric combat is fun due to the characters having not just different abilities, but such different abilities that it feels good when you figure out a way they can co-operate to take down a monster. For example in one of the later levels I had to kill the boss with a certain character ("A") - 4 of the 6 team members were knocked out, the 2 survivors only had a few points of health left and were surrounded by powerful enemies - but the medic was *just* able to run inbetween A and the boss, so that A could leapfrog across the screen and give the boss one last punch, which was enough to win. The game is entirely set-piece scenarios, but the whole thing was like that: if someone scores a critical hit in a round all the tactics have to adapt. The other good thing is that the combat system rewards you for using sentai-hero logic, rather than X-Com logic. It's not about finding a weakness and exploting it, it's about trying and failing and returning again in a stronger form.There are some downsides. Only 1 gamesave. There aren't any random levels which I think is quite a bold decision: the bosses and stage layouts are little works of art: I can see that just bashing randomly-placed waves of minions would get dull. But I'd still have liked to try it - some games have a horde mode where you survive as long as possible, even if it didn't work in practice it would have made me appreciate the scripting more, I think.A side effect of everything being tightly scripted (except what actually happens in a battle) is that you can't build up or replenish resources (money and crafting materials) so if you wanted to go back and try a different character build then you couldn't (not that there are many, it isn't RPG-ish, just that you can select a couple of types of equipment for each of the 5-6 set characters). The writing is a bit odd: the overarching plot is somehow *even more* disjointed than Power Rangers, and they have tried to make *every* *single* *line* into a joke: but the layer of abstraction inbetween and the way they set each episode up to satirize the genre is ingenious - almost worthy of Charlie Kaufman at points. The stunt actors are on the way to film a scene, but monsters kidnap one of them, and when the others rescue her the first thing they ask is whether she has brought any food back (on the story's logic she was off the set).The mecha battles are both disappointing and an excellent rendition of kaiju battles. Round 1: you win. Round 2: they win. Round 3: it's really close but you power attack charges up again just in the nick of time. The mecha's abilities upgrade, the monsters' abilities change, but the traditional pattern is honoured. They're only short, so it isn't annoying - but a tiny bit more mechanics wouldn't have gone amiss like choosing which weapons to take into which fights. In a real super-robot series they would have occasionally had the kindly scientist invent a jetpack so it could fight a flying monster, or something - just for variety.Overall great fun though.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Now, I know what you must be thinking about this game at the moment...  "What?  A Power Rangers rip off game?  What the fruity pebbles is this doing on steam?"  Well, I will tell you what the fruity pebbles this is doing on steam, It is being one of the better games on steam as of this moment.It is quite literally a parody of power rangers, because it was quite literally inspired by the same show.  The combat system revolves around the turn-based combat system, but with tactical movements and everything.  You have your basic healer, fast person, tech person, heavy hitter, and balanced fighter.  Using these five (or less) characters, you spend actions fighting an enemy squad of minions which would be followed up by a boss.  Since the characters you are playing as are "actors of their own Sentai Show," a lot of their armors, weapons, skills, and enemies would look studio-made (or for lack of better words, artificial).  Also, if you have a vast knowledge of puns, jokes, or can catch onto references or parodical-cameos of other characters of the past 15 years, then you will chuckle at all of the things Chroma Squad throws at you.There are also SUPER ROBOT VS. KAIGU {Sorry if I butchered the name} battles, where you go into your own Power Ranger-esque Robot that would fight giant sized versions of the bosses on top of the cities.  And you can customize even your own robot...  OH, and speaking of customization, you get to customize your squad (appearance AND names AND species AND ranger color), your studio name, the hero group's name, the robot's name, and a whole lot of other things!  Meaning you can make the squad as personal as you want :3!Also, this game's soundtract is very addicting, as I would catch m.yself not playing the game as I just enjoy the amazingness of the soundtrack that plays in the battles.And this game is very replayable as there are three seperate endings...  as of this moment, I haven't seen any of them, and I have only heard of one of them and I hate one of my friends who spoiled a little bit of that ending for me >:(...  But since I hope you haven't been spoiled yet either, I assure you that if all of the endings are as good as what I heard one of the endings was going to be, it will be amazing!In conclusion, this game should be on the top of you MUST BUY RIGHT NOW lists, as it is addicting, has a great soundtrack, has SO MUCH CUSTOMIZATION, and has laughs from the start of the game AAAALL the way to the end.  You'll enjoy it, I swear on it!  :D

Posted: February 17, 2016
												Simple Turn-based tactics RPG that brings in a few unique mechanics to the genre.Gameplay straddles a fine line between making things intuitive but not too simple while giving you just enough but not too much stuff to play around with. The crafting system is multiple layers of RNG buggery and it leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth sometimes.  You can work around it but meh.The pacing is fairly on point and the game never really overstays its welcome.There are Super Robot Fights, though it's easily the weakest part of the game currently.  They're also gathering feedback and have announced an overhaul, so this point may become moot in a couple of months.Aesthetics are colorful with a strong indie feel (it's an indie, kickstarted game so yeah).  16 bit and the like.The writing assumes that you've watched at least 2-3 episodes of power rangers and have a passing knowledge of certain internet memes that came out within a specific timeframe (I had to google a couple things).  I enjoyed it.  It has the right kind of corn and ham that'll get me to sensibly chuckle most of the time.and again, the pacing is pretty strong despite the source material.I highly recommend configuring your super sentai team away from the defaults to fit your preferences as it can greatly improve your gameplay experience.  My team was called the Rude Rollers, they Rolled Out, and my robot was named Pablo Escobar (he shanked giant monsters).A single run may take like 6-8 hours and there are multiple endings.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												I received Chroma Squad in the Humble Monthly Bundle earlier this year.  Having never heard of it, I decided to give it a chance.  This is a turn based game where you control a team of five stunt actors who decide to start their own power rangers show.  Every 'battle' is one episode, so you go through the setup and fundraising for the studio and costumes and such, and then enter filming, which is essentially the episode.  Failing to win the battle causes you to get bad ratings on your show.  If you have positive feelings towards Power Rangers from your childhood, and you like lighter-side story centered RPG strategy games, you'd probably like this.  Its strong points are numerous; it has item crafting, a good story, challenging but not overly brutal strategy, combat is fun, good humor, likeable characters, nostalgia (without leaning on it too heavily), etc.Weak points might be that some mechanics can be a little tedious.  Kaiju battles never got boring for me (there's like 8 or so in the game) but they're all pretty similar.  Also, some people don't like pixel graphics, so if that's not your thing then move on.  Also, the game tries (and succeeds) in capturing the campy nature of power rangers style shows, so if that's going to make you cringe then you could consider it a weak feature.

Posted: April 4
Product received for free
												Full Disclosure: As a member of press, I received this game for free from the developer. I also make a cameo in the game. Created as a love letter to shows like Power Rangers and Super Sentai, Behold Studios created a great game for fans of the tokusatsu drama, turn based RPGS, or quirky stories. Your team of heroes (named by you) is highly customizable, with tons of items, special moves, and so many tricks between characters that you'll be hard pressed to play the same game twice. This game is definitely a recommendation.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												It's an easy to pick up tactical RPG inspired by super sentai themed shows (aka Power Rangers, if you're in the USA). The premise is light-hearted and often lends itself to some enjoyable comedy. The balance between RPG and TV studio management at first might seem like a chore, but growing both sides turned out to be enjoyable for me. Struggling to get a leg up and gradually improving your team's costumes to get more fans to get more stuff for your studio/cast is a rewarding cycle of endeavors. I hadn't even heard of this game until I got it in a Humble Bundle with some other things I wanted. I am not disappointed so far!One thing I didn't like was that the mech battles seem to be driven by RNG in the worst possible way. 75% chance to hit = you will miss 90% of the time. Just a heads up.update: if absolutely awful final bosses are a pet peeve of yours, you should avoid this game. 99% of it is *sooo* good. And then the final boss is a teleporting enemy with the worst arena layout. Get close to attack, he teleports and then it takes your squad like 4 turns to reach him. 2 hits, then he teleports across the arena again. Instead of being strategic, it's just unnecessarily drawn out and boring. The game still gets a positive rec from me, but I don't know what the devs were thinking when they made the finale.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												It's a fun, light-hearted game! It's got good (not fantastic) music, a decent set of strategy mechanics, a fun and mostly light story, giant mechs, and an engaging, but lightweight TV show budget simulatorIt's a jack-of-all-games. It's a turn based strategy, 2-D mech fighting, TV show simulator. Though, by the end of the 4th season (out of 5), money management ceases to exist because your set is bankrolled enough to fund the wildest expenditures with ease. Combat is also too easy, with some straight up OP characters and pants-on-head AI. The enemy will spread out it's attacks amongst your team rather than congregating together to fight a single weak enemy, thus losing is almost laughably hard. That being said, team acrobatics, team attacks, and finding the sweet spot with AOE attacks are honestly delightful.It's not super strategic, but it's a genuinely fun and widely appealing indie game.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												As a huge toku fanboy, I was excited to see a video game based on Super Sentai. One that kept in the spirit of sentai by parodying it, and at the same time, paying tribute to it. I've been following this game since Kickstarter, but only more recently got a chance to buy it with the Steam Sale.As far as the gameplay goes, it actually managed to exceed my expectations. Everything is controlled by mouse and things like the the teamwork mechanic and skills you can switch out are things I've seen in other games, but this is one of the better ones in recent memory. Teamwork is more than just an extra person to help you attack, you can also use teamwork to get to spaces much farther on the field and pull off specials using it. This really helped me when trying to accomplish the special requirements. The game never felt imbalanced, too, which is awesome because it's the easiest trap to fall in with strategy RPGs.When you start a new game, you're given the option of picking your team. While I wish there was more options for party members (DLC/Chroma Squad 2?), what characters they do have are very diverse and I think they have just a right amount of options for character selections. The plot itself is the exact same regardless of who you pick, so the main reason to do this is to decide your character's starting stats and which ones you would like to see for the rest of the game, which I really like a lot. The easy way out would have been to just always have them in the suit and choose their stats, or just have your five chosen for you. It even allows there to be a possible lesbian romance later on in the game depending on what gender you pick a certain ranger. Your main five are completely customizable.As for the story itself, it's not like a mind blowing story or anything like that, but it does it's job of feeling like the power ranger/super sentai shows the game is based on. The end goal is defeating a big bad guy, and on the way, you defeat a ton of different monsters ranging from ridiculous to...well, more ridiculous. There's also trophies, multiple endings, storyline branches, and three difficulties to add some replay value.There's one place this game falls flat for me, and I don't think it's major, because it only really started to bother me nearing the end. The humor in this game can be funny at times, and then at other times can get a little groan worthy with the memes. I don't mind a lot of the refernces. The non-comedic ones for sentai fans in the weapons/equipment/skills that referenced a bunch of different sentai series all made me smile when I realized the references, and certain jokes work really well. At one point, they reference the "What has science done" image with the Seagull with massive biceps, and jokes like that and the backstreet boys/lady gaga references work really well, but when it's just meme, after meme, after meme, it starts to get a little grating, not unlike being in the presence of an middle aged person who goes on Reddit.Still, I would recommend this to anybody looking for a fun and quirky little RPG. It's definitely worth the price. I still have two more ending paths and minor storyline branches to get, so I may update this in the future, but having just completed my first playthrough, I just wanted to share my thoughts on it.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												Ahhh Chroma Squad, where to begin... I know!TL;DRChroma squad is a fantastic action startegy game with an in depth, self aware story. With a well written set of dialogue, and a surprisingly deep combat system Chroma Squad is sure to please strategy fans... even if you haven't seen power rangers!Chroma Squad, in an depth action strategy game that never ceases to amaze me! With large a (and albeit, very obvious) inspiration from Sabans Power Ranger. Chroma Squad is a game that will make you want to relive your childhood... and at the same time want to destroy it. You see Chroma Squad's difficulty system can be changed on the fly for those of you who don't want to think... If you do enjoy a challenge however, play the game on hard mode (warning! PLAN ABOUT THREE STEPS AHEAD ON HARD). This game can, and will kick you in the rear so hard you won't remember what you planned to do afterwards.Chroma Squad has a very (from what I have played) unique system called teamwork. This system allows your teamates to perform double, tiple, even quadruple attacks (similar fire emblem fates), but there is a catch... teamwork is the only way to use your finisher (a vital tool later on) , and can allow your team to move further on the set! Now you may be wondering what can make this game so difficult, IMO I believe Chroma Squad is one of the few games that got difficulty right. It doesn't just swarm you with hundreds of cheap, or extremely powerful enemies, atleast not in the beginning. Chroma Squad has a real sense of growth meaning that as you get stronger the game can and WILL adapt.Mecha battles, this feature surprised me. when I had my first mecha battle I was pleasently surprised. Though simple the mecha battle can really make you question your "startegic genius" and really mke you pull your hair out if not careful.To sum it up, this game seems very simple, and easy on your first run. That fact can be a lie, the game can be very challenging to the extreme on the harder difficulties, and the AI can be very ruthless and capitalize on every mistake you make. The premise is great, and the game has this atmosphere that I find hard to explain, but enjoy. The mecha battles are a nice break from the normal gameplay. Worth a buy. if you watched Power Rangers for sure!My score: 5/5 (6/5 if you enjoyed Power Rangers as a child)

												This game is overall a fantastic game. It has very fun gameplay, a pretty decent story, and good mechanics to it, but there is a huge flaw with the game in my opinion and that is the mech fights. The reason I think they are flawed is because the fights are extremely luck based. It doesn't have any strategy to it at all. It's pretty much, "Am I feeling lucky enough to punch again with a 74% chance to hit and leave myself completely vulenerable if I miss and even if I do hit, am I feeling lucky enough to do it again with a now 64% chance to hit?" You don't get to upgrade your mech very much either which just makes the upgrades extremely obselete the futher you go into the game. My mech is fully upgraded with the max studio buff giving an extra 15% health to my mech, but after 4th season, I have not been able to win any mech battle without failing at least once. the mech battles just seriously disappoint me because other than that there isn't really much to complain about aside from a few non-intrusive bugs and because of how good the rest of the game is, it just accentuates to terribleness of the mech battles. My overall review of the game still comes out to be an 8/10 anyway.

Posted: January 1
												I love this game to bits.Absolutely zero regrets about buying it.I just finished playing through on the Normal difficulty. I wouldn't consider myself good at strategy games, and I found it to be generally rather easy most of the time (while trying to accomplish every Director's Instruction). I also never had to replay any of the levels, though I did put a good amount of thought between missions on what to purchase and upgrade. Anyone who often plays or enjoys strategy games should probably pick the hardest difficulty if they're looking for a proper challenge. It's there, though it probably wouldn't be the hardest game out there, by far.There is so much to love about this game. Adorable and lovably drawn art, simplified but thought-out gameplay, and a very funny and self-aware representation of Indie Sentai filmmaking. You even get to pick your characters out of a good list of choices, choose their colour, and names. The costumes even change depending on what they have equipped, seriously.It comes out as 'one-of-those-games-that-aren't-really-that-deep-but-it-really-doesn't-need-to-be' kind of games. It isn't the longest game out there either (it does have multiple endings though), so if you've only got a few dollars to throw around, you ought to wait for a sale.You have to play this one and really feel the love and spirit put into it. If you even remotely enjoy the strategy genre or enjoy Sentai-style films like Power Rangers, Kamen Rider, or anything of the sort- this is practically a MUST-play.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												Ahhh Chroma Squad, where to begin... I know!TL;DRChroma squad is a fantastic action startegy game with an in depth, self aware story. With a well written set of dialogue, and a surprisingly deep combat system Chroma Squad is sure to please strategy fans... even if you haven't seen power rangers!Chroma Squad, in an depth action strategy game that never ceases to amaze me! With large a (and albeit, very obvious) inspiration from Sabans Power Ranger. Chroma Squad is a game that will make you want to relive your childhood... and at the same time want to destroy it. You see Chroma Squad's difficulty system can be changed on the fly for those of you who don't want to think... If you do enjoy a challenge however, play the game on hard mode (warning! PLAN ABOUT THREE STEPS AHEAD ON HARD). This game can, and will kick you in the rear so hard you won't remember what you planned to do afterwards.Chroma Squad has a very (from what I have played) unique system called teamwork. This system allows your teamates to perform double, tiple, even quadruple attacks (similar fire emblem fates), but there is a catch... teamwork is the only way to use your finisher (a vital tool later on) , and can allow your team to move further on the set! Now you may be wondering what can make this game so difficult, IMO I believe Chroma Squad is one of the few games that got difficulty right. It doesn't just swarm you with hundreds of cheap, or extremely powerful enemies, atleast not in the beginning. Chroma Squad has a real sense of growth meaning that as you get stronger the game can and WILL adapt.Mecha battles, this feature surprised me. when I had my first mecha battle I was pleasently surprised. Though simple the mecha battle can really make you question your "startegic genius" and really mke you pull your hair out if not careful.To sum it up, this game seems very simple, and easy on your first run. That fact can be a lie, the game can be very challenging to the extreme on the harder difficulties, and the AI can be very ruthless and capitalize on every mistake you make. The premise is great, and the game has this atmosphere that I find hard to explain, but enjoy. The mecha battles are a nice break from the normal gameplay. Worth a buy. if you watched Power Rangers for sure!My score: 5/5 (6/5 if you enjoyed Power Rangers as a child)

Posted: February 27
												I really liked this.I was never into the Power Rangers myself, nor a lot of the anime this game pays tribute to. But I don't think that's really required here to appreciate that this game is a love letter to cheesy TV and all the fun people have had with it. Everything in this game is so goofy and so fourth wall breaking wink wink, but it's done in a way I found really charming and sweet, as opposed to, say, Retro City Rampage which just bashed you over the head with how funny it thought it was every 5 seconds (hot tip: it wasn't).There are about five million of these faux-16 bit games now, but here is one that actually uses that effect correctly and accurately. The target audience for this game is, at least in part, people like me that actually remember when 16-bit was real and spectacular, and tactics RPG's were just an emerging thing. There's just enough depth here to be interesting without being something overwhelming to work out, both in terms of the combat and the crafting system. The gimmick with the game is you are playing a fight scene in each episode of the show, and you can get bonuses for fulfilling director's instructions, things like "kill three enemies on a turn" or "use team attacks 4 times", these add enough spice for completionist types without, technically, being neccessary to advance the game.The game isn't flawless, I hit a couple annoying but inconsequential bugs (there's an annoying one with one of the Space Sherrifs where his finisher doesn't actually count as a finisher). There are a couple spelling errors that aren't part of the on-purpose narrator gag (breath/breathe mixup happened at least twice). And I really, really wish this game had saving mid-chapter.But on the whole, I had way more fun with this than I could have ever anticipated. It's cute, almost disgustingly so. But not quite. I got this in the Humble Freedom Bundle which was so large it was inevitable there were several indie games I'd never heard of there. This was the first of those I tried becaue the premise of "some stuntmen quit a TV show to start their own knockoff" is a hilarious, great premise. And I really did enjoy the game from start to finish.Save earth with friendship instead of with ultraviolence? Well, why ever not?

Posted: January 14
												It was hard for me to decide whether to recommend this or not. On the one hand, you've got some fairly smart Power Rangers/Sentai parody work, a fun storyline, and a great aesthetic. On the other hand, the tactical RPG aspect is... very unpolished. Even on medium difficulty, Season 3 really ramps up the challenge level, driven purely by poor design aspects. Unlike most TRPGs, there's no way to undo a move action if you realize you've gone to the wrong square. Healing is also ridiculously thin on the ground given how much damage enemies do the further you go in the game. I had one of my dudes (the scout, who has about average health) taken from full health to zero in a single round.In the end, though, it's still pretty fun, even if the percentages on the material recycling in the crafting menu are complete BS.

Posted: April 7
												Not a game for me. Reasons off the top of my head:- Story, while ok for a short joke, is extremely boring and cliché for a long game. The conversations between the team members really don't help; "I am not good enough" -- "you are an important team member and we all love you" -- "I now know I am good enough" is just infantile writing.- Mecha fighting is trivial with one repeated QTE that is just annoying. Yet is still a gear check, so if you were silly enough to not upgrade your mecha a lot in the start, you can get to impossible fights.- Fighting with your team is reasonably varied, but gets very repetetive after you get far enough into the game.- Fight setup is sloooooooow. Monsters arrive one at a time when fighting is about to start, and later stages have up to 20-25 monsters slowly jumping in and moving into place. Doesn't help when certain fights also do similar summoning of mobs/mines/etc. during them.- Cutscene skipping is not a thing. At best you can fast forward (much too slowly), while the screen shakes, which quite frankly is annoying after the first time you use it.- Studio upgrades (base upgrades, essentially) are not interesting and by mid-game there aren't any more new ones.- Crafting, while interesting, has the very big weak point, that you buy upgrade packs with random items in it, which makes getting specific items annoying. Also, one item for mecha upgrades can only be found in mid-level fights (and certain one-off event), which makes getting specific upgrades for your mecha impossible once you use the last of that item and move on to higher level fights.- I wish games would stop using the method of slowly typing spech one letter at a time for dialogue. Reading is not done by reading each letter and then building the word, it's based on recognizing the entire word and understanding what word it is, which is why you can read text even when all but the first and last letter have been jumbled up. Also, most people can read much faster than what games devs set the speech speed to.I would not recommend this unless you honestly truly love power rangers in the way that bronies love my little pony; the joke setting really doesn't work for a long game and the core gameplay is not strong enough to make up for it.

Posted: February 4
												Chroma Squad is a little, cute game that has spend a fair bit of time just laying in my library. I liked the premise and got my hands on the game, but didn't feel the pressure to try and play it for a while. I have finally decided to give it a shot, and I honestly can't say that I regret that decision. The game is a tactical RPG with minor management elements - you control a squad of five (and later - six) characters, who will fight against sets of enemy minions and bosses. I am not going to discuss a premise, because it is very clearly stated in the description. What I will say, that gameplay-wise, the game is pretty good at what it does. Game is split in two phases - episodes (which consist of combat) and studio management. The combat system is simple, but enjoyable - your characters can use simple melee attacks, weapons and their abilities. There is also a teamwork system, which allows you to attack with a few characters at the same time. In some episodes you also get control of special characters which have some unique abilities of their own. The management part of the game is less robust and in many ways confusing. You can craft equipment for your squad, you can upgrade studio equipment which comes with different bonuses, and you can choose a marketing agency, which also provides you with a set of benefits based on your fans. That part of it all is, however, fairly simplistic and lacks any real depth.The game makes good use of it's theme, and most of the game is enjoyably cheesy. If that's something you are not into, you will probably not enjoy your time with Chroma Squad. It does also take a bizzare twist half way through, but it only adds to the experience in my opinion. There is a single place where the story diverges. It isn't a huge difference, honestly, and happens very late into the game. If you are going to unlock all the achievements, you will have to play through the game three times - and about 80% of each playthrough is going to be identical, sadly.There are some minor issues that I have with the game. The mech combat is extremely repetitive, and if you are planning on finishing up the game in short period of time (I personally did last 2 seasons in one sitting), you will have to do A LOT of mech fighting. A system which is a cool idea, but execution of it is rather lackluster, and you will always be doing the same thing. No matter who you are fighting, the enemy will always have the same pattern - either three basic attacks or one large attack. You just sit there and click the same button time after time, hoping for RNG to work out for you. Another issue right now is the scarcity of information - or at least information which is not being presented in a clear way. There are some terms thrown around without much explanation at all, and at other times information that you could need at any given time is not given to you in the right place. Sure, you could remember it - but you shouldn't have to. I didn't realise you could read buffs and debuffs on your enemy until the last season, because of how unintuitive it is.  While the game has it's flaws, I would still recommend it. There is nothing that actively makes it less fun - the mech combat is a bit of a drag, and management could use more work, but the episodes themselves, with turn-based combat and abilities to use, can be really fun. It's a small and enjoyable experience overall.

Posted: November 13, 2016
												In this game, you play as a team of stuntmen who play Power Rangers on television, and they've gotten fed up with their director and open their own studio doing the exact same thing instead. The plot is rather tongue-in-cheek and "dorky," but with a fun tone and some pleasant music along the way. The gameplay is a bit like the Shadowrun turn-based strategy games on PC if those were all about melee combat instead of ranged. You might say "oh, like Banner Saga?" but I would reply "No, this is actually kinda enjoyable, so it's not that much like Banner Saga." As with Shadowrun, you have abilities with cooldowns that give you a nice edge in combat, and the further into the game you get, the game shows you that there are higher tiers of skills to unlock, making things more interesting than just "run over and punch a dude" each turn.The game has three difficulty levels: one intended to just get through the game without challenge, one to get through it with a little challenge, and a tough version. I played the middle of these three options and found it to be a nice experience that does a good job of teaching you the basics. In between missions ("episodes"), you can buy new equipment for your team, as well as upgrade your studio to incur running costs that give you bonus attitbutes on missions (worth it, from what I experienced).I personally lack the interest in the narrative and the gameplay hasn't fully hooked me in enough for me to want to really continue, but this game has the rare condition of being one I'm stopping playing that I would actually recommend. I could totally see myself playing it through to completion and liking it if I had more time to spend on games that don't pull me in strong. It commits no grave offenses against the player, seems well-balanced, has a lot of heart, and seems fully intended to be a fun and different experience for gamers. If turn-based strategy, goofy/dorky plot, and/or Power Rangers put a smile on your face, this could be a good buy for you, especially on sale or Humble Bundle.

Posted: April 7
												Not a game for me. Reasons off the top of my head:- Story, while ok for a short joke, is extremely boring and cliché for a long game. The conversations between the team members really don't help; "I am not good enough" -- "you are an important team member and we all love you" -- "I now know I am good enough" is just infantile writing.- Mecha fighting is trivial with one repeated QTE that is just annoying. Yet is still a gear check, so if you were silly enough to not upgrade your mecha a lot in the start, you can get to impossible fights.- Fighting with your team is reasonably varied, but gets very repetetive after you get far enough into the game.- Fight setup is sloooooooow. Monsters arrive one at a time when fighting is about to start, and later stages have up to 20-25 monsters slowly jumping in and moving into place. Doesn't help when certain fights also do similar summoning of mobs/mines/etc. during them.- Cutscene skipping is not a thing. At best you can fast forward (much too slowly), while the screen shakes, which quite frankly is annoying after the first time you use it.- Studio upgrades (base upgrades, essentially) are not interesting and by mid-game there aren't any more new ones.- Crafting, while interesting, has the very big weak point, that you buy upgrade packs with random items in it, which makes getting specific items annoying. Also, one item for mecha upgrades can only be found in mid-level fights (and certain one-off event), which makes getting specific upgrades for your mecha impossible once you use the last of that item and move on to higher level fights.- I wish games would stop using the method of slowly typing spech one letter at a time for dialogue. Reading is not done by reading each letter and then building the word, it's based on recognizing the entire word and understanding what word it is, which is why you can read text even when all but the first and last letter have been jumbled up. Also, most people can read much faster than what games devs set the speech speed to.I would not recommend this unless you honestly truly love power rangers in the way that bronies love my little pony; the joke setting really doesn't work for a long game and the core gameplay is not strong enough to make up for it.

Posted: April 22
												Chroma Squad is a game that begs to be great -- begs to be loved -- but just doesn't quite get there.There is something lacking to this game in its basic combat system, and the way it feels. It's difficult to describe, whether attacks just don't feel satisfying, the skills your character possessing not being as useful as they ought to be, or maybe something else that somebody else can better elaborate. It doesn't help that it's almost impossible to pin down if the AI is just a little too good or just stupid enough to get lucky too often. Having played for almost two hours, managing budget, character equipment, studio perks, etc. seems just a little too frustrating and nervewracking.The writing goes for light-hearted and funny, but it's just not up to snuff enough to be charming and actually land. Like everything else, it gets close, but doesn't quite hit the mark. Unfortunately, fixing that doesn't really make the game enjoyable.If only the combat system was made a little more in-depth and satisfying, or if studio/equipment/money management didn't seem so futile, this game could be played and enjoyed. It doesn't even require both -- just one of the two will do the trick. But because the game is as it is, it falls flat and is almost perplexingly boring. And that is such a shame, because it looks fun from the outside -- and from the inside it really feels the game deserving of Chroma Squad's hype is buried just a couple inches away, but nobody's digging deep enough to hit it.

Posted: April 18



YouTube™ Video: Indie Review - Chroma Squad 

			Views: 33		

			Steam Curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/JinReviews#curation Indie DB: http://www.indiedb.com/members/jinreviews/reviews Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/JinReviews/ Twitter:...		

Chroma Squad starts as a simple Strategy Turn-Based Game but it offers many surprises. The teamwork mechanic is a simple concept that opens a lot of choices and suits well with the game genre and setting. Each character has a different role on the team and can be customizable from the name, looks, traits, abilities and equipment, making room for multiple play-styles and different tactics which make the game fell fresh and new as it proceeds. Fans of Sentai (A.K.A. Power Rangers-like shows) will be pleased to see that transforming into your Power Suit and gigantic Mech Battles actually play a role in the game.	Aesthetically the game makes use of Pixel Art with vibrant colors that suits with the lighthearted tone of Chroma Squad. The sound design is spot on with a great Sentai themed main song and a happy chiptune music that fuses together with the game’s vibe. The bosses are really interesting both in abilities and design and also very silly (like the giant pigeon with macho arms) but the minions do start to get a little repetitive specially as they get recycled as stronger versions with a different color scheme. 	The plot is not very forward thriving but it does have some intrigue right from the start and it is a fun setup for the rest of the game. You will most certainly have some good laughs with Chroma Squad as long as you are ready to read through the characters’ dialogues. Although the game is very smartly written, it may sometimes become boresome as the scripted events drag on. As mentioned the game has a very lighthearted tone and it doesn't take itself too seriously which is actually connected to the main story. • Final thoughts	Chroma Squad is a game that excels in the strategic battle gameplay with great, fun core mechanics and offers other pleasant side activities like the Mech Battles, Crafting and Studio Management which make the game flow fell fresh and non-repetitive. The direction of the story may seem a little odd sometimes as the silly, lighthearted, “not taking itself too serious” plot develops but it is a game that I recommend, specially for those who enjoy a really good squad strategy turn-based game.
